original: viruddhanāmapi matānāṃ na sarveṣāṃ prāmāṇyaṃ sambhavati vastuno bahurūpatvābhāvāt /
analyzed: viruddhanām api matānām na sarveṣām prāmāṇyam sambhavati vastunaḥ bahu rūpa tva abhāvāt
translated: Even contradictory opinions cannot all be valid, because a thing cannot have many forms.

analyzed: kintu ekasya atra prāmāṇyam itareṣām aprāmāṇyam vācyam
translated: But one must be declared valid here, and the others invalid.

original: tatra kasya prāmāṇyaṃ kasya vāprāmāṇyamiti punaryudhiṣṭhirajanamejayahārdapraśnottaramāha bhīṣmo vaiśampāyanaśca /
analyzed: tatra kasya prāmāṇyam kasya vā aprāmāṇyam iti punar yudhiṣṭhira janamejaya hārda praśna uttaram āha bhīṣmaḥ vaiśampāyanaḥ ca
translated: There, Bhishma and Vaishampayana answer the question of Yudhishthira, Janamejaya, and Hardi again, as to which is valid and which is invalid.

original: sāṅkhyasya vaktā kapilaḥityārabhya pañcarātrasya kṛtsnasyaityanena jñāneṣu jñānasādhaneṣu etatpañcarātram /
analyzed: sāṅkhyasya vaktā kapilaḥ iti ārabhya pañcarātrasya kṛtsnasya eti anena jñāneṣu jñāna sādhaneṣu etat pañcarātram
translated: The expounder of Sāṅkhya is Kapila, and so on, up to of the entire Pañcarātra - this Pañcarātra is among the knowledges, the means of knowledge.

original: abhiprāyastu paramāptatamena nārāyaṇena sarvasya pañcarātrasya kṛtatvātprāmāṇyaṃ tāvatsiddham /
analyzed: abhiprāyaḥ tu parama āptatamena nārāyaṇena sarvasya pañcarātrasya kṛta tvāt prāmāṇyam tāvat siddham
translated: But the intention is that since the entire Pañcarātra was composed by Nārāyaṇa, the most authoritative one, its authoritativeness is established.

analyzed: viruddhānām ca eka prāmāṇye anya aprāmāṇyam ca
translated: And when there is contradiction, one is authoritative and the other is not.

analyzed: etat ca ādya vākya stha veda āraṇyaka padena veda mūlaka pañcarātrasya uttara vākya stha pañcarātra padena ca mūla bhūta veda āraṇyakasya upalakṣaṇām aṅgīkṛtya ubhayoḥ ekavākya tāyām eva  sambhavati
translated: And this is possible only when there is syntactical unity of the two, accepting the indication by the word Vedānta in the first sentence of the Pañcarātra based on the Veda, and by the word Pañcarātra in the second sentence of the Vedānta which is the basis.

analyzed: anyathā pañcarātrasya pūrvam aprakṛta tvena pūrva uttara vākyayoḥ asaṅgata tva āpātaḥ
translated: Otherwise, since the Pañcarātra was not the subject matter before, there would be the undesirable consequence of lack of connection between the first and second sentences.

original: upalakṣaṇāmaṅgīkṛtyaikavākyatāyāṃ ca svīkṛtāyāṃ vedapañcarātrayoreva prāmāṇayaṃ siddhyati /
analyzed: upalakṣaṇām aṅgīkṛtya eka vākya tāyām ca svīkṛtāyām veda pañcarātrayoḥ eva prāmāṇayam siddhi ati
translated: And when syntactical unity is accepted by accepting the indication, the authoritativeness of only the Veda and the Pañcarātra is established.

analyzed: na tad viruddha pāśupata ādīnām iti teṣām aprāmāṇyam eva iti
translated: And the authoritativeness of the Pāśupata and others which are contradictory to them is not established, so they are indeed unauthoritative.

analyzed: śāstram yoniḥ pramāṇam asya iti śāstra yoni
translated: The treatise is the source, the means of knowledge, of this, therefore it is called having the treatise as its source.

original: evaṃ sūtraṃ vyākhyāya yatpareṇoktaṃ śāstrasya yoniriti tadayuktamiti bhāvena svābhimatārthaṃ darśayati śāstramiti /
analyzed: evam sūtram vyākhyāya yat pareṇa uktam śāstrasya yoniḥ iti tat ayuktam iti bhāvena sva abhimata artham darśayati śāstram iti
translated: Having thus explained the Sūtra, with the idea that what was said by the opponent, that the Sastra has a source, is not proper, he shows his own intended meaning, saying the Sastra etc.

original: kāraṇārthakena yoniśabdena yogyatayā jñaptessambandhe pramāṇamiti paryavasyatītyabhiprāyeṇa 'yoniḥ pramāṇam' /
analyzed: kāraṇa arthakena yoni śabdena yogyatayā jñapteḥ sambandhe pramāṇam iti paryavasyati iti abhiprāyeṇa yoniḥ pramāṇam
translated: With the word source in the sense of cause, the connection of cognition by fitness is concluded as the means of valid knowledge. With this idea, the source is the means of valid knowledge.

analyzed: iti vyākhyātam
translated: It is thus explained.

analyzed: asya jagat kāraṇasya iti śāstra yoni  iti anantaram tuśabdaḥ dhyā ahāryaḥ
translated: Of this, of the cause of the world, this is the source of the Sastra.🔽But the word tu should be supplied after source of the Sastra.

original: ata eva gītābhāṣye iti tu śāstrayonitvamityuktam /
analyzed: atas eva gītā bhāṣye iti tu śāstra yoni tvam iti uktam
translated: For this very reason, in the commentary on the Gita, it is said this is the source of the Sastra.

analyzed: tuḥ eva arthaḥ
translated: Tu has the same meaning.

original: tathā ca śāstraṃ yoniḥ pramāṇaṃ yasya tacchāstrayonītyeva śāstrayonipadārtho brahma /
analyzed: tathā ca śāstram yoniḥ pramāṇam yasya tat śāstrayonī iti eva śāstra yoni padārthaḥ brahma
translated: And thus, Brahman is the meaning of the word source of the Sastra, in the sense that the Sastra is the source, the means of valid knowledge, of that.

analyzed: na tu śāstrasya yoni iti arthaḥ
translated: But not in the sense that it is the source of the Sastra.

analyzed: para vyākhyānam tu ukta anupayuktam ayuktam ca iti ṭīkāyām eva dūṣitam
translated: But the other's explanation is said to be useless and improper, and is refuted in the commentary itself.

analyzed: iti śāstra yoni tva adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on being the source of the Sastra.
The section on the identification of Brahman.

analyzed: ajñānām pratīyamānam api na itareṣām śāstra yoni tvam
translated: Even though it is understood by the ignorant, it is not the source of the Sastra for others.

analyzed: kutas
translated: Why?

analyzed: tat tu samanvayāt
translated: But that is by identification.

analyzed: atra adhikaraṇe jagat kāraṇasya śāstra yoni tvāt na lakṣaṇa ativyāptiḥ iti pūrva adhikaraṇa phala ākṣepa parihāra mukhena
translated: In this section, it is argued that the cause of the world is not beyond the definition because it is the source of the scriptures. To establish that it is the definition by way of resolving the objection raised by the result of the previous section,

original: tasya lakṣaṇatvasiddhaye viṣṇoreva jagatkāraṇatvena śāstragamyatvaṃ netareṣāmapīti samarthyate /
analyzed: tasya lakṣaṇa tva siddhaye viṣṇoḥ eva jagat kāraṇatvena śāstra gamya tvam na itareṣām api iti samarthyate
translated: it is argued that only Vishnu is known through the scriptures as the cause of the world, not others, to establish that He is the definition.

analyzed: pūrvapakṣa sūcana pūrvakam siddhāntam āha ajñānām iti  kartari ṣaṣṭhī iyam
translated: Before indicating the prima facie view, he states the conclusion: ignorant of...🔽The genitive case is used for the agent.

analyzed: itareṣām iti sambandhe  samuccaya arthasya āpeḥ ubhayatra anvayaḥ
translated: Of others is in the relation.🔽The word api (also) has the sense of combination and is construed with both.

analyzed: pratītyā āgama upalakṣaṇāḥ vā
translated: Pratītyā (through) is a metaphor for the scriptures.

analyzed: tathā ca na kevalam pāśupata ādi uktam
translated: And thus, not only what is stated by the Paśupatas,

analyzed: kintu ajñānām
translated: but also ignorant of...

original: śrutitātparyārthājñānibhirāpātataḥ jñāyamānamapi na kevalaṃ viṣṇoḥ kintu 'itareṣāṃ' /
analyzed: śruti tātparya artha ajñānibhiḥ āpātataḥ jñāyamānam api na kevalam viṣṇoḥ kintu itareṣām
translated: Even what is known superficially by those ignorant of the intended meaning of the scriptures, is not only of Vishnu, but also of others,

analyzed: rudra ādīnām api śāstra yoni tvam
translated: of Rudra and others, is the source of the scriptures.

analyzed: jagat kāraṇatvena śāstra gamya tvam na iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are not known through the scriptures as the cause of the world.

original: nanu pratītyāderajñānamūlatvādikaṃ parikalpyānyeṣāṃ kāraṇatayā śāstrayonitvāgrahaṇe ko heturiti pṛcchati kuta iti /
analyzed: nanu pratīti ādeḥ ajñāna mūla tva ādikam parikalpya anyeṣām kāraṇatayā śāstra yoni tva agrahaṇe kaḥ hetuḥ iti pṛcchati kutas iti
translated: But why is it that, assuming that ignorance is the root of belief etc., others are not accepted as the source of the scriptures as causes? He asks this with kutas (why).

analyzed: pratīyamānam api iti anena asya anvayaḥ
translated: The connection of this [word] is with the word 'even though cognized'.

analyzed: tatra hetu kathanāya sūtram upanyasyati tat tu iti
translated: In order to state the reason there, he introduces the aphorism with the word 'tat' (that).

analyzed: yatas ityādau grāhyam
translated: The word 'yataḥ' (from which) etc. should be taken.

analyzed: anvaya upapatti ādi liṅgam
translated: Anvaya (connection) is the reason such as upamāna (analogy).

analyzed: sūtra akṣarāṇi vyācaṣṭe anvayaḥ iti
translated: He explains the letters of the aphorism with the word 'anvaya' (connection).

original: anvīyate svārthena sambadhyate tatparatayā jñāyate śāstraṃ śabdo vānenetyanvayaḥ upapattyāditātparyaliṅgamityarthaḥ /
analyzed: anvīyate svārthena sambadhyate tatpara tayā jñāyate śāstram śabdaḥ vā anena iti anvayaḥ upapatti ādi tātparya liṅgam iti arthaḥ
translated: That by which the scripture or the word is connected with its own meaning, known to be for that purpose, is the connection, which means the reason such as upamāna (analogy) which indicates the purport.

analyzed: sūtra anusārāt ekavacanam samudāya abhiprāyam
translated: The singular number in the aphorism is intended for the collection.

analyzed: tena ca upakrama ādīnām kvacid avirodham sūcayati
translated: And by that, he indicates the non-contradiction of upamāna etc. somewhere.

analyzed: ādi padam śruti liṅga vākya prakaraṇa sthāna samākhyānām api grāhakam
translated: The word 'ādi' (etc.) also includes śruti (scripture), liṅga (reason), vākyas (sentences), prakaraṇa (context), sthāna (place), and samākhyā (etymology).

analyzed: atra śruti ādi ṣaṭkam ca grāhyam iti ṭīkā ukteḥ
translated: Because it is said in the commentary that the group of six beginning with śruti should be taken here.

original: atra vākye śrutyādiṣaṭkamapyādipadena grāhyamiti hi tasyārthaḥ /
analyzed: atra vākye śruti ādi ṣaṭkam api ādi padena grāhyam iti hi tasya arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of that is that in this sentence, the group of six beginning with śruti should also be taken by the word 'ādi'.

analyzed: parantu śruti ādīnām upakrama ādi vat tātparya grāhaka tva abhāvāt āgama artha mātra nirṇāyaka tvāt na atra tad nidarśaka pramāṇa uktiḥ
translated: However, because śruti etc. do not indicate the purport like upamāna etc., because they only determine the meaning of the scripture, there is no statement of the evidence indicating that here.🔽For this very reason, later on...

analyzed: atas eva uttaratra
translated: For this very reason, later on,🔽

original: śrutirliṅgaṃ samākhyā ca vākyaṃ prakaraṇaṃ tathā /
analyzed: śrutiḥ liṅgam samākhyā ca vākyam prakaraṇam tathā
translated: Śruti, liṅga, samākhyā, vākyas, prakaraṇa, and so on,

analyzed: pūrvam pūrvam balīyaḥ syāt evam āgama nirṇaye
translated: the earlier ones are stronger, thus in the determination of the scriptures.

analyzed: iti tatra api pramāṇam vakṣyati
translated: Thus, he will state that it is also a means of knowledge there.

original: uktaṃ hi pramāṇalakṣaṇaṭīkāyām upakramādīnāṃ tātparyaliṅgatvameteṣāṃ punarartha eveti viśeṣajñāpanārtho yogavibhāgaḥiti /
analyzed: uktam hi pramāṇalakṣaṇaṭīkāyām upakrama ādīnām tātparya liṅga tvam eteṣām punar arthaḥ eva iti viśeṣa jñāpana arthaḥ yogavibhāgaḥ iti
translated: For it is said in the commentary on the definition of means of knowledge: The purpose of the division of yoga is to show the difference that the beginning and so on are the marks of the purpose, but these are the meaning itself.

original: na caivam atra śrutyādiṣaṭkaṃ ca grāhyamiti ṭīkāyāṃ tātparyagrāhakeṣvantarbhāvoktirayukteti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca evam atra śruti ādi ṣaṭkam ca grāhyam iti ṭīkāyām tātparya grāhakeṣu antarbhāva uktiḥ ayuktā iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that it is not proper in the commentary to include the six such as śruti in those that grasp the purpose.

analyzed: yatas trā ityasya samanvaya śabda arthaḥ iti eva arthaḥ na tātparya grahakeṣu iti
translated: Because the meaning of 'atra' is only the meaning of the word 'samanvaya', not in those that grasp the purpose.

analyzed: ākāśaḥ tad liṅgāt
translated: Ākāśa, because of that mark.

analyzed: śabdāt eva pramitaḥ brasū
translated: Only from the word is it known. Brahmasūtra.

original: ityādau śrutiliṅgādibhirāgamārthaniraṇayadarśanena teṣāmapi anvīyate śaktirūpasambandhavattayā jñāyate padajātamebhiritivyutpattyā anvayaśabdārthatvaucityāt
analyzed: ityādau śruti liṅga ādibhiḥ āgama artha niraṇaya darśanena teṣām api anvīyate śakti rūpa sambandhavat tayā jñāyate pada jātam ebhiḥ iti vyutpattyā anvaya śabda artha tva aucityāt
translated: Thus, by showing the determination of the meaning of the scriptures through śruti, liṅga, and so on, those also are known as having the relation in the form of power, and by the etymological derivation that the group of words is known by these, it is proper that the meaning of the word 'anvaya' is that.

analyzed: na ca upakrama upasaṃhāra abhyāsa apūrva tā phala arthavāda upapattayaḥ śruti liṅga vākya prakaraṇa sthāna samākhyāḥ ca tātparya liṅgāni iti jñānapādīya sudhā virodha
translated: And there is no contradiction with the Sudha commentary on the Jnanapada, which states that the indications of purport are the appropriateness of the introductory section, conclusion, repetition, novelty, result, explanatory passage, Vedic text, indicative power, syntactical connection, context, and name.

analyzed: iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that this contradicts the Sudha commentary on the Jnanakhanda, which says that the indications of purport are the occurrence of introductory and concluding passages, repetition, novelty, purpose, explanatory passages, and the agreement of scriptural passages, inferential marks, sentences, contexts, locations, and names.

analyzed: atra śakteḥ api saṃyojanāt
translated: Because even the power is included here.

original: ata eva candrikāyāmupakramādipramāṇakaḥ śaktitātparyalakṣaṇassambandhaḥ samanvaya ityuktam /
analyzed: atas eva candrikāyām upakrama ādi pramāṇakaḥ śakti tātparya lakṣaṇaḥ sambandhaḥ samanvayaḥ iti uktam
translated: For this very reason, in the Chandrika commentary, it is said that the relation characterized by power and purport, which is based on the means of knowledge such as introduction, etc., is called the agreement.

analyzed: atra di padam śruti ādīnām api grāhakam
translated: Here, the word etc. also includes scripture, etc.

analyzed: vyutkrameṇa anvayaḥ
translated: The relation is in the reverse order.

original: anenātra bṛhatsaṃhitāvacanodāharaṇaṃ vakṣyamāṇasya śrutirliṅgamiti vacanasyopalakṣakamiti sūcitam /
analyzed: anena atra bṛhatsaṃhitā vacana udāharaṇam vakṣyamāṇasya śrutiḥ liṅgam iti vacanasya upalakṣakam iti sūcitam
translated: This indicates that the example of the statement from the Brihat-samhita, which will be stated as scripture is the inferential mark for that, is merely illustrative of the statement.

analyzed: uktam ca bṛhatsaṃhitāyām
translated: And it is said in the Brihat-samhita:

analyzed: upakrama upasaṃhārau abhyāsau pūrva tā phalam
translated: Introduction, conclusion, repetition, novelty, result,

analyzed: arthavāda upapattī ca liṅgam tātparya nirṇaye
translated: explanatory passages, and reasonings are the inferential marks for determining the purport.

analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: kāni tānyupapattyādīni kutra ca liṅgānītyata āha uktaṃ ceti /
analyzed: kāni tāni upapatti ādīni kutra ca liṅgāni iti atas āha uktam ca iti
translated: Which are those reasonings, etc., and where are the inferential marks? Therefore it is said and it is stated etc.

analyzed: upapatti ādi iti anuṣajyate
translated: Reasoning, etc. is to be supplied.

analyzed: na kevalam upapatti ādi uktam nirdiṣṭam
translated: Not only what is stated by reasoning, etc. is indicated.

analyzed: kintu tat jñāpyam ca uktam iti ca arthaḥ
translated: But that is to be known, and it is said.

analyzed: asmad uktam upapatti ādi liṅgam bṛhatsaṃhitāyām api uktam iti vā
translated: Or, the reasonings stated by us, such as the possibility, are stated in the Brihat-samhita also.

analyzed: kim uktam iti atas tat paṭhati upakrama iti  prakaraṇa ādiḥ upakramaḥ tad antaḥ upasaṃhāraḥ
translated: What is said? Therefore, he quotes the beginning, etc.🔽The context and so on is the beginning, and the conclusion is at the end.

analyzed: upakrama upasaṃhāraḥ ca tau tathā uktau
translated: The beginning and the conclusion are said to be like that.

analyzed: atra upakrama upasaṃhāra tad aikarūpya abhyāsa apūrva tā phala artha vādāḥ ca iti pramāṇa lakṣaṇa ukteḥ  pratyeka vivakṣayā viśakalitau upakrama upasaṃhārau dvau samudāya vivakṣayā ubhaya avirodha lakṣaṇam
translated: Here, because of the statement in the definition of valid means of knowledge that the beginning, the conclusion, the oneness of those, the repetition, the novelty, the purpose, and the explanatory passages are the reasons,

analyzed: ekārtha tva lakṣaṇam vā tad aikarūpyam api pṛthak tātparya grāhakam anusandheyam
translated: the beginning and the conclusion are separately mentioned with the intention of each being mentioned individually, and the oneness of those, which has the characteristic of the non-contradiction of both or the characteristic of having the same meaning, should also be understood as a means of understanding the intended meaning separately.

analyzed: atas eva dvivacana prayogaḥ
translated: For this very reason, the dual number is used.

analyzed: eka prakāra asakṛt uktiḥ abhyāsaḥ
translated: The repetition is the statement of one kind of thing more than once.

analyzed: prācuryeṇa pramāṇa antara asiddha artha bodhaka tā apūrva tā
translated: The novelty is the ability to convey a meaning not established by other means of knowledge, for the most part.
The purpose is the statement of a meaning that has a result.

analyzed: stutiḥ nindā  eka kartṛkā upākhyāna rūpā parakṛtiḥ
translated: The praise. The censure.🔽The ancient story is in the form of a story with one protagonist.

analyzed: aneka kartṛka upākhyāna rūpaḥ purākalpaḥ ca
translated: The ancient account is in the form of a story with many protagonists.

analyzed: arthavādaḥ
translated: It is a commendatory statement.

analyzed: upapattiḥ yuktiḥ
translated: Reasoning is logic.

analyzed: tātparyanirṇaye
translated: In the ascertainment of the purport.

analyzed: vākya tātparya niścaye liṅgam
translated: In the ascertainment of the purport of a sentence, logic is the mark.

analyzed: sādhanam iti yarthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is a means.

analyzed: yat vā nirṇetavye tātparye sādhye liṅgam
translated: Or, in the ascertainment of the purport to be determined, logic is the mark.

analyzed: hetuḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is a reason.

analyzed: liṅgam ityasya upakrama ādi padaiḥ yathāyogyam pratyekam sambandhaḥ
translated: The word mark is connected with each of the terms beginning etc. as appropriate.

original: smṛterupakramāditve 'pi virodhe uttarottaraprābalyasūcanāya bhāṣye upapattyādīti vyatyasyoktiḥ /
analyzed: smṛteḥ upakrama ādi tve virodhe uttara uttara prābalya sūcanāya bhāṣye upapatti ādi iti vyatyasya uktiḥ
translated: Even though Smṛti is included in the beginning etc., the statement in the Bhāṣya as reasoning etc. is made by reversing the order in order to indicate the increasing strength of the later ones over the earlier ones.

original: sāmānyaviśeṣabhāvena upapatterupakramādibhyaḥ pṛthaguktiḥ /🔽yadvā etaccopakramādi svārthe śabdātmakamapi idametatparam abādhe satyetadupakramatvāt🔽ityādirūpeṇa vākyatātparye liṅgaṃ ca bhavati /
analyzed: sāmānya viśeṣa bhāvena upapatteḥ upakrama ādibhyaḥ pṛthak uktiḥ  yat vā etat ca upakrama ādi svārthe śabda ātmakam api idam etat param abādhe sati etad upakrama tvāt  ityādi rūpeṇa vākya tātparye liṅgam ca bhavati
translated: Reasoning is stated separately from the beginning etc. by way of the general and the specific.🔽Or, this beginning etc. is in the form of words in its own meaning, but this is the mark in the purport of the sentence in the form This is that, because of this beginning, in the absence of contradiction.

original: upapattistu yathāgnyādirūpasvarthe tathā tātparye 'pi ayametattātparyaviṣayaḥ upapannatvāt iti prakāreṇa liṅgarūpeti pṛthaguktiḥ /
analyzed: upapattiḥ tu yathā agni ādi rūpa svarthe tathā tātparye pi ayam etat tātparya viṣayaḥ upapanna tvāt iti prakāreṇa liṅga rūpā iti pṛthak uktiḥ
translated: And reasoning is stated separately as a mark in the form This is the object of that purport, because it is reasonable, in the same way as it has its own meaning in the form of fire etc.

analyzed: upakrama ādi tātparya liṅgaiḥ samyak nirūpyamāṇe tat eva śāstra gamyam
translated: When that is being properly ascertained by the indications of the introductory portion and the like, it is to be understood from the scriptures.

analyzed: sūtram yojayati upakrama ādi iti
translated: He connects the aphorism with the words beginning with the introductory portion.

analyzed: śāstre iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is 'in the scriptures'.

analyzed: sam iti asya arthaḥ samyak iti
translated: The meaning of 'samyaṅ' is 'properly'.

analyzed: sarvasmin iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should also be seen as 'in all'.

analyzed: nirūpyamāṇe
translated: 'Being ascertained'.

analyzed: iti anena saṃ śabda arthasya adhyāhṛta kriyayā anvayaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: By this, the meaning of the word 'sam' is shown to be connected with the understood verb.

analyzed: tuśabdasya arthaḥ eva iti
translated: The meaning of the word 'tu' is 'indeed'.

analyzed: śāstra yoni
translated: 'The source of the scriptures'.

analyzed: iti anuṣakta padasya arthaḥ śāstra agamyam iti
translated: The meaning of the attached word is 'to be understood from the scriptures'.

analyzed: tathā ca yatas tra anvaya pada uktaiḥ śruti liṅga vākya prakaraṇa sthāna samākhyā upakrama ādibhiḥ śakti tātparya liṅgaiḥ sam samyak
translated: And thus, since here by the indications of power and purport expressed by the words 'śruti', 'liṅga', 'vākya', 'prakāraṇa', 'sthāna', 'samākhyā', 'upक्रम' and so on, 'sam' means 'properly',

analyzed: bala abala vimarśa pūrvakam sarvasmin
translated: after considering the strength and weakness, 'in all',

analyzed: śāstre ṛk ādi rūpe nirūpyamāṇe
translated: in the scriptures in the form of Ṛg Veda etc., 'being ascertained',

analyzed: vicāryamāṇe ekārthe śakti tātparya rūpa vyāpaka dharmavat tayā avagamyamāne tat eva
translated: being understood as having the universal property in the form of power and purport, which is the same, 'that alone',

analyzed: viṣṇu ākhyam brahma eva śāstra gamyam
translated: the Brahman called Viṣṇu alone 'is to be understood from the scriptures'.

analyzed: tad pramāṇakam pratīyate
translated: It is understood to be the object of that means of knowledge.

analyzed: na rudra ādi
translated: Not Rudra and others.

analyzed: atas jñānām pratīyamānam api na itareṣām śāstra yoni tvam iti yojanā
translated: Therefore, even though it is understood by the ignorant, it is not the source of other scriptures. This is the construction.

original: liṅgairiti tṛtīyayā nirūpyamāṇe iti saptamīprayoge ca upakramādikaṃ tātparyahetuḥ /
analyzed: liṅgaiḥ iti tṛtīyayā nirūpyamāṇe iti saptamī prayoge ca upakrama ādikam tātparya hetuḥ
translated: In the use of the instrumental case 'by the indications' and the locative case 'in what is being determined', the beginning and other [factors] are the cause of the purport.

original: tātparyaṃ ca śāstrapramāṇakatve heturiti sūcitaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tātparyam ca śāstra pramāṇaka tve hetuḥ iti sūcitam bhavati
translated: And it is indicated that the purport is the cause of being based on scriptural authority.

analyzed: na kevalam upapatti ādikam samanvaya śabda arthaḥ
translated: Not only is the meaning of the word 'samanvaya' (reconciliation) mere logical consistency and so on.

analyzed: kintu tad hetukaḥ śāstra janya pramā gocara tva rūpaḥ śāstra yoni tve hetu bhūtaḥ
translated: But it is the cause of being the source of scripture, which is the nature of being the object of valid knowledge produced by scripture, which is caused by that [logical consistency and so on].
As it is said in the Sudha [commentary], the relation is also the nature of being devoted to that.

analyzed: anena samanvayāt
translated: By this [verse], 'from the reconciliation'.

original: sāvakāśatvaniravakāśatvādinā balābalaniścayapurassaraṃ anyatarabādhayā vākyārthavimarśarūpasamyagvicāritatvalakṣaṇasamyakttvayuktādupakramā🔽diśaktitātprayaliṅgasamudāyātmasamanvayāt sarvaśāstrasya bhagavatyeva samyagvacanavṛttyā
analyzed: sāvakāśa tva niravakāśa tva ādinā bala abala niścaya purassaram anyatara bādhayā  diśakti tātpraya liṅga samudāya ātma samanvayāt sarva śāstrasya bhagavatyā eva samyak vacana vṛttyā
translated: The beginning and other [factors] have the nature of proper consideration, which is the form of examining the meaning of a sentence by way of the contradiction of one [view] by another, preceded by the ascertainment of strength and weakness by way of having an opportunity and not having an opportunity, etc.🔽From the reconciliation, which is the collection of the power, fitness, and indication that have the nature of the beginning and other [factors], all scripture is properly understood to have the relation called power and purport only with regard to the Lord, by the primary meaning of the word.

analyzed: śakti tātparya ākhya sambandha avagamāt tat viṣṇu ākhyam brahma eva jagat kāraṇatayā śāstra yoni
translated: Therefore, that Brahman called Vishnu is the source of the scripture, as the cause of the world.

analyzed: na rudra ādi iti samanvayāt
translated: Not Rudra and others, because of the connection.

analyzed: iti asya āvṛttyā sūtra yojanā darśitā bhavati
translated: By repeating this, the arrangement of the sutra is shown.

analyzed: mām vidhatte bhidhatte mām vikalpyā u pohyāḥ iti aham
translated: He who creates me, who speaks of me, who is to be imagined by me, who is to be excluded by me, is I.

analyzed: iti asyāḥ hṛdayam sākṣāt na anyaḥ mat veda kaścana
translated: This is the heart of this, no one else knows me except this.

analyzed: iti bhāgavate
translated: Thus in the Bhagavata.

original: nanu karmavidhānādirūpaśāstrasya kathaṃ brahmaparatetyāśaṅkāṃ bhagavadvākyena pratiṣedhati māmiti/
analyzed: nanu karma vidhāna ādi rūpa śāstrasya katham brahma para tā iti āśaṅkām bhagavat vākyena pratiṣedhati mām iti
translated: Now, how can the scripture, which is in the form of injunctions of action, etc., be about Brahman? This doubt is refuted by the words of the Lord.

original: yadyapi bhāgavate ityasyā hṛdayaṃ lokeiti pāṭhaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api bhāgavate iti asyāḥ hṛdayam loke iti pāṭhaḥ
translated: Although in the Bhagavata, the reading is the heart of this and in the world,

analyzed: tathā pūrva uttara ardhayoḥ vyutkrameṇa pāṭhaḥ ca dṛśyate
translated: and the reading is seen in the reverse order in the first and second halves,

analyzed: tathā api ācārya ukteḥ anya kalpīyaḥ yam iti adoṣaḥ
translated: nevertheless, because it is stated by the teacher, this is not a fault.

analyzed: ekādaśa skandhe uddhavam prati kṛṣṇa vacanam etat
translated: This is the statement of Krishna to Uddhava in the eleventh canto.

original: atrāsmacchabdena kṛṣṇa ucyate /🔽tathā ca vasante vasante ityādi karmavidhātrī śrutiḥ 'mām' /
analyzed: atra asmad śabdena kṛṣṇaḥ ucyate  tathā ca vasante vasante ityādi karma vidhātrī śrutiḥ mām
translated: Here, Krishna is referred to by the word our.🔽And thus, the Veda, which enjoins action such as in spring, in spring, enjoins action as worship of me,

analyzed: uddiśya eva mad pūjā tvena karma vidhatte
translated: referring to me.

analyzed: indra ādi abhidhātrī mām abhidhatte
translated: It speaks of me, who is referred to by the words Indra and so on.

analyzed: mad guṇān aiśvarya ādīn abhidhatte
translated: It speaks of my qualities such as lordship.

analyzed: aham vikalpyaḥ
translated: I am to be imagined.

analyzed: kalpanam vidhānam tathā ca
translated: Imagination, injunction, and also🔽

original: catvāri vākparimitā padāni tāni vidurbrāhmaṇā ye manīṣiṇaḥ /
analyzed: catvāri vāc parimitā padāni tāni viduḥ brāhmaṇāḥ ye manīṣiṇaḥ
translated: The four feet of speech are limited, those wise Brahmins who know them,

original: guhā trīṇi nihitā neṅgayanti turīyaṃ vāco manuṣyā vadanti // ṛ / /
analyzed: guhā trīṇi nihitā na iṅgayanti turīyam vācaḥ manuṣyāḥ vadanti
translated: The three hidden ones do not move, men speak the fourth of speech.

original: iti śrutyā yā vāgvaktṛttvānnimittādvākbdito hariḥ tasyā yāni sthānāpekṣayā 'parimitāni' /
analyzed: iti śrutyā yā vāc vaktṛ tvāt nimittāt vāc bditaḥ hariḥ tasyāḥ yāni sthāna apekṣayā parimitāni
translated: By this Vedic text, Hari, who is called speech due to being the speaker, has those feet which are not limited in relation to the places.

analyzed: paricchinnāni catvāri padāni
translated: The four feet which are limited,

original: vāsudevādirūpāṇi tāni ye manīṣiṇaḥ brāhmaṇāḥ ta eva viduḥ /
analyzed: vāsudeva ādi rūpāṇi tāni ye manīṣiṇaḥ brāhmaṇāḥ te eva viduḥ
translated: those wise Brahmins who are in the form of Vāsudeva and others, they alone know.

original: tatra vāco hṛdayaguhāyāṃ nihitāni vāsudevāditrīṇi rūpāṇi 'manuṣyāḥ' /
analyzed: tatra vācaḥ hṛdaya guhāyām nihitāni vāsudeva ādi trīṇi rūpāṇi manuṣyāḥ
translated: There, the three forms of Vāsudeva and others, which are hidden in the cave of the heart of speech, are common to men.

analyzed: sādhāraṇāḥ na iṅgayanti na jānanti
translated: They do not move, they do not know.

analyzed: turīyam aniruddha ākhyam tu vadanti
translated: The fourth, which is called Aniruddha, they speak.

analyzed: jānanatī iti evaṃrūpeṇa aham eva catuṣṭva saṅkhyā viśiṣṭa vāsudeva ādi vividha rūpatayā bahutvena vidheyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: In this form, I am the object of injunction in the form of many forms such as Vāsudeva, distinguished by the number four.

analyzed: aham apohyaḥ
translated: I am to be avoided.

analyzed: na surām pibet manu
translated: One should not drink liquor. Manu.

analyzed: ityādi vākyena apriyāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: By this and other statements, the rest is from apriya (unpleasant).

original: tathā ca niṣedhabuddhiviṣayamapriyaṃ hi hareḥ smṛtamiti bhāgavatatātparyokteḥ surāpānādikaṃ madaprītisādhanatvāt niṣidhyate ityapriyadvārā 🔽'na surāṃ pibet' /🔽ityādinā ahameva niṣedhya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca niṣedha buddhi viṣayam apriyam hi hareḥ smṛtam iti bhāgavata tātparyokteḥ surā pāna ādikam mada prīti sādhanatvāt niṣidhyate iti apriya dvārā  na surām pibet  ityādinā aham eva niṣedhyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus, because it is said in the Bhāgavata Tattva that what is disliked by Hari is the object of the cognition of prohibition, drinking liquor etc. is prohibited because it is a means of delighting the self, the meaning is that I myself am to be prohibited by the statement One should not drink liquor, etc.

original: athavā ahamapriyādapohyaḥ mamāprītikarātsurāpānaśabditāt surā harerguṇā me syuḥiti cintanāttapadapekṣya apohyo niṣedhya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: athavā aham apriyāt apohyaḥ mama aprīti karāt surā pāna śabditāt surāḥ hareḥ guṇāḥ me syuḥ iti cintanāt tapat apekṣya apohyaḥ niṣedhyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning is that what is to be avoided, what is to be prohibited, is to be avoided in relation to the word sura, because of the thought May the qualities of Hari be mine, which are called sura and which cause displeasure to me, who am to be avoided as disliked.

original: taduktaṃ bhāgavatatātparye vidhirūpatvena kalpanaṃ vikalpaḥ catvāri vāgityādi /
analyzed: tat uktam bhāgavatatātparye
translated: That is said in the Bhāgavata Tattva: The assumption as injunction, the option, the four beginning with 'speech,' etc.

analyzed: tatra vāc iti anuvādaḥ
translated: There, speech is a restatement.

analyzed: vidhi bhāge hareḥ pūjā eva abhidhāne ca tad guṇāḥ
translated: In the part of injunction, it is the worship of Hari itself, and in the statement, it is its qualities.

analyzed: vikalpe tad bahu tvam ca api apohe tu tat apriyam
translated: In the option, it is its multiplicity, and in the exclusion, it is what is disliked by it.

original: ucyate sarvavedeṣu tacca veda sa eva hi // iti / tathā
analyzed: ucyate sarva vedeṣu tat ca veda saḥ eva hi iti tathā
translated: It is said: That is indeed the Veda, which is recited in all the Vedas. And thus:

original: surā harerguṇāḥ proktāste me syuriti cintanam /
analyzed: surāḥ hareḥ guṇāḥ proktāḥ te me syuḥ iti cintanam
translated: The thought 'May the qualities of Hari, which are called 'sura,' be mine,'

analyzed: surā pānam iti proktam tat na kuryāt kathañcana iti
translated: is said to be 'drinking sura.' One should never do that.

original: tattvapradīpe tu 'dve vā va brahmaṇo rūpe' /
analyzed: tattvapradīpe tu dve vā va brahmaṇaḥ rūpe
translated: But in Tattvadipika, after considering Brahman has two forms,

original: iti vikalpya vividhaṃ kalpayitvā 'tatra yassa ātmā' /
analyzed: iti vikalpya vividham kalpayitvā tatra yaḥ saḥ ātmā
translated: and after various speculations, it is said Among them, that which is the Self,

analyzed: tala vakāra brāhmaṇam
translated: The Talavakara Brahmana

original: iti sadoṣādapohyo nirdeṣatvena vidheyo 'pyahamevetyarthaḥ uktaḥ /🔽atra tattvapradīpapakṣe vikalpyeti lyap /
analyzed: iti sa doṣāt apohyaḥ nirdeṣa tvena vidheyaḥ pi aham eva iti arthaḥ uktaḥ  atra tattva pradīpa pakṣe vikalpya iti lyap
translated: The meaning is that it should be excluded due to having faults and should be enjoined as being faultless, but it is only I.🔽Here, in the view of Tattvadipika, the word vikalpya is a nominal suffix.

original: ṭīkākṛtpakṣe tu vikalpyaśabdassamāsāntargato vyasto veti viśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: ṭīkākṛt pakṣe tu vikalpya śabdaḥ samāsa antargataḥ vyastaḥ vā iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: But in the view of the commentator, the word vikalpya is either within the compound or separate - this is the difference.

analyzed: iyam ca bhagavati
translated: And this is the essence of the method of reconciling statements in the Lord.

analyzed: vākya samanvaya rītiḥ ādyasya iti śabdasya prakāra arthasya hṛdayam iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: The word iti at the beginning has the meaning of type, which is connected with the word hṛdaya (heart).

analyzed: dvitīyasya evaṃbhūtāyāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The second iti has the meaning of in this way.🔽And thus, this scripture, which is understood to have a different meaning than injunctions, prohibitions, etc., in this way,

original: tathā ca hyevaṃbhūtāyā vidhiniṣedhādirūpāyā anyaparatvena pratītāyāścāsyāśśruteriti 'māṃ vidhatte' /
analyzed: tathā ca hi evaṃbhūtāyāḥ vidhi niṣedha ādi rūpāyāḥ anya para tvena pratītāyāḥ ca asyāḥ śruteḥ iti mām vidhatte
translated: vidhatte (enjoins), etc.

analyzed: ityādi ukta prakāreṇa hṛdayam
translated: In the manner stated, hṛdaya (heart).

analyzed: tātparyam aham eva veda
translated: I alone know (understand).

analyzed: jānāmi mad anyaḥ kaścana
translated: Madanyah (other than me),

original: ko 'pi viśeṣataḥ prāyaḥ na veda na jānātītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: kaḥ pi viśeṣataḥ prāyas na veda na jānāti iti arthaḥ
translated: means that no one else, in particular, usually knows (understands).

original: bhāgavata ityanantaraṃ tadeva śāstragamyamityuktatvāt na kathamitiśaṅkāvakāśa iti vākyaśeṣaḥ // //
analyzed: bhāgavataḥ iti anantaram tat eva śāstra gamyam iti ukta tvāt na katham iti śaṅkā avakāśaḥ iti vākyaśeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder of the sentence is: How? is not a possibility, because it has been said that the same is known from the scriptures, after Bhāgavata.

analyzed: iti samanvaya adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on Anvāvṛtti.

analyzed: īkṣati adhikaraṇam
translated: The section on Īkṣaṇa.

analyzed: nanu yatas vācaḥ nivartante
translated: But from which words turn back,

analyzed: a prāpya manasā saha
translated: Not reaching with the mind.

analyzed: taiu
translated: Those.

original: atrādhikaraṇe saṃśabdoktaṃ vācyatvaṃ kārtsnyaṃ cākṣipya samādhīyate /
analyzed: atra adhikaraṇe saṃśabda uktam vācya tvam kārtsnyam ca ākṣipya samādhīyate
translated: Here in this section, the verbality stated by the word saṃ and the completeness are raised and resolved.

analyzed: pūrvapakṣayati nanu iti
translated: He presents the prima facie view with But etc.

analyzed: ityādibhiḥ śrutibhiḥ
translated: By these śrutis etc.

analyzed: iti tṛtīyā pañcamī arthe
translated: In the sense of the third and fifth cases.

analyzed: na ityādi āvartate
translated: No etc. is repeated.

analyzed: tathā ca tat
translated: And thus that etc.

original: pūrvasūtre tacchabdoktaṃ brahmaśabdagocaraṃ śāstroktaṃ kāraṇaṃ na / kutaḥ /
analyzed: pūrva sūtre tad śabda uktam brahma śabda gocaram śāstra uktam kāraṇam na kutas
translated: The cause stated in the scripture, which is referred to by the word tat in the previous sūtra, is not Brahman. Why?

analyzed: yatas na śabda gocaram śāstra mukhya arthaḥ na
translated: Because the main meaning of the scripture is not the object of words.

analyzed: tat api kutas
translated: Why is that also?

analyzed: yatas na śabda gocaram śabda avācyam
translated: Because it is not the object of words, it is not denoted by words.

analyzed: na ca īkṣaṇīya tva virodhaḥ tad asiddheḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with being the object of sight, because that is not established.

original: kutaḥ / yato na tadgocaraṃ jñānaviṣayaḥ na /
analyzed: kutas yatas na tad gocaram jñāna viṣayaḥ na
translated: Why? Because it is not the object of that, it is not the object of knowledge.

analyzed: ajñeyam iti yāvat
translated: It is as much as to say it is not knowable.

analyzed: na ca avācya tva ajñeya tvayoḥ asiddhiḥ
translated: And verbality and unknowability are not unestablished.

analyzed: yatas vācaḥ nivartante ityādi śruteḥ iti yojanā
translated: The construction is: because of the Vedic text beginning with 'From which words turn back'.

original: 'yato vācaḥ' / iti vākye avācyatvasya 'aprāpya manasā saha' /
analyzed: yatas vācaḥ iti vākye avācya tvasya a prāpya manasā saha
translated: In the sentence 'From which words', the inexpressibility is stated, and in 'Not reaching with the mind',

analyzed: iti ajñeya tvasya ca ukta tvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: the unknowability is stated, this is the meaning.

original: trayī na śrutigocarāityatra gocaraśabdasya viśeṣyaliṅgatayā prayogāt 'na tacchabdagocaram' / iti sādhu /🔽sudhāyāṃ tu śabdānāṃ gavāṃ jñānānāṃ caraścaraṇaṃ vṛttiryasmin tacchabdagocaramiti
analyzed: trayī na śruti gocarā iti atra gocara śabdasya viśeṣya liṅga tayā prayogāt na tat śabda gocaram iti sādhu  sudhāyām tu śabdānām gavām jñānānām caraḥ caraṇam vṛttiḥ yasmin tat śabda gocaram iti
translated: In the statement 'The three are not within the range of the Vedas', the word 'gochara' is used with the gender of the qualified word, therefore 'Not within the range of words' is correct.🔽But in the commentary, it is said that the word 'gochara' is a bahuvrihi compound with a different substratum, meaning 'that in which the movement and action of words and cows and cognitions occurs',

analyzed: vyadhikaraṇa bahuvrīhim caraḥ caraṇam asya asti iti matvarthīya a c pratyaya anta tvam ca āśritya  śabda gocaram iti asya sādhu tvam uktam
translated: and that the word 'gochara' is correct as a tatpurusha compound ending in the matup affix, meaning 'that which has movement and action'.

analyzed: yatas iti taittirīya vākyam
translated: The Taittiriya text 'From which' is quoted.

analyzed: yatas vācaḥ vedāḥ vāc indriyāṇi ca manasā
translated: From which words, the Vedas and the organs of speech, along with the mind,

analyzed: manaḥ rūpa indriyeṇa saha tam a prāpya
translated: not reaching him,

analyzed: tad viṣayaka vṛtti jñānam a jānantyaḥ eva nivartante
translated: the cognitions in the form of vṛtti turn back, not knowing him.

original: taṃ brahmaṇa ānandaṃ vidvānna bibheti ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tam brahmaṇaḥ ānandam vidvān na bibheti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: one who knows the bliss of Brahman does not fear.

analyzed: guṇa guṇinoḥ abheda āśrayeṇa etat udāhṛtam
translated: This is cited based on the non-difference of the quality and the possessor of the quality.

analyzed: a śabdam a sparśam a rūpam avyayam tathā arasam nityam a gandhavat ca yat  kaṭha
translated: The Katha Upanishad says: That which is without sound, without touch, without form, without decay, without taste, eternal, and without smell....

analyzed: aśabdam iti kāṭhaka vākyam
translated: The Katha Upanishad says: That which is without sound...

original: atra sarvatra yacchabdo yojyaḥ /🔽na vidyate śabdo guṇaḥ pramāṇaṃ vā yasmiṃstattathoktam /
analyzed: atra sarvatra yad śabdaḥ yojyaḥ  na vidyate śabdaḥ guṇaḥ pramāṇam vā yasmin tat tathā uktam
translated: Here, the word that should be connected everywhere.🔽That which does not have sound as a quality or means of knowledge is said to be so.

analyzed: prākṛta śabda guṇa śūnyam śabda pramāṇa aviṣayaḥ śabda bhinnam ca iti arthaḥ
translated: It means that which is devoid of the natural sound quality, is not an object of sound as a means of knowledge, and is different from sound.

original: 'asparśaṃ' / sparśaguṇaśūnyaṃ tata eva sparśaliṅgāviṣayaḥ tadbhinnaṃ ca /
analyzed: asparśam sparśa guṇa śūnyam tatas eva sparśa liṅga aviṣayaḥ tad bhinnam ca
translated: Without touch means devoid of the quality of touch, therefore not an object of touch as an indicator, and different from it.

original: 'arūpaṃ' / rūparahitam ata eva cakṣuṣapratyakṣāviṣayastadbhinnaṃ ca /🔽'arasaṃ' / rasaguṇaśūnyaṃ rasabhinnaṃ ca /
analyzed: arūpam rūpa rahitam atas eva cakṣuṣā pratyakṣa aviṣayaḥ tad bhinnam ca  arasam rasa guṇa śūnyam rasa bhinnam ca
translated: Without form means devoid of form, therefore not an object of direct perception by the eye, and different from it.🔽Without taste means devoid of the quality of taste, and different from taste.

analyzed: agandham iti asya api upalakṣakam etat
translated: Without smell is also an indication of this.

analyzed: anena pañca mātrā vilakṣaṇa tvam api uktam
translated: By this, it is also said to be different from the five elements alone.

analyzed: avyayam nityam  iti ābhāyām svarūpataḥ dehataḥ ca nāśa śūnya tvam ucyate
translated: Without decay, eternal...🔽In the absence of light, it is said to be devoid of destruction in its own form and in the body.

analyzed: agandhavat iti anena gandhavat pṛthivī lakṣaṇa tvam uktam
translated: Without smell indicates that it is not characterized by earth, which has smell.

analyzed: anena upalakṣaṇayā pañca mahābhūta vilakṣaṇa tvam api uktam bhavati
translated: By this indication, it is also said to be different from the five great elements.

analyzed: asya nicāyya tam mṛtyu mukhāt pramucyate
translated: This is connected with the following: Having thus known, one is freed from the jaws of death.

analyzed: iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: This is the connection.

analyzed: avacanena eva provāca
translated: He spoke by means of the word itself.

analyzed: bāṣkala śrutiḥ
translated: The scripture of Bakshakala

analyzed: avacanena iti anyat śruti vākyam
translated: By means of the word. This is another scriptural passage.

analyzed: avacanena vacana vṛttim vinā eva lakṣaṇayā provāca brahma guruḥ
translated: By means of the word, without the use of denotation, but by indication, the teacher spoke Brahman,

original: śiṣyāyopadideśeti pararītyārthaḥ / 🔽'yadvācānabhyuditaṃ yena vāgabhyudyate / / / yacchrotreṇa na śruṇoti yena śrotramidaṃ śrutam'
analyzed: śiṣyāya upadideśa iti para rītyā arthaḥ  yat vācā an abhyuditam yena vāc abhyudyate yat śrotreṇa na śruṇoti yena śrotram idam śrutam
translated: that is, he taught it to the disciple, according to the opponent's interpretation.🔽By such scriptural passages as That which is not uttered by speech, by which speech is uttered... That which one does not hear by the ear, by which this ear is heard,

analyzed: ityādibhiḥ śrutibhiḥ na tat śabda gocaram
translated: it is not the object of words.

analyzed: yat vācā iti anyat talavakāra vākyam
translated: This is another passage from the Talavakara text, By speech...

analyzed: vācā tad uccāryeṇa śabdena yat an abhyuditam an uktam
translated: By speech, by the word uttered by it, that which is not uttered, not spoken.

analyzed: yena vāc abhyudyate ucyate
translated: By which speech is uttered, is spoken.

analyzed: śrotra indriyeṇa na śṛṇoti puruṣaḥ
translated: A person does not hear by the auditory sense organ.

original: yenedaṃ śrotraṃ śrutaṃ tadeva brahma tvaṃ viddhītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: yena idam śrotram śrutam tat eva brahma tvam viddhi iti arthaḥ
translated: By which this ear is heard, know that alone to be Brahman, is the meaning.

analyzed: atra pūrvapakṣa rītyā vacana vṛtti niṣedhaḥ
translated: Here, according to the prima facie view, there is a prohibition of denotation.

analyzed: ādi padena evaṃjātīyakā śrutiḥ gṛhyate
translated: The word ādi includes scriptural passages of this type.

analyzed: na iti āha
translated: No, he says.

analyzed: īkṣateḥ na a śabdam
translated: Not so, on account of the seeing, it is not without words.

analyzed: saḥ etasmāt jīva ghanāt parātparam puriśayam puruṣam īkṣate
translated: 'He sees that Person, the Supreme Self, beyond this mass of life.' Pr.

analyzed: ātmani eva ātmānam paśyet
translated: 'One should see the Self in the Self.' Br.

analyzed: vijñāya prajñām kurvīta bṛ
translated: 'Having understood, one should perform the act of wisdom.' Br.

analyzed: ityādi vacanaiḥ īkṣaṇīya tvāt vācyam eva
translated: Thus, because it is to be seen, it is expressible, according to statements such as these.

analyzed: siddhāntayat sūtram avatārayati na iti
translated: He introduces the sutra that establishes the conclusion with 'No'.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ āvartate
translated: The word 'iti' is repeated.

original: tathā ca atra sūtrakāraḥ iti pūrvapakṣyuktaṃ śrutitātparyāparijñānaprāptaṃ brahmaṇo 'vācyatvaṃ neti niṣedhatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca atra sūtrakāraḥ iti pūrvapakṣi uktam śruti tātparya aparijñāna prāptam brahmaṇaḥ vācyatvam na iti niṣedhati iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus, here the author of the sutra denies, 'No', the inexpressibility of Brahman, which is obtained by ignorance of the purport of the scriptures, as stated by the opponent.

analyzed: sūtram paṭhati īkṣateḥ iti
translated: He recites the sutra 'Because of the word 'īkṣate'.

analyzed: atra tat iti anuvartate
translated: Here 'tat' is continued.

analyzed: tat ca ādhyāya parisamāpteḥ vidheya samarpakam api iha uddeśya samarpakam
translated: And that, which conveys the object to be enjoined up to the end of the chapter, here conveys the object to be aimed at.

original: na vidyate śabdo vācako yasya tadaśabdam /
analyzed: na vidyate śabdaḥ vācakaḥ yasya tat aśabdam
translated: That which has no word as its expounder is 'ashabda'.

analyzed: tathā ca tat
translated: And thus, 'tat',

analyzed: brahma aśabdam
translated: Brahman, is 'ashabda',

analyzed: śabda avācyam na
translated: not inexpressible by words.

analyzed: kintu vācyam eva
translated: But it is indeed expressible.

analyzed: kutas īkṣateḥ
translated: Why? Because of 'īkṣate'.

analyzed: dhātu nirdeśaḥ yaṃ
translated: This is the indication of the verbal root.

analyzed: tathā eva sudhā ukteḥ
translated: Because it is stated in the commentary in the same way.

analyzed: tathā api śabda mātrasya asādhaka tayā tena tad arthaḥ lakṣyate
translated: Nevertheless, because mere words are not conclusive, their meaning is indicated by that.

analyzed: tena prakṛta anukūla tayā īkṣaṇīya tvam vivakṣyate
translated: Therefore, the state of being fit to be seen is intended to be in accordance with the main topic.

analyzed: tathā ca īkṣateḥ
translated: And thus, 'because of the verb to see'.

original: īkṣaṇīyatvāt jñānaviṣayatvādityarthaḥ ityāśayena sūtraṃ vyācaṣṭe sa iti /
analyzed: īkṣaṇīya tvāt jñāna viṣaya tvāt iti arthaḥ iti āśayena sūtram vyācaṣṭe saḥ iti
translated: The meaning is: because of being fit to be seen, because of being the object of knowledge. With this idea, he explains the sutra as follows: He, etc.

analyzed: idam ca ṣaṣ praśna vākyam
translated: And this is the sentence with six questions.

original: atra yaḥ punaretaṃ trimātreṇaumityanenaivākṣareṇa paraṃ puruṣamabhidhyāyīta sa tejasi
analyzed: atra yaḥ punar etam tri mātreṇa om iti anena eva akṣareṇa param puruṣam abhidhyāyīta sa tejasi
translated: Here, one who meditates on the Supreme Being with this syllable Om consisting of three mātrās, he, being accomplished in the sun, is freed from sin

original: sūrye sampanno yathā pādodarastavacā vinirmucyate evaṃ ha vai sa pāpmanā vinirmuktaḥ
analyzed: sūrye sampannaḥ yathā pāda udara stavacāḥ vinirmucyate evam ha vai sa pāpmanā vinirmuktaḥ
translated: just as a snake is freed from its skin. He is thus freed from sin.

original: sa sāmabhirunnīyate brahmalokamiti pūrvavākye prakṛto yaḥ akārokāramakārākhyāṃśatrayayuktapraṇavoktaprakāreṇa
analyzed: sa sāmabhiḥ unnīyate brahma lokam iti pūrva vākye prakṛtaḥ yaḥ akāra ukāra makāra ākhya aṃśa traya yukta praṇava ukta prakāreṇa
translated: He is led to the world of Brahman by the Sāmans. In the previous sentence, the one who is referred to, by meditating on the Supreme Self in the manner described by the syllable Om consisting of the three parts named a, u, and m,

analyzed: paramātmānam abhidhyāya tam a parokṣīkṛtya ca tejaḥ rūpe sūrye sampanna tvac vinirmukta sarpa vat vidhūta pāpaḥ sāma abhimāni devaiḥ
translated: and making that manifest, and being accomplished in the sun in the form of light, like a snake freed from its skin, freed from sin, by the gods who preside over the Sāmans,

original: satyākhyaṃ brahmalokaṃ prāptaḥ praṇavopāsako jīvaḥ saḥ 'jīvaghanāt' /
analyzed: satya ākhyam brahma lokam prāptaḥ praṇava upāsakaḥ jīvaḥ saḥ jīva ghanāt
translated: the individual soul who meditates on the syllable Om, having attained the world of Brahman called Satya, is 🔽'from the essence of the individual soul'.

analyzed: jīvasārāt tat śreṣṭhāt etasmāt
translated: From the best of that essence,

analyzed: caturmukhāt tad upadeśena parātparam
translated: By the instruction of the Four-faced One, the Supreme.

analyzed: uttamāt uttamam puriśayam
translated: From the best, the best, the Purusha.

analyzed: sakala deha antargatam puruṣam
translated: The Purusha residing within the entire body.

analyzed: pūrṇam vāsudevam paramātmānam īkṣate
translated: He sees the complete Vāsudeva, the Supreme Self.

analyzed: jānāti iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: he knows.

analyzed: yadi api ṣaṭpraśnaṭīkāyām jīva ghanāt viriñcāt tad upāsanayā iti yāvat
translated: Although in the Ṣaṭpraśna Tīkā it is said: from the mass of individual souls, up to Virinchi, up to the worship of that.

analyzed: īkṣate punar abhivṛddha jñānaḥ bhavati
translated: He sees again, with increased knowledge, he becomes.

original: īkṣitvāca taṃ prāpnotiityukterīkṣateraparokṣajñānārthatvaṃ pratīyate /🔽tathāpi mūle jñānasāmānyaviṣayatvarūpekṣaṇīyatvahetorasiddhiparihārāya asyāḥ śruterupanyastatvāt
analyzed: īkṣitvā ca tam prāpnoti iti ukteḥ īkṣateḥ aparokṣa jñāna artha tvam pratīyate  tathā api mūle jñāna sāmānya viṣaya tva rūpa īkṣaṇīya tva hetoḥ asiddhi parihārāya asyāḥ śruteḥ upanyasta tvāt
translated: And having seen, he attains that. Thus, it is understood that seeing is for the purpose of non-direct knowledge.🔽Nevertheless, this scripture is cited in order to avoid the fallacy of unestablishedness of the reason of being an object of seeing, which is in the form of being the object of general knowledge.

analyzed: hiraṇyagarbha upadeśena eti ṭīkā ukteḥ ca iha prakṛta ānuguṇyāt īkṣatiḥ parokṣa jñāna arthaḥ vyākhyeyaḥ
translated: And because it is said in the Tīkā: by the instruction of Hiraṇyagarbha, here it should be explained that seeing is for the purpose of indirect knowledge, in accordance with the context.

analyzed: ātmani iti aparam kāṇva vākyam jijñāsā naye vyākṛtam
translated: The other Kaṇva text beginning with in the Self is explained in the section on inquiry.

analyzed: vijñāya iti anyat vājasaneya vākyam
translated: The other Vājasaneya text beginning with having known.

analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ brahma niṣṭhaḥ dhīraḥ tam
translated: The wise Brāhmaṇa, devoted to Brahman, that,

analyzed: paramātmānam evam śāstreṇa ācāryāt vā vijñāya
translated: the Supreme Self, having known thus by scripture or from a teacher,

analyzed: parokṣataḥ jñātvā prajñām
translated: Having known it indirectly, one should not have ignorance.

analyzed: prakṛṣṭam apokṣa jñānam kurvīta
translated: One should accomplish the excellent indirect knowledge.

analyzed: sampādayet iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is one should bring about.

analyzed: ityādi iti
translated: By these and other statements.

analyzed: evamādi vākyaiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is by statements beginning with this.🔽By the word and so on, this and other statements are included.

analyzed: ādi śabdena ātmā vai are draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: The Self is to be seen.

analyzed: aja ātmā mahān dhruvaḥbṛu
translated: The unborn Self is great and eternal.

analyzed: tam eva dhīraḥ vijñāyabṛu
translated: The wise one, having known Him alone.

analyzed: iti ādikam gṛhyate
translated: This and other statements are included.

analyzed: īkṣaṇīya tvāt  avagama upalakṣakam etat
translated: Because it is to be seen.🔽This indicates the understanding.

analyzed: anyathā ananvayāt
translated: Otherwise, there would be no connection.

analyzed: anena asiddhiḥ parihṛtā
translated: By this, the unestablished is refuted.

analyzed: tad anyathā anupapatteḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is because it is not otherwise possible.

analyzed: vācyam eva iti sautra nañ dvaya labdha artha uktiḥ
translated: The meaning obtained from the two negations in the sutra is stated as only expressible.

analyzed: na tu avācyam na api lakṣyam iti eva śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word eva is that it is not inexpressible nor is it denoted.

analyzed: tat iti anena asya anvayaḥ  aniyama sūcanāya sūtra bhāṣyayoḥ pratijñā hetvoḥ vyutkrameṇa uktiḥ
translated: By this tat (that) is connected.🔽For the purpose of indicating the absence of restriction, the sutra and the commentary state the thesis and reason in reverse order.

analyzed: aupaniṣada tvāt na avacanena īkṣaṇam
translated: Because it is related to the Upanishads, it is not seen by non-statement.

analyzed: nanu astu īkṣaṇīya tvam brahmaṇaḥ
translated: But indeed, Brahman is to be seen.

original: tathāpi na tadanyathānupapattyā tasya vācyatvaṃ vācyaṃ pratyakṣādināpīkṣaṇīyatvopapatterityata āha aupaniṣadatvāditi /
analyzed: tathā api na tad anyathā anupapattyā tasya vācya tvam vācyam pratyakṣa ādinā api īkṣaṇīya tva upapatteḥ iti atas āha aupaniṣada tvāt iti
translated: Even so, its expressibility should not be stated by the non-possibility of that, because it is possible to be seen by perception and so on. Therefore, it is said that because it is related to the Upanishads.

analyzed: tat iti etat vipariṇamya anuvartate
translated: The word 'that' is to be construed with 'not'.

analyzed: tathā ca tasya  brahmaṇaḥ aupaniṣada tvāt
translated: And so 'of that' (Brahman).🔽Because of its being the object of the Upanishads.

analyzed: upaniṣad eka samadhigamya tvāt a vacanena
translated: Because it is to be known only through the Upanishads, 'not by words'.

analyzed: vacana itara pramāṇena īkṣaṇam
translated: By a means of knowledge other than verbal testimony, 'the seeing' (of Brahman).

analyzed: jñānam na iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no knowledge.

original: tathā ca śrutismṛtisāhāyyarahitapratyakṣādyavedyatvaviśiṣṭekṣaṇīyatvānyathānupapattyā brahmaṇo vācyatvaṃ siddhyatyeveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca śruti smṛti sāhāyya rahita pratyakṣa ādya vedya tva viśiṣṭa īkṣaṇīya tva anyathā anupapattyā brahmaṇaḥ vācyatvam siddhi ati eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that thus the fact that Brahman is expressible is established by the non-applicability of being the object of seeing qualified by not being known by perception etc. which are devoid of the help of scripture and smrti.

analyzed: pariśeṣa pramāṇa para tayā vā idam āvṛttya vyākhyeyam
translated: Or this (verse) should be explained by a repetition with the idea of the means of knowledge called 'parishesha'.

original: yojanā tu brahmaṇaśrutiṣūktaṃ īkṣaṇaṃ pramāṇenaiva hi bhavet /
analyzed: yojanā tu īkṣaṇam pramāṇena eva hi bhavet
translated: The construction is: The seeing mentioned in the passages about Brahman can be only by a means of knowledge.

analyzed: prasakta pramāṇeṣu ca na avacanena
translated: And among the means of knowledge that are possible, 'not by words',

original: vacanetarapramāṇenekṣaṇaṃ sambhavati aupaniṣadatvāt vacanenaiva bhavadīkṣaṇaṃ nāvacanena vacanavṛttyanyalakṣaṇādinā sambhavati /
analyzed: vacana itara pramāṇena īkṣaṇam sambhavati aupaniṣada tvāt vacanena eva bhavat īkṣaṇam na avacanena vacana vṛtti anya lakṣaṇa ādinā sambhavati
translated: the seeing is not possible by a means of knowledge other than verbal testimony, because of its being the object of the Upanishads. The seeing of Brahman is possible only by words, not by non-words such as secondary signification.

analyzed: kutas avacanena
translated: Why? 'Not by words'.

analyzed: bhāva pradhānaḥ bahuvrīhiḥ
translated: The bahuvrihi compound is governed by the substantive.

original: avacanatvenāvācyatvena nimittena ataḥ pariśeṣādīkṣaṇaṃ vācyatvameva sādhayatīti /
analyzed: avacana tvena avācya tvena nimittena atas pariśeṣāt īkṣaṇam vācya tvam eva sādhayati iti
translated: Since it is not mentioned, it is inexpressible. Therefore, the remaining option, namely, being expressible, is established by the argument of being an object of knowledge.

original: 'sarve vedā yatpadamāmanti tapāṃsi sarvāṇi ca yadvadanti' / /
analyzed: sarve vedāḥ yat padam āmanti tapāṃsi sarvāṇi ca yat vadanti
translated: All the Vedas proclaim that one pada, and all the austerities speak of that.

analyzed: kaṭha
translated: Katha Upanishad

analyzed: nanu śruti siddham avācya tvam katham īkṣaṇīya tva yukti mātreṇa dūṣyate
translated: But how can the inexpressibility established by the scriptures be refuted merely by the reasoning of being an object of knowledge?

analyzed: prābalyam āgamasya eva
translated: The scriptures are more powerful.

original: iti yuktitaḥ śruteḥ prābalyokterityataḥ sautro heturāgamopalakṣaka iti bhāvena vācyatve śrutismṛtī cāha sarva iti //
analyzed: iti yuktitaḥ śruteḥ prābalya ukteḥ iti atas sautraḥ hetuḥ āgama upalakṣakaḥ iti bhāvena vācya tve śruti smṛtī ca āha sarve iti
translated: Thus, since the reason stated in the sutra indicates the scriptures, the author states the scriptures and smrti in the verse beginning with sarve (all), with the idea that expressibility is indicated by the scriptures.

analyzed: kaṭhānām iyam śrutiḥ
translated: This is the scripture of the Katha Upanishad.

analyzed: sarve vedāḥ yat padam  yasya brahmaṇaḥ svarūpam āmananti
translated: All the Vedas proclaim the pada (word) of that Brahman.

analyzed: mukhya vṛttyā sa tātparyam pratipādayanti
translated: They primarily teach with the intention of conveying the nature of Brahman.

original: sarve vedāḥ sarvāṇi tapāṃsi prasiddhāni 'yat' /🔽brahma prati 'vadanti' /
analyzed: sarve vedāḥ sarvāṇi tapāṃsi prasiddhāni yat  brahma prati vadanti
translated: All the well-known austerities speak of that Brahman.

analyzed: yad uddeśena kartavyāni iti bodhayanti iti arthaḥ
translated: They convey the idea that they are to be performed with reference to Brahman.

analyzed: ālocana rūpāḥ yuktayaḥ iti vā
translated: According to the Tattvapradipa, austerities are the arguments in the form of reflections.

analyzed: sarvaiḥ vedaiḥ aham eva vedyaḥ
translated: Or, all the Vedas proclaim that I alone am to be known.

analyzed: mukhyatas pratipādyaḥ
translated: The primary object of instruction.

analyzed: aham vedānta kṛt
translated: I am the author of the Vedanta.
The author of the Brahma Sutras, the knower of the Vedas.

analyzed: veda artha jñānī ca iti gītā smṛti arthaḥ
translated: The knower of the meaning of the Vedas - this is the meaning of the Gita Smriti.

analyzed: ādi padāt atha kasmāt ucyate
translated: From the word 'ādi' (beginning with), 'Then why is it said?'

analyzed: nāmāni sarvāṇi
translated: 'All names'

analyzed: vacasām vācyam uttamam
translated: 'The meaning of words is supreme'

analyzed: ityādeḥ saṅgrahaḥ
translated: and so on are included.

analyzed: tathā ca śrutau āmananti
translated: And thus in the Shruti, 'They mention'

analyzed: iti sākṣāt vācya tva ukteḥ
translated: because the direct object is stated.

analyzed: smṛtau ca aham eva
translated: And in the Smriti, 'I alone'

original: ityavadhāraṇopapattaye mukhyatayā vedyatvasya vivakṣaṇīyatvāt tasya ca vācyatvaṃ vināyogātsarvaśabdalakṣaṇāyāścāsambhavādvācyatvamevābhyāṃ
analyzed: iti avadhāraṇa upapattaye mukhya tayā vedya tvasya vivakṣaṇīya tvāt tasya ca vācyatvam vinā ayogāt sarva śabda lakṣaṇāyāḥ ca asambhavāt vācyatvam eva ābhyām
translated: in order to establish the primary nature of the knowable, which is to be expressed, and because it is not possible without being the object, and because the figurative meaning of all words is impossible, the object is established by these two

analyzed: siddhi ati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: as being the object itself. This is the meaning.

analyzed: smṛtibhyaḥ ca ityasya vācyam eva iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: And from the Smritis - this is connected with the word 'only' in 'the object'.

analyzed: ādi śabda upātta śruti smṛti apekṣayā bahuvacanam
translated: The plural is used in relation to the Shruti and Smriti included by the word 'ādi'.

analyzed: na kevalam īkṣaṇīya tva hetoḥ iti ca arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: not only because of the reason of being the object of sight.🔽And by the Shrutis and Smritis such as:

analyzed: vedaiḥ ca sarvaiḥ aham eva vedyaḥ vedānta kṛt veda vid eva ca aham
translated: 'I alone am to be known by all the Vedas, I am the author of the Vedanta, and I alone am the knower of the Vedas.'🔽Bh. Gita

analyzed: bhagī  ityādi śruti smṛti smṛtibhyaḥ ca
translated: and so on.

analyzed: avācya tva ādikam tu aprasiddha tvāt
translated: But inexpressibility etc. is not well-known.

analyzed: nanu evam vācya tvasya yukti ādi siddha tve avācya tva ajñeya tva abhidhāyaka udāhṛta śruteḥ yatas vācaḥ
translated: But if inexpressibility is established by reasoning, etc., what is the position of the quoted scripture, which speaks of inexpressibility and unknowability, in the form From which speech turns back (Tai. 2.4)?

analyzed: ityādi rūpāyāḥ kā gatiḥ iti atas āha avācya tva ādikam iti
translated: To this he says Inexpressibility, etc..

analyzed: ajñeya tvam atarkya tvam ca ādi śabda arthaḥ
translated: The word etc. means unknowability and unthinkableness.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ śaṅkā vyāvartakaḥ bhinna krameṇa avadhāraṇe vā
translated: The word tu (but) sets aside the doubt, or it determines in a different sequence.

analyzed: tathā ca aprasiddha tvāt  sākalyena agocara tvāt nimittāt eva brahmaṇi avācya tva ādikam
translated: And thus, because of non-famedness,🔽 due to the absence of being the object of all, inexpressibility, etc. are proper in Brahman alone.

original: avācyatvādivyapadeśo yujyata iti na tadvirodha iti bhāvaḥ /🔽anena siddhānte 'aśabdam' /🔽ityāderaprasiddhatvātsākalyena vācakaśabdaśūnyamityādirthaḥ /
analyzed: avācya tva ādi vyapadeśaḥ yujyate iti na tad virodhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ  anena siddhānte aśabdam  ityādeḥ aprasiddha tvāt sākalyena vācaka śabda śūnyam ityādi arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no contradiction with that.🔽By this, in the Siddhānta, the meaning of inscrutable (Tai. 2.1) etc. is that it is not famed, or that it is devoid of all expressive words, etc.

original: 'avacanena' / ityasya tu sākalyena vacanamantareṇetyartha ityuktaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: avacanena iti asya tu sākalyena vacanam antareṇa iti arthaḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: But the meaning of without speech (Tai. 2.1) is that it is without all speech. This is what is said.

original: na tadīdṛgiti jñeyaṃ na vācyaṃ na ca tarkyate /
analyzed: na tat īdṛś iti jñeyam na vācyam na ca tarkyate
translated: It is not to be known as such, it is not expressible, and it is not to be reasoned about.

original: paśyanto 'pi na paśyanti mero rūpaṃ vipaścitaḥ //
analyzed: paśyantaḥ u pi na paśyanti meroḥ rūpam vipaścitaḥ
translated: Even seeing, the wise do not see the form of Meru.

analyzed: itivat
translated: Like this.

original: nanvaprasiddhinimittako 'vācyatvādivyapadeśaḥ kva dṛṣṭa ityata āha na taditi /
analyzed: nanu aprasiddhi nimittakaḥ vācya tva ādi vyapadeśaḥ kva dṛṣṭaḥ iti atas āha na tat iti
translated: But where is it seen that the designation of being inexpressible, etc., is due to non-famedness? To this he says Not that.

analyzed: yasmāt vipaścito  jñāninaḥ meroḥ rūpam paśyantaḥ pi īdṛś iti
translated: Because the wise ones,🔽even though seeing the form of Meru, do not see it as such,

analyzed: sākalyena na paśyanti na jānanti
translated: in its entirety. They do not know it.

analyzed: anena aprasiddha tva hetuḥ sūcitaḥ
translated: By this, the reason of non-famedness is indicated.

analyzed: tasmāt meroḥ rūpam na jñeyam pratyakṣeṇa
translated: Therefore, the form of Meru is not to be known by perception.

original: na vācyaṃ śabdena /🔽'na tarkyate' /🔽nānumīyate ca liṅgenetyucyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: na vācyam śabdena  na tarkyate  na anumīyate ca liṅgena iti ucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Nor is it to be expressed by words.🔽It is said that it is not to be inferred by inference.

analyzed: itivat iti
translated: The meaning is that it is not to be inferred by a reason.🔽As in the case of Meru.

analyzed: iti vākye iva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: as in a sentence.

analyzed: asya avācya tva ādikam iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ
translated: The connection is with the preceding: this is inexpressible, etc.

original: tathā ca yathā merurūpe aprasiddhinimittakāvācyatvādivyapadeśastathā brahmaṇyapīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca yathā meru rūpe aprasiddhi nimittaka avācya tva ādi vyapadeśaḥ tathā brahmaṇi api iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, just as the designation of being inexpressible, etc., is due to non-famedness in the case of the form of Meru, so it is also in the case of Brahman.

analyzed: aprasiddheḥ avācyam tat vācyam sarva āgama uktitaḥ
translated: It is inexpressible due to non-famedness, but expressible due to being mentioned in all scriptures.

analyzed: atarkyam tarkyam ajñeyam jñeyam evam param smṛtam
translated: It is said to be unthinkable, thinkable, unknowable, and knowable in this way.

analyzed: iti gāruḍe
translated: Thus it is said in the Garuda Purana.

analyzed: na kevalam paśyantaḥ
translated: Not only do they not see,

analyzed: iti ukti anyathā anupapatti mātreṇa eva aprasiddheḥ ajñeya tva atarkya tva avācya tva vyapadeśaḥ iti vyavasthā siddhā
translated: Thus, the conclusion is established that the designation of being unknowable, unthinkable, and inexpressible is due to mere impossibility of being known by verbal testimony, because of non-famedness.

original: api tu smṛtisiddhā ceti bhāvenāha aprasiddheriti /
analyzed: api tu smṛti siddhā ca iti bhāvena āha aprasiddheḥ iti
translated: But the meaning is that it is established by Smṛti. With this in mind, he says because of non-famedness.

analyzed: tat brahma yatas param
translated: That Brahman is supreme.

analyzed: pūrṇam atas sākalyena aprasiddha tvāt avācyam ucyate
translated: It is said to be inexpressible because it is not famous as a whole.

analyzed: sarva sat āgama ukta tvāt tad prasiddha tvāt vācyam ca bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is also expressible because it is famous due to being mentioned in all authentic scriptures.

original: evamaprasiddhiprasiddhibhyāṃ tat atarkyam anumeyaṃ ca ajñeyaṃ jñeyaṃ jñānipratyakṣagamyaṃ ca 'smṛtaṃ' /
analyzed: evam aprasiddhi prasiddhibhyām tat atarkyam anumeyam ca ajñeyam jñeyam jñāni pratyakṣa gamyam ca smṛtam
translated: Thus, by non-famedness and famedness, it is unthinkable, inferable, unknowable, knowable, and directly perceptible to the wise. It is remembered.

analyzed: smṛti kāraiḥ uktam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is mentioned by the authors of Smṛti.

analyzed: gāruḍe iti anantaram uktam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: In the Gāruda should be supplied after this.

analyzed: asya api avācya tva ādikam iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: This also has inexpressibility and so on. It is connected with this.

analyzed: na ca aśabdatvam itara siddham
translated: And non-verbality is not established by others.

analyzed: evam yatas vācaḥ
translated: Thus, from which speech

original: ityādiśrutīnāṃ yuktyādibalādarthāntaropapatterna tadbalācchabdāvācyaṃ brahmeti sūtraṃ vyākhyāyāpavyākhyāṃ pratyākhyāti na ceti /
analyzed: ityādi śrutīnām yukti ādi balāt artha antara upapatteḥ na tad balāt śabda avācyam brahma iti sūtram vyākhyāya apavyākhyām pratyākhyāti na ca iti
translated: and so on. The meaning of the sūtra is that Brahman is not inexpressible by words because of the possibility of another meaning by the power of reasoning and so on. The false explanation is refuted by not and so on.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ sva siddham api na iti samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for including 'not even what is established by itself'.

analyzed: tathā ca jagat kāraṇam aśabdam
translated: And thus, the cause of the world is 'not mentioned'.

analyzed: pradhānam na kutas
translated: The primordial matter is not. Why?

analyzed: aśabdam hi tat
translated: Because that is not mentioned.

analyzed: aśabdam pradhānam kāraṇam na iti vā kutas
translated: Or, the primordial matter is not the cause. Why?

analyzed: īkṣateḥ tat aikṣata
translated: Because of the statement of the seer. 'That desired' (Tai. Up. 2.6.1).

original: iti jagatkāraṇasyekṣaṇakartṛtvaśravaṇātpradhānasya cācetanatvena tadasambhavāditi sāṅkhyamatanirākaraṇaparatayā vyākhyāne prathamapratijñāyāṃ
analyzed: iti jagat kāraṇasya īkṣaṇa kartṛ tva śravaṇāt pradhānasya ca acetana tvena tad asambhavāt iti sāṅkhya mata nirākaraṇa para tayā vyākhyāne prathama pratijñāyām
translated: Because of the statement that the cause of the world is the agent of seeing, and because that is impossible for the primordial matter which is insentient. Thus, when it is explained as being for the purpose of refuting the Sāṃkhya view, in the first proposition,

analyzed: hetūkṛtam aśabdatvam
translated: 'not being mentioned' is taken as the reason.

analyzed: aśrauta tvam
translated: Not being heard.

analyzed: itara siddham
translated: Established for the other.

analyzed: sva itara sāṅkhya siddham na
translated: Not established for the Sāṃkhya other than one's own.

analyzed: na kevalam etāvat
translated: Not only that much.

analyzed: kintu sva siddham api na
translated: But also not established by itself.

analyzed: sāṅkhyena vaidika tva abhyupagateḥ
translated: Because the Sāṃkhya accepts it as Vedic.

analyzed: sūtrakāreṇa ajām ekām tai ā
translated: By the author of the aphorisms, 'The unborn one' (Tai. Up. 2.6.1).

analyzed: ityādi śruti ukta tva aṅgīkārāt
translated: Because it is accepted as being stated in the scriptures.

original: yadvā tattvapradīparītyā māyinā sāṅkhyaṃ prati hetutvenopanyastamaśabdatvaṃ māyītarasya sāṅkhyasya na siddhaṃ nāpi sāṅkhyetaramāyisiddhamuktahetubhyāmeva
analyzed: yat vā tattva pradīpa rītyā māyinā sāṅkhyam prati hetutvena upanyastam aśabdatvam māyi itarasya sāṅkhyasya na siddham nā api sāṅkhya itara māyi siddha mukta hetubhyām eva
translated: Or, according to the Tattva-prakāśa, the reason of not being mentioned which is stated by the Māyāvādins against the Sāṃkhyas is not established for the Sāṃkhya other than the Māyāvādins, nor is it established for the Māyāvādins other than the Sāṃkhyas, by the stated reasons themselves.

analyzed: tathā ca asiddhiḥ iti na tad vyākhyānam yuktam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And so there is non-establishment. Thus the explanation of that is not proper. This is the meaning.

analyzed: evam aśabda tvam śrauta tvam brahmaṇaḥ sāṅkhya itara māyi siddham na
translated: Thus, the fact that Brahman is not denoted by words, and is not the meaning of the Vedas, is not established by the Sankhyas and other non-Vedantins.

analyzed: tad mate avācya tvāt
translated: Because in their view it is inexpressible.

analyzed: cakārāt dīkṣitṛ tvam api siddham na
translated: The fact that it is not the object of the eye, etc. is also not established.

original: tasyekṣatisvarūpatvādityapi vyākhyeyam /🔽tathā ca hetudvayamapi svapakṣapratikūlamiti na paravyākhyā yukteti bhāvaḥ tattvapradīpe tu 'naca' /
analyzed: tasya īkṣati svarūpa tvāt iti api vyākhyeyam  tathā ca hetu dvayam api sva pakṣa pratikūlam iti na para vyākhyā yuktā iti bhāvaḥ tattvapradīpe tu na ca
translated: This should also be explained as follows: because that is of the nature of seeing.

analyzed: ityādi bhāṣyam itara siddham
translated: And thus both reasons are contrary to one's own position. Therefore the other's explanation is not proper. This is the meaning. But in the Tattvadipika, the commentary beginning with na ca (is not) explains that what is established by others,

original: māyisiddhamaśabdatvaṃ na śrutyarthaḥ uktanyāyena brahmaṇo vācyatvāt /
analyzed: māyi siddham aśabdatvam na śruti arthaḥ ukta nyāyena brahmaṇaḥ vācyatvāt
translated: the fact that Brahman is not denoted by words, is not the meaning of the Vedas, because Brahman is expressible, as stated by the above reasoning.

analyzed: evam aśabda tvam
translated: Similarly, the fact that Brahman is not denoted by words,

original: avācyatvaṃ brahmaṇa itarasya māyino 'pi na siddham /
analyzed: avācya tvam brahmaṇaḥ itarasya na siddham
translated: the fact that Brahman is inexpressible is not established even by the Maya school.

original: brahmaṇi vyavahārābhāvaprasaṅgāt iti dvedhā vyākhyāyaparakṛtavyākhyāpratyākhyānāya paroktahetoṣṭīkārītyāsiddhyuktiparatayāpi vyākhyātam //
analyzed: brahmaṇi vyavahāra abhāva prasaṅgāt iti dvedhā vyākhyāya para kṛta vyākhyā pratyākhyānāya para ukta hetoḥ ṭīkā rītyā asiddhi ukti para tayā api vyākhyātam
translated: Because it would lead to the absurdity of the absence of usage regarding Brahman. Thus it is explained in two ways. In order to reject the explanation given by others, it is also explained as having the purpose of stating the non-establishment of the reason stated by the opponent, by the statement asiddhi (non-establishment).

analyzed: gauṇaḥ ced na ātma śabdāt  /
translated: If it be said that the word atman (Self) is figurative, no; because of the word atman.

original: īkṣaṇīyatvasya hetorvyadhikaraṇāsiddhimākṣipya samādhātuṃ sūtram 'oṃ gauṇaścennātmaśabdāt' / iti /
analyzed: īkṣaṇīya tvasya hetoḥ vyadhikaraṇa asiddhim ākṣipya samādhātum sūtram om gauṇaḥ ced na ātma śabdāt iti
translated: To raise the question of the reason being unestablished with a different subject and to resolve it, the aphorism is: 'If it is secondary, not so, because of the word Self.'

analyzed: asya arthaḥ yatas ātmani eva ātmānam paśyet
translated: The meaning of this is: 'From which one should see the Self in the Self.'

analyzed: ityādi śruti uktaḥ ātmā gauṇaḥ
translated: The Self spoken of in this and other scriptures is secondary.

original: sattvādiguṇabaddho jīva evātastadanyathānupapattyā vācyo 'pi sa eva syānna nirguṇaḥ paramātmeti cet na / kutaḥ /
analyzed: sattva ādi guṇa baddhaḥ jīvaḥ eva atas tad anyathā anupapattyā saḥ eva syāt na nirguṇaḥ paramātmā iti ced na kutas
translated: The individual soul, bound by qualities like sattva, is to be spoken of by that [scripture], so it should be that, not the qualityless Supreme Self. If this is said, it is not so. Why?

analyzed: ātmānam paśyet
translated: 'One should see the Self.'

analyzed: iti īkṣaṇīye tasmin ātma śabda śravaṇāt iti
translated: Because the word 'Self' is heard in that which is to be seen, [the Self is not secondary].

analyzed: ātma pata sāmānādhikaraṇyāya
translated: The masculine gender is used for the sake of co-reference with 'Self' and 'Lord.'

original: na ca gauṇa ātmā dṛśyo vācyaśca na nirguṇa iti yuktam /
analyzed: na ca gauṇaḥ ātmā dṛśyaḥ vācyaḥ ca na nirguṇaḥ iti yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to say that the secondary Self is visible and speakable, not the qualityless one.

analyzed: ātma śabdāt
translated: Because of the word 'Self.'

analyzed: sūtram vyācaṣṭe na ca iti
translated: He explains the aphorism: 'Not so,' etc.

analyzed: atra yatas dṛśyaḥ
translated: Here, 'because it is invisible,'

analyzed: īkṣati śrutau dṛśya tayā uktaḥ ātmā
translated: in the Vedic text about seeing, the 'Self' is spoken of as visible.

original: jīvākhyo gauṇa eva atastadanyathānupapattyā vācyo 'pi sa eva syāt 'na nirguṇaḥ' /
analyzed: jīva ākhyaḥ gauṇaḥ eva atas tad anyathā anupapattyā saḥ eva syāt na nirguṇaḥ
translated: Since the secondary one called the individual soul is that, it should be spoken of by that [scripture], so it should be that, 'not the qualityless one.'

analyzed: guṇa atītaḥ viṣṇuḥ dṛśyaḥ
translated: Vishnu, who is beyond qualities, is 'visible.'

analyzed: īkṣati śrutti uktaḥ
translated: He is spoken of as seen in the Vedic text about seeing.

analyzed: gauṇa grahaṇe bādhakasya itara jñāpakasya ca abhāvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no contradiction in accepting the secondary sense, and no other reason for rejecting it.

original: ato na sa vācyaḥ iti codyaṃ na yuktam /
analyzed: atas na sa vācyaḥ iti codyam na yuktam
translated: Therefore, the objection that it should not be spoken of is not proper.

analyzed: kutas ātma śabdāt  ātmani eva
translated: Why? Because of the word 'ātman'.

original: iti vākye īkṣaṇīye tasmin ātmaśabdaśravaṇāddṛśyo nirguṇa eva /
analyzed: iti vākye īkṣaṇīye tasmin ātma śabda śravaṇāt dṛśyaḥ nirguṇaḥ eva
translated: In the sentence 'in the ātman alone', because the word 'ātman' is heard in that which is to be seen, the visible one is only without qualities.

original: ata evekṣatyā liṅgena vācyo 'pi sa eva bhavediti yojanā /
analyzed: atas eva īkṣatyā liṅgena saḥ eva bhavet iti yojanā
translated: For this very reason, it is connected that even if it is to be spoken of by the indicative 'īkṣati', it should be that very one.

original: yadyapi sudhāyāṃ gauṇapadaṃ māyāśabalitaiśvaryādidharmayuktasaguṇabrahmaparatayā vyākhyātaṃ tathāpi pūrvapakṣiṇo māyāśabalitaṃ vā guṇabaddhā
analyzed: yadi api sudhāyām gauṇa padam māyā śabalita aiśvarya ādi dharma yukta saguṇa brahma para tayā vyākhyātam tathā api pūrvapakṣiṇaḥ māyā śabalitam vā guṇa baddhā
translated: Although in the Sudhā, the word 'secondary' is explained as referring to the qualified Brahman endowed with the attributes of power etc. tainted by māyā, still, for the opponent, either the one tainted by māyā, or the bound individual souls,

analyzed: jīvāḥ vā dṛśyāḥ vācyāḥ ca
translated: or the visible ones are to be spoken of.

analyzed: na sarvathā nirguṇam brahma iti āśayāt na virodhaḥ
translated: The Brahman without qualities in every way is not so, is the idea. Hence there is no contradiction.
