translated: That is so.🔽Now, in this chapter, out of the five topics that must necessarily be stated, beginning with the section on the one consisting of bliss,🔽the words that denote the qualities such as bliss, which are indicated by the word one consisting of bliss, which is well-known elsewhere than in the Vedas,

analyzed: asmin adhikaraṇe lokataḥ nyatra prasiddha ānanda maya śabda upalakṣita guṇi vāci śabdānām ānanda ādi guṇa vāci śabdānām
translated: and the words that denote the qualities such as bliss,

analyzed: ca brahmaṇi samanvaya karaṇāt
translated: And because it establishes the connection of Brahman.

analyzed: asyāḥ tu śāstre dhyāye pāde ca antarbhāva rūpā saṅgatiḥ
translated: But this has the connection of being included in this scripture, chapter, and section.

original: tathāpi ānandamayasya viṣṇutvasamarthane kā pūrvasaṅgatirityato 'vyavahitapūrvādhikaraṇenaiva saṅgatirvaktavyeti niyamābhāvāt
analyzed: tathā api ānanda mayasya viṣṇu tva samarthane kā pūrva saṅgatiḥ iti atas vyavahita pūrva adhikaraṇena eva saṅgatiḥ vaktavyā iti niyama abhāvāt
translated: Even so, when establishing that the Bliss-Body is Vishnu, what is the previous connection? Therefore, since there is no rule that the connection must be stated only with the immediately preceding section,

original: vyavahitapūrveṇa jijñāsādhikaraṇena tadviṣayeṇa ca asyānantaryalakṣaṇalakṣitāmākṣepikīṃ saṅgatiṃ tāvaddarśayati brahmeti //
analyzed: vyavahita pūrveṇa jijñāsā adhikaraṇena tad viṣayeṇa ca asya ānantarya lakṣaṇa lakṣitām ākṣepikīm saṅgatim tāvat darśayati brahma iti
translated: he shows the connection by implication characterized by immediate sequence with the section on inquiry and its subject matter, which is previously interrupted, by the word Brahman.

analyzed: uktam jijñāsā adhikaraṇe iti śeṣaḥ  tat ca iti
translated: The remainder is it was said in the section on inquiry.

analyzed: yat jijñāsya tayā pratijñātam brahma tat eva iti arthaḥ
translated: And that means the Brahman that was promised as the object of inquiry is that very thing.

analyzed: yat vā prakṛta anusandhāna arthaḥ caśabdaḥ
translated: Or, the word and is for the purpose of connecting with the subject matter.

analyzed: iti iti anantaram śrutau iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Thus is to be supplied after in the Vedic text.

analyzed: ānanda maya avayava rūpam iti  ānanda maya ākhyasya kasyacid puccha ākhya avayava bhūtam pratīyate iti arthaḥ
translated: In the form of a part of the Bliss-Body.🔽It is understood to be a part called the tail of something called the Bliss-Body.

original: nanu brahmaṇo 'vayavatvoktāvapi kimarthamānandamayasya viṣṇutvasamarthanamityata āha na hīti/
analyzed: nanu brahmaṇaḥ vayava tva uktau api kimartham ānanda mayasya viṣṇu tva samarthanam iti atas āha na hi iti
translated: But even if the partness of Brahman is stated, for what purpose is the establishment of the Bliss-Body as Vishnu? Therefore he says not indeed.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The word 'hi' (means) reason.

analyzed: atas iti āvartate  tat ca ityādi iti atas āha
translated: 'Therefore' is repeated.

analyzed: ityantam saṅgati prayojana ubhaya para tayā vyākhyeyam
translated: 'And that' etc. up to 'therefore it is said' should be explained as referring to both connection and purpose.

analyzed: na hi iti etat tad upapādakam
translated: 'Indeed' is the explanation of that.

analyzed: yojanā tu yatas brahma puccham pratiṣṭhā
translated: The construction is this: Since 'Brahman is the tail, the support',

original: iti śrutau jijñāsyatayoktaṃ brahma ānandamayākhyasya kasyacidavayavarūpaṃ 'pratīyate' /
analyzed: iti śrutau jijñāsya tayā uktam brahma ānanda maya ākhyasya kasyacid avayava rūpam pratīyate
translated: in the Vedic text, Brahman, which is stated as the object of inquiry, is understood to be a part of something called the 'Bliss-body'.

analyzed: ucyate yatas ca anya aṅgatayā jijñāsya tve pi avayavinam
translated: And since it is said that even when it is the object of inquiry as a subordinate part,🔽without the 'whole', the Bliss-body,

original: ānandamayaṃ vinā 'avayavamātrasya' /🔽avayavasyaiva kevalasya brahmaṇo na pṛthak 'jñeyatā' /
analyzed: ānanda mayam vinā avayava mātrasya  avayavasya eva kevalasya brahmaṇaḥ na pṛthak jñeya tā
translated: the 'mere part',🔽Brahman alone, the part, cannot be known separately.

analyzed: jijñāsya tā sambhavati
translated: The state of being the object of inquiry is not possible.

analyzed: a mukhya tvāt
translated: Because it is not primary.

analyzed: nā api jijñāsāyāḥ eva tyāgaḥ yujyate
translated: Nor is it proper to abandon the inquiry itself.

analyzed: tat vijijñāsasvatai u
translated: 'You should seek to know that.'

analyzed: iti śruti vihita tvāt iti evam śaṅkā prāptā
translated: Because it is enjoined by the Vedic text. Thus the doubt arises.

original: ataḥ śaṅkārūpasaṅgatisadbhāvāt atrānandamayasya viṣṇvanyatvapakṣe brahmajijñāsākṣepāt viṣṇutvapakṣe ca tatsamādhānāt evaṃ ca pūrvapakṣasiddhāntayoḥ
analyzed: atas śaṅkā rūpa saṅgati sadbhāvāt atra ānanda mayasya viṣṇu anyatva pakṣe brahma jijñāsā ākṣepāt viṣṇu tva pakṣe ca tad samādhānāt evam ca pūrvapakṣa siddhāntayoḥ
translated: Therefore, due to the presence of a connection in the form of doubt, here, in the case of the non-Viṣṇu nature of the one consisting of bliss, there is a raising of the question of the inquiry into Brahman, and in the case of the Viṣṇu nature, there is its resolution. And thus, because of the presence of the result in the prima facie view and the established conclusion,

analyzed: phala sadbhāvāt ca atas
translated: therefore,

analyzed: brahma jijñāsā siddhi artham ānanda mayaḥ bhyāsāt  iti ānanda mayasya viṣṇu tvam āha
translated: for the sake of accomplishing the inquiry into Brahman, the one consisting of bliss is Viṣṇu by repetition.

analyzed: samarthayati sūtrakāraḥ iti
translated: Thus, the author of the aphorisms supports the view that the one consisting of bliss is Viṣṇu.

analyzed: tasmāt vai etasmāt vijñāna mayāt
translated: Therefore, different from this one consisting of knowledge,

analyzed: anyaḥ ntaraḥ ātmā ānanda mayaḥ
translated: the inner self consisting of bliss.

original: tenaiṣa pūrṇaḥ /🔽sa vā eṣa puruṣavidha eva /🔽tasya puruṣavidhatām /
analyzed: tena eṣa pūrṇaḥ  sa vai eṣa puruṣavidhaḥ eva  tasya puruṣavidha tām
translated: He is filled with that.🔽He is indeed of the form of a person.🔽His form is that of a person.

analyzed: anvayam puruṣavidhaḥ
translated: Following the form of a person.

analyzed: tasya priyam eva śiraḥ  modaḥ dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: His head is indeed joy.🔽The right wing is delight.

analyzed: pramodaḥ uttaraḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: The left wing is supreme delight.

analyzed: ānandaḥ ātmā
translated: The self is bliss.

analyzed: brahma puccham pratiṣṭhātau
translated: The tail and support is Brahman.

analyzed: iti taittirīya vākyasya ayam arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the Taittirīya passage.

analyzed: tasmāt ātma pada uditāt etasmāt
translated: From that, indicated by the word self, from that,

analyzed: jīva śarīra gatāt vijñāna pūrṇa tvāt vijñāna maya śabda vācyāt viṣṇoḥ ānanda mayaḥ  ānanda pūrṇa tvāt ānanda maya śabda vācyaḥ ātmā
translated: The Self, who is different from Viṣṇu, who is called the 'knower of the field', who is full of consciousness, who is denoted by the word 'made of consciousness', is called 'full of bliss' by the word 'other'.

analyzed: nārāyaṇaḥ antaro
translated: The Self, who is full of bliss, who is denoted by the word 'made of bliss', is Nārāyaṇa, who is 'within'.

analyzed: vijñāna mayasya antar sthitaḥ tena
translated: He, who is situated within the one made of consciousness, by 'Him',

analyzed: ānanda mayena eṣaḥ
translated: by the one made of bliss, 'this'

analyzed: vijñāna maya śabda vācyaḥ vāsudevaḥ pūrṇaḥ
translated: Vasudeva, who is denoted by the word 'made of consciousness', is 'full',

analyzed: niśchidra tvena pūritaḥ
translated: filled without any gaps.

analyzed: vaiśabdaḥ prasiddhau
translated: The word 'vai' (in fact) indicates well-known.

analyzed: saḥ eṣaḥ ānanda mayaḥ puruṣavidhaḥ eva
translated: 'He', the one made of bliss, 'is of the form of a person',

analyzed: puruṣa ākāraḥ eva
translated: has the form of a person.

analyzed: tasya ānanda mayasya śarīra sthānīyasya puruṣa ākāra tām anu
translated: 'Following' the form of a person of the one made of bliss, which is like a body,

analyzed: anusṛtya ayam
translated: 'this'

analyzed: vijñāna mayaḥ śarīra sthānīyaḥ puruṣavidhaḥ
translated: one made of consciousness, which is like a body, 'is of the form of a person'.

analyzed: tasmāt prādurbhūtaḥ  uttaraiḥ pūritāḥ pūrve niśchidra tvena sarvaśas
translated: He has emerged from that.🔽The later ones fill the earlier ones completely without any gaps.

analyzed: sarve pi puruṣa ākārāḥ uttarāt pūrva sambhavaḥ
translated: All of them have the form of a person. The later one arises from the earlier one.

analyzed: iti taittirīyabhāṣya ukteḥ
translated: As stated in the Taittirīya Bhāṣya.

analyzed: tasya ānanda mayasya viṣṇoḥ avayava bhūtam parā iyam priya nāmakam
translated: The head of that Viṣṇu, who is made of bliss, is the bliss called Priya, which is a part of Him.

analyzed: iti bhāṣya ukteḥ
translated: This is stated in the Bhāṣya.

analyzed: paraiḥ uttamaiḥ devaiḥ prāpya tvāt priya śabda vācyam yat sukham tat tasya śiraḥ
translated: The bliss called Priya, which is to be attained by the supreme gods, is His head.

original: tadevānandamayākhyasya jīvaśarīrasya parairanyairupakartṛbhiḥ prāpyatvāt priyanāmakamupakārajanyavaiṣayikasukhākhyaṃ yacchiraḥ tatsthaṃ ca🔽evamānandamayākhyasya viṣṇoḥ ye dakṣiṇottarabāhumadhyadehāḥ modapramodakāritvānandatvanimittairmoda
analyzed: tat eva ānanda maya ākhyasya jīva śarīrasya paraiḥ anyaiḥ upakartṛbhiḥ prāpya tvāt priya nāmakam upakāra janya vaiṣayika sukha ākhyam yat śiraḥ tad stham ca  evam ānanda maya ākhyasya viṣṇoḥ ye dakṣiṇa uttara bāhu madhya dehāḥ moda pramoda kāri tva ānanda tva nimittaiḥ moda
translated: That very bliss, which is to be attained by others, by those who serve Him, is the head called Priya, which is the bliss arising from service. It is located in the body of the individual soul called made of bliss.

analyzed: pramoda ānanda nāmānaḥ te ānanda maya ākhya jīva śarīrasya dakṣiṇa uttara pakṣa ātma nāmānaḥ dakṣiṇa savya bāhu madhya dehāḥ
translated: In the same way, the right and left arms and the middle part of the body of Viṣṇu, who is called made of bliss, are named Moda, Pramoḍa, and Ānanda, because He causes joy, great joy, and bliss. They are the right and left wings and the middle part of the body of the individual soul called made of bliss.

analyzed: modaḥ bhoga nimittakaḥ pramodaḥ
translated: Moda is the bliss caused by enjoyment. Pramoḍa is the special form of that arising from excellent objects.

analyzed: tad viśeṣa utthaḥ iti aitareya bhāṣya ukteḥ  mud nāma viṣaya uttham yat prakṛṣṭa viṣayāt pramud
translated: This is stated in the Aitareya Bhāṣya.🔽Mun is the bliss arising from objects. Pramu is the excellent bliss arising from excellent objects.

analyzed: sukham svarūpa bhūtam yat ānandaḥ iti kathyate
translated: The bliss that is of the nature of Ānanda is said to be Ānanda.

analyzed: iti bṛhadbhāṣya ukteḥ ca
translated: This is stated in the Brhad Bhāṣya.

analyzed: apakṛṣṭa viṣaya udbhūta tva prakṛṣṭa viṣaya uttha tva jīva svarūpa ānanda tva nimittaiḥ moda pramoda ānanda nāmānaḥ teṣu sthitāḥ ca
translated: They are called joy, supreme joy, and bliss, respectively, due to the causes of being born from a lesser object, being born from a superior object, and being the bliss of the individual soul. They abide in those.

analyzed: evam ānanda maya ākhyasya viṣṇoḥ puccham
translated: Thus, the tail of Viṣṇu, called the blissful one,🔽is the part called the foot, which is denoted by the word support, by the derivation the world goes by these two. It is denoted by the word Brahman

original: pratiṣṭhati gacchati loka ābhyāmiti vyutpattyā pratiṣṭhāpadokto yaḥ pādākhyo 'vayavaḥ tadbrahma 'brahmasṛṣṭyā tu bṛṃhayet' /
analyzed: pratiṣṭhati gacchati lokaḥ ābhyām iti vyutpattyā pratiṣṭhā pada uktaḥ yaḥ pāda ākhyaḥ vayavaḥ tat brahma brahma sṛṣṭyā tu bṛṃhayet
translated: by the method stated in the Taittirīya Bhāṣya: It would nourish by the creation of Brahman,

analyzed: iti taittirīya bhāṣya ukta rītyā sṛṣṭi ādi kriyayā viśva guṇa vṛddhi kara tvāt brahma śabda vācyaḥ
translated: because it causes the increase of the qualities of the universe by the action of creation, etc.

original: sa evānandamayākhyajīvaśarīrasya yat pucchaṃ yaḥ pādākhyo 'vayavaḥ tatsthite brahmākhye
analyzed: saḥ eva ānanda maya ākhya jīva śarīrasya yat puccham yaḥ pāda ākhyaḥ vayavaḥ tad sthite brahma ākhye
translated: That which is the tail, the part called the foot, of the body of the individual soul called the blissful one,

analyzed: pradhāna vāyau sthitaḥ  anena kośa avayavasya brahma śabda vācya tvam brahma śabda vācya pradhāna vāyu adhiṣṭhāna tva nimittam
translated: is located in the principal wind called Brahman, which is located there.🔽By this, it is said that the part of the sheath is denoted by the word Brahman because it is the substratum of the principal wind denoted by the word Brahman.

analyzed: pradhāna vāyoḥ brahma śabda vācya tvam tu para brahma adhiṣṭhāna tvāt iti uktam bhavati
translated: But the denotation of the principal wind by the word Brahman is because it is the substratum of the supreme Brahman.

analyzed: anena ānanda maya ādi śabda vācyasya viṣṇoḥ avayava
translated: By this, it is said that the part of Viṣṇu, denoted by the words blissful one, etc.,

original: bhūtāḥ ye priyādayaḥ te viṣṇvabhinnāḥ ye cānandamayādijīvakośāvayavāḥ priyādayaste pratiśarīraṃ bhinnā iti dvividhāḥ priyādaya ityuktaṃ bhavati
analyzed: bhūtāḥ ye priya ādayaḥ te viṣṇu abhinnāḥ ye ca ānanda maya ādi jīva kośa avayavāḥ priya ādayaḥ te pratiśarīram bhinnāḥ iti dvividhāḥ priya ādayaḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: The priyās, etc., which are beings, are non-different from Viṣṇu, and those priyās, etc., which are parts of the sheaths of the jīva, such as the one consisting of bliss, etc., are different in each body. Thus it is said that priyās, etc., are of two kinds.

original: yathoktaṃ candrikāyām ye jīvābhimanyamānānandamayādikośāvayavāḥ priyādayaste pratiśarīraṃ bhinnāḥ /
analyzed: yathā uktam candrikāyām ye jīva abhimanyamāna ānanda maya ādi kośa avayavāḥ priya ādayaḥ te pratiśarīram bhinnāḥ
translated: And as it is said in the Candraikā: Those priyās, etc., which are parts of the sheaths such as the one consisting of bliss, etc., which are considered to be the jīva, are different in each body.

analyzed: na te ānanda maya ādi ākhyasya viṣṇoḥ avayavāḥ
translated: They are not parts of Viṣṇu, who is called the one consisting of bliss, etc.

original: ye ca bhagavato 'vayavāḥ priyādayo na te pratiśarīraṃ bhinnā kintvabhinnā iti jīvasvarūpasyānandasya
analyzed: ye ca bhagavataḥ vayavāḥ priya ādayaḥ na te pratiśarīram bhinnā kintu abhinnāḥ iti jīva svarūpasya ānandasya
translated: And those priyās, etc., which are parts of the Lord, are not different in each body, but are undifferentiated. Thus the bliss, which is the nature of the jīva,

analyzed: hṛdaya ākhya madhya gata tvāt kośa madhya deha tvam sva rūpa dehasya jaḍa avayava tvam ca amukhyam yujyate
translated: because it is located in the heart, it is proper that the body which is its own form has the secondary meaning of being located in the middle of the sheath and being a part of the insentient.

analyzed: yadi api bhāṣye śiraḥ nārāyaṇaḥ
translated: Although in the Bhāṣya (it is said): The head is Nārāyaṇa.

original: ityudāhariṣyamāṇavacanaparyālocanayādmanandamayākhyo nārāyaṇaḥ punarnārāyaṇādirūpeṇa pañcadhā bhinnaḥ śiraḥprabhṛtyavayavātmanā tiṣṭhatīti
analyzed: iti udāhariṣyamāṇa vacana paryālocanayā adma nanda maya ākhyaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ punar nārāyaṇa ādi rūpeṇa pañcadhā bhinnaḥ śiraḥ prabhṛti avayava ātmanā tiṣṭhati iti
translated: By considering the passage to be quoted, the one called the one consisting of bliss is Nārāyaṇa, who is again divided five times in the form of Nārāyaṇa, etc., and exists as the parts beginning with the head.

analyzed: taittirīyabhāṣye tu priya ādīnām ananda maya avayava tvam
translated: But in the Taittiriya commentary, Priya and others are parts of the Bliss-Body.

analyzed: tathā api priya ādi sukha viśeṣa deha sthita brahma ākhya pradhāna vāyu gatānām nārāyaṇa ādi rūpāṇām eva ānanda maya ākhya viṣṇu avayava tva sambhavāt teṣām eva
translated: Even so, it is possible that only Narayana and other forms, which are in the primary wind called Brahman residing in the body, which gives the special bliss of Priya etc., are parts of Vishnu called the Bliss-Body.

analyzed: parā iyam priya nāmakam
translated: This is the supreme one named Priya.

analyzed: moda pramoda nāmānau modanāt ca pramodanāt
translated: Joy and delight are named from joy and delight.

original: dehasthavāyusaṃsthaṃ ca brahma sṛṣṭyā tu bṛṃhayet // iti /🔽taittirīyabhāṣyoktarītyā priyādiśabdavācyatvasyāpi sambhavānna virodhaḥ /
analyzed: deha stha vāyu saṃstham ca brahma sṛṣṭyā tu bṛṃhayet iti  taittirīya bhāṣya ukta rītyā priya ādi śabda vācyatvasya api sambhavāt na virodhaḥ
translated: And Brahman residing in the bodily wind would nourish creation.🔽Thus, there is no contradiction because it is also possible for the words Priya etc. to denote, according to the method stated in the Taittiriya commentary.

analyzed: tattvapradīpe tu priya śiraḥ tva ādi naye śravaṇa uttham priyam
translated: But in the Tattvadipika, in the Priya-shiras etc. method, Priya arises from hearing.
Delight arises from seeing.🔽Delight arises from enjoyment.

original: bhogotthaḥ pramodaḥiti padatrayasyārthāntaramuktam /🔽tathā tatraiva 'abhāvaṃ bādariḥ' /🔽iti sūtreṇa 'priyāpriye' / chāṃ / /
analyzed: bhoga utthaḥ pramodaḥ iti pada trayasya artha antaram uktam  tathā tatra eva abhāvam bādariḥ  iti sūtreṇa priya apriye chāṃ
translated: Thus, a different meaning of the three words is stated.🔽And in the same place, in the sutra Abhavam Badari,🔽by the word Priya in the scripture Priya-apri,

analyzed: iti śruti stha priya śabdena parā iyam priya nāmakam
translated: by the word Priya in the scripture, This is the supreme one named Priya.

original: iti taittirīyachāndogyabhāṣyayoruktatvātparaprāpyasukhasāmānyavācakena prākṛtaṃ sukhaṃ grāhyamiti sūcitamiti coktam /
analyzed: iti taittirīya chāndogya bhāṣyayoḥ ukta tvāt para prāpya sukha sāmānya vācakena prākṛtam sukham grāhyam iti sūcitam iti ca uktam
translated: Thus, since it has been stated in the Taittiriya and Chandogya commentaries, it has been indicated that natural happiness should be accepted by the word denoting the general happiness attainable by others.

analyzed: idam tu avadhayam paridṛśyamānam anna mayam śarīram
translated: This is the limited, visible food-body.

analyzed: tad antar prāṇa mayaḥ dehaḥ tad antar manaḥ mayaḥ dehaḥ
translated: Within that is the life-force body, within that is the mind body.

analyzed: tat antar vijñāna mayaḥ dehaḥ
translated: Within that is the consciousness body.

analyzed: tad antar ānanda mayaḥ sti
translated: Within that is the bliss body.

original: eteṣu pañcasu dehākhyakośeṣu tattacchabdavācyāni puruṣākārāṇi aniruddhapradyumnasaṅkarṣaṇavāsudevanārāyaṇarūpāṇi dehadehibhāvena vartanta iti
analyzed: eteṣu pañcasu deha ākhya kośeṣu tad tad śabda vācyāni puruṣa ākārāṇi aniruddha pradyumna saṅkarṣaṇa vāsudeva nārāyaṇa rūpāṇi deha dehi bhāvena vartante iti
translated: In these five bodies called sheaths, the forms of Aniruddha, Pradyumna, Sankarshana, Vasudeva, and Narayana, which are denoted by those words and have the form of a man, exist in the relationship of the embodied and the body.

analyzed: iti ānanda maya avayava rūpam pratīyate
translated: Thus, the form of the parts of the bliss body is understood.

original: na hyavayavinaṃ vinā avayavamātrasya jñeyatetyata āha //
analyzed: na hi avayavinam vinā avayava mātrasya jñeya tā iti atas āha
translated: For, without the whole, the mere parts cannot be known. Therefore, it is said:

analyzed: ānanda mayaḥ bhyāsāt
translated: The bliss body is Brahman by repetition.

analyzed: ānanda mayaḥ brahma ādiḥ prakṛtiḥ viṣṇuḥ vā
translated: The bliss body is Brahman and others, or Prakriti, or Vishnu.

original: evaṃ saṅgatiṃ phalaṃ coktvā viṣayasaṃśayau darśayati ānandamaya iti //
analyzed: evam saṅgatim phalam ca uktvā viṣaya saṃśayau darśayati ānanda mayaḥ iti
translated: Having thus stated the connection and result, he shows the subject and doubt, saying the bliss body and so on.

analyzed: ānanda mayaḥ iti upalakṣaka padena viṣayaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: The word bliss body is a suggestive word showing the subject.

analyzed: brahma ādiḥ iti atra brahmā ādiḥ yasya jīva saṅghasya iti vigrahaḥ
translated: The compound 'Brahmā-ādi' is to be analysed as 'the group of souls beginning with Brahmā'.

analyzed: brahmā catur mukhaḥ
translated: Brahmā is the four-faced one.

analyzed: ādi śabdena rudra indra bṛhaspati mukhāḥ devāḥ tad tad deha āgata jīvāḥ ca gṛhyante
translated: By the word 'ādi', gods such as Rudra, Indra, Bṛhaspati, and souls residing in those bodies are included.

analyzed: prakṛti śabdena cit prakṛtiḥ
translated: And by the word 'prakṛti', the intelligent nature.

analyzed: iti saṃśayaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Thus is the doubt. This is the remainder.

analyzed: brahma śabdāt hiraṇyagarbhasya prāptiḥ
translated: From the word 'Brahman', Hiraṇyagarbha is attained.

analyzed: śatānanda nāmnā ca
translated: And by the name 'Śatānanda'.

analyzed: atra sa yuktikam pūrvapakṣān āha brahma śabdāt iti
translated: Here he states the prima facie view along with reasons, beginning with 'from the word Brahman'.

analyzed: ānanda mayam adhikṛtya dāhṛte asti brahma iti ced veda
translated: With reference to the 'Ānandamaya', it is said in the Taittirīya Upaniṣad, 'If one knows that Brahman exists' (Taitt. Up. 2.1).

analyzed: ityādau śrutāt brahma śabdāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is from the word 'Brahman' heard in this and other places.

original: brahmaśabdasya anyatrāpi vṛtteḥ kathaṃ tena caturmukhasyānandamayatvaniśca ityato yuktyantaramāha śateti /
analyzed: brahma śabdasya anyatra api vṛtteḥ katham tena caturmukhasya ānanda maya tva niścaḥ iti atas yukti antaram āha śata iti
translated: Since the word 'Brahman' is used elsewhere also, how can the nature of being Ānandamaya be ascertained for the four-faced one by that? To this, he states another reason, beginning with 'śata'.

analyzed: caḥ pi arthe samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' has the sense of 'api' (even) and 'samuccaya' (collection).

analyzed: te ye śatam prajāpateḥ ānandāḥ
translated: Those hundred joys of Prajāpati,

analyzed: saḥ ekaḥ brahmaṇaḥ ānandaḥ
translated: that is one joy of Brahman. (Taitt. Up. 2.8).

analyzed: iti vākyāt arthāt sūcitena śatānanda nāmnā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is by the name 'Śatānanda' indicated by the meaning of this sentence.

analyzed: yat vā ānanda maya śabda samāna arthakena hiraṇyagarbhe vidyamānena śatānanda nāmnā iti arthaḥ
translated: Or, the meaning is that the name 'Śatānanda' belongs to Hiraṇyagarbha, who is synonymous with the word 'ānandamaya'.

analyzed: prāptiḥ ānanda maya tvasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Non-attainment. The rest is 'of the nature of bliss'.

analyzed: tathā ca hiraṇyagarbhasya ānanda maya tvasya prāptiḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: And thus the meaning is that there is non-attainment of the nature of bliss for Hiraṇyagarbha.

analyzed: aṣṭa mūrti tvāt sūrye prokta tvāt ca rudrasya
translated: Because of being the eight forms and because of being mentioned in the sun, Rudra.

analyzed: evam ekam pūrvapakṣam abhidhāya anyam āha aṣṭa mūrti tvāt iti
translated: Having stated one prima facie view in this way, he states another, saying 'because of being the eight forms' and so on.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ rudrasya ca iti sambadhyate
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is connected with 'of Rudra'.

original: prāptirityasyānukarṣaṇārtho vā tathā ca rudrasya cānandamayatvaprāptiḥ kutaḥ /
analyzed: prāptiḥ iti asya anukarṣaṇa arthaḥ vā tathā ca rudrasya ca ānanda maya tva prāptiḥ kutas
translated: Or, the word 'ca' (and) is for the purpose of drawing out the meaning of 'attainment'. And thus, why is there attainment of the nature of bliss for Rudra?

analyzed: sūrye prokta tvāt  yaḥ ca asau āditye taiu
translated: Because of being mentioned in the sun.🔽'And he who is in the sun' (Tai. Up. 2.1).

original: ityānandamayasya sūrye sthiteḥ uktatvādrudrasya ca sūryādyaṣṭaśarīratvādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: iti ānanda mayasya sūrye sthiteḥ ukta tvāt rudrasya ca sūrya ādi aṣṭa śarīra tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Because of the statement that the nature of bliss abides in the sun, and because Rudra has the eight bodies beginning with the sun, that is the meaning.

original: tathā ca rūdraliṅgasya ānandamaye śrutatvāt ānandamayo rudra evepi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca rūdra liṅgasya ānandamaye śruta tvāt ānanda mayaḥ rudraḥ eva ipi bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, because the mark of Rudra is heard in the nature of bliss, the nature of bliss is Rudra alone, this is the idea.

analyzed: rudrasya sūrya ādi aṣṭa pratima tvam ca
translated: And Rudra's having the eight images beginning with the sun:

original: sūryo jalaṃ mahī vahnirvāyurākāśa eva ca /
analyzed: sūryaḥ jalam mahī vahniḥ vāyuḥ ākāśaḥ eva ca
translated: The sun, water, earth, fire, air, and space,

analyzed: dīkṣitaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ somaḥ iti etāḥ tanavaḥ kramāt
translated: The initiated Brāhmaṇa, Soma—these are the names in order.

analyzed: iti viṣṇupurāṇa vākyāt siddham
translated: This is established by the statement in the Viṣṇu Purāṇa.

analyzed: evam anyeṣām api
translated: So also for others.

analyzed: pūrvapakṣa antaram darśayati evam iti  uktābhyām anyeṣām
translated: He shows another prima facie view, saying thus etc.

analyzed: indra bṛhaspati ādīnām api evam
translated: For others means for Indra, Bṛhaspati and others.

analyzed: ukta prakāreṇa sva avara sūrya ādi adhiṣṭhātṛ tva ādinā ānanda maya tva prāptiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus means in the manner stated, by attaining the state of being full of bliss by being the presiding deity of their own lower suns etc. This is the meaning.

analyzed: mama yoniḥ mahat brahma bha gī
translated: My source is the great Brahman (Bh. Gītā).

analyzed: iti brahma śabdāt
translated: This is because of the word Brahman.

analyzed: bahu bhāvāt ca prakṛteḥ
translated: And because of the multiplicity of Prakṛti.

analyzed: sa yuktikam pūrvapakṣa antaram āha mama iti
translated: With reasoning, he states another prima facie view, saying mine etc.

analyzed: yojanā tu cit prakṛteḥ vā ānanda maya tva prāptiḥ
translated: The plan is that the attainment of the state of being full of bliss by the cit-prakṛti.

original: kutaḥ / brahmaśabdāt/🔽ānandamaye śrutasya brahmaśabdasya 'mama yonirmahadbrahma tasmin garbhaṃ dadhāmyaham' /
analyzed: kutas brahma śabdāt  ānanda maye śrutasya brahma śabdasya mama yoniḥ mahat brahma tasmin garbham dadhāmi aham
translated: How so? Because of the word Brahman.

analyzed: iti gītāyām cit prakṛtau prayogāt iti
translated: Because the word Brahman, heard in the full of bliss, is used in the Gītā for the cit-prakṛti, in the passage My source is the great Brahman, in that I place the embryo.

analyzed: smṛtau mahat brahma iti bhinne pade
translated: In the Smṛti, the words great and Brahman are different.

original: tathā ca mahat brahmaśabdavācyā lakṣmīḥ mama yoniḥ garbhādhānārthaṃ bhāryā /
analyzed: tathā ca mahat brahma śabda vācyā lakṣmīḥ mama yoniḥ garbhādhāna artham bhāryā
translated: And thus, Lakṣmī, denoted by the words great and Brahman, is my source, the wife for the purpose of impregnation.

original: tasmin brahmaṇi prakṛtau ahaṃ garbhaṃ dadhāmi dadha ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tasmin brahmaṇi prakṛtau aham garbham dadhāmi dadhe iti arthaḥ
translated: In that Brahman, in Prakṛti, I place the seed, the meaning is I place the seed.

analyzed: arjunam prati kṛṣṇa vākyam etat
translated: This is the statement of Kṛṣṇa to Arjuna.

original: kathaṃ sāvakāśena brahmaśabdena prakṛterānandamayatvaniścaya ityato hetvantaramāha 'bahubhāvāt' /
analyzed: katham sa avakāśena brahma śabdena prakṛteḥ ānanda maya tva niścayaḥ iti atas hetu antaram āha bahu bhāvāt
translated: How is the certainty of the blissfulness of Prakṛti established by the word Brahman, which has other meanings? For this reason, he says, 'because of the many states'.

analyzed: bahu rūpa tvāt ca iti
translated: And because of the many forms.

analyzed: caḥ hetu samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for the combination of reasons.

analyzed: tathā ca saḥ kāmayata
translated: And thus, 'He desired'.

analyzed: bahu syām taiu
translated: 'May I become many.' Taittirīya Upaniṣad.

analyzed: iti ānanda mayasya bahu bhāvāt
translated: Thus, because of the many states of the bliss-filled one.

analyzed: bahu bhāva śravaṇāt tad abhimāni tvāt cit prakṛteḥ sva abhimanyamāna vikāri jaḍa dvārā bahu bhāva sambhavāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Because of the statement of the many states, because of the possibility of the many states of the conscious Prakṛti through the inert modifications that it identifies with, this is the meaning.

analyzed: evam prakṛteḥ iti asya jaḍa prakṛteḥ iti artha āśrayeṇa pūrvapakṣa antaram api draṣṭavyam
translated: In this way, the alternative view should also be seen based on the meaning of the word 'of Prakṛti' as 'of the inert Prakṛti'.

analyzed: yojanā tu jaḍa prakṛteḥ vā ānanda maya tva prāptiḥ
translated: The arrangement is: the attainment of the bliss-filled state by the inert Prakṛti.

analyzed: kutas abhimāni tvena vinā sākṣāt bahu bhāvāt eva iti
translated: Why? Because of the many states alone without the identification.

analyzed: jāti jīva kamala āsana śabdarāśiṣu iti brahma śabdāt eva
translated: The word 'Brahman' is used for the class, the individual soul, the lotus, the seat, and the collection of words.🔽Even from the word 'Brahman' alone,

analyzed: sarva jīvānām
translated: of all individual souls.

analyzed: anna maya tva ādeḥ ca
translated: And of the state of being made of food, etc.

analyzed: sa yuktikam pūrvapakṣa antaram āha
translated: He states another prima facie view along with reasons, beginning with The word 'brihat' (great).

analyzed: tad tad deha gata sarva jīvānām vā ānanda maya tva prāptiḥ
translated: Or the attainment of the state of being made of bliss by all the individual souls residing in those respective bodies.

analyzed: kutas jīvānām brahma śabdāt
translated: Why? Because of the word Brahman referring to the individual souls.

analyzed: jīva vāci brahma śabdāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because of the word Brahman referring to the individual souls.

analyzed: na tatra pṛthak hetuḥ gaveṣaṇīyaḥ iti eva śabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word eva (only) is that no separate reason need be sought.

original: kuto brahmaśabdasya jīvavācitvamityata uktam bṛha jātīti /
analyzed: kutas brahma śabdasya jīva vāci tvam iti atas uktam
translated: From where does the word Brahman refer to the individual souls? In response, it is said: The word 'brihat' (great).

analyzed: bṛhadhātuḥ jāti ādiṣu vartate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: the root brih is used in the sense of birth, etc.

analyzed: iti iti anantaram dhātu vyākhyānāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: After iti, the rest is supplied: from the explanation of the root.

analyzed: brahma śabdasya sādhāraṇa tvāt aniścāyaka tvam iti atas āha anna maya tva ādeḥ ca iti
translated: Since the word Brahman is common, it is inconclusive. In response, it is said: And because of being made of food, etc.

analyzed: idam ca āvartate
translated: This is repeated.

analyzed: tatra dvitīyaḥ vipariṇamyate
translated: There, the second is modified.

analyzed: ādi śabdaḥ bhinnakramaḥ
translated: The word ādi (etc.) has a different sequence.

analyzed: tena prāṇa ādikam gṛhyate
translated: By that, the life force and so on are included.

analyzed: yathākramaḥ ca caśabdaḥ ukta anukta hetu samuccaye
translated: And the word ca (and) in sequence is for the combination of stated and unstated reasons.

analyzed: tathā ca na kevalam brahma śabdāt
translated: And thus, it is not only because of the word Brahman.

analyzed: kintu  yatas jīvānām anna rasa mayaḥ
translated: But rather,🔽because the individual souls are made of the essence of food,

analyzed: prāṇa mayaḥ
translated: made of the life force,

analyzed: iti ukta annādi maya tvāt anna ādi vikāra deha ādi abhimāni tvāt anna maya tva ādi prāptam atas tad prāya paṭhita tvāt ca ānanda maya tva prāptiḥ iti yojanā
translated: Thus, because of being made of food etc., because of the conception of the body etc. as modifications of food etc., the state of being made of food etc. is obtained. Therefore, because of being mostly recited, the state of being made of bliss is obtained. This is the construction.

analyzed: atra hiraṇyagarbha ādīnām jīva tve pi deva tva vivakṣayā pṛthak uktiḥ
translated: Here, although Hiranyagarbha etc. are individual souls, they are mentioned separately with the intention of their being gods.

original: ata eva tattvapradīpe brahmādiryasya devatāsaṅghasyaityapi brahmādirityasya vigraho darśitaḥ /
analyzed: atas eva tattvapradīpe brahma ādiḥ yasya devatā saṅghasya eti api brahma ādiḥ iti asya vigrahaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: For this very reason, in the Tattvapradipa, the compound 'brahma-adi' is shown to mean 'the group of deities headed by Brahma'.

analyzed: tatra api hiraṇyagarbha rudrayoḥ ati prasiddha tvāt vakṣyamāṇa krameṇa pṛthak uktiḥ
translated: Even there, because of the great fame of Hiranyagarbha and Rudra, they are mentioned separately in the manner to be described.

original: atha indrādīnāṃ brahmā śivaḥ sureśādyāḥiti vacanoktakrameṇa kṣaradevoktyanantaramakṣarāyāḥ prakṛteruktiḥ /
analyzed: atha indra ādīnām brahmā śivaḥ sureśa ādyāḥ iti vacana ukta krameṇa kṣara deva ukti anantaram akṣarāyāḥ prakṛteḥ uktiḥ
translated: Then, in the order stated in the words 'Brahma, Shiva, the lord of gods etc.', after mentioning the perishable gods, the mention of the imperishable Prakriti is made.

analyzed: atha ati alpa pratibhāna tvāt dṛśyamāna deha abhimāni jīvānām iti dhyeyam
translated: Then, because of having very little intelligence, it should be thought that they are individual souls who conceive themselves to be the visible body.

analyzed: tathā api na te ānanda maya śabdena ucyante
translated: Even so, they are not called the one made of bliss.

analyzed: kintu viṣṇuḥ eva
translated: But. Vishnu alone.

analyzed: tat eva brahma paramam kavīnām
translated: 'That alone is the supreme Brahman of the sages.' Maha-na.

analyzed: etam eva brahma iti ācakṣate
translated: 'They call him Brahman alone.' Ai.A.

analyzed: siddhāntayati tathā api iti
translated: He concludes thus: Even so.

analyzed: yadi api evam anyeṣām prāptiḥ
translated: Even though it is so for others,

original: tathāpi atra ye ānandamayaśabdenocyante na te hiraṇyagarbhādaya ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api atra ye ānanda maya śabdena ucyante na te hiraṇyagarbha ādayaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: the meaning is that those who are called the 'one consisting of bliss' here are not Hiraṇyagarbha and others.

analyzed: kaḥ tarhi iti āśaṅkate kintu iti
translated: Then who is it? He doubts with 'but'.

analyzed: uttaram āha viṣṇuḥ eva iti
translated: He answers with 'Viṣṇu alone'.

original: ya ucyate sa viṣṇurevetyanvayaḥ /🔽anenodāhṛtānandamaya iti sūtrapratijñābhāgasya saṅgatyarthamanvayārthaṃ samanvayasūtrodāhṛto vidheyasamarpakaḥ 'tattu' /
analyzed: yaḥ ucyate sa viṣṇuḥ eva iti anvayaḥ  anena udāhṛta ānanda mayaḥ iti sūtra pratijñā bhāgasya saṅgati artham anvaya artham samanvaya sūtra udāhṛtaḥ vidheya samarpakaḥ tat tu
translated: The meaning is that he who is spoken of is Viṣṇu alone.

analyzed: iti pratijñā bhāgaḥ vyākhyātaḥ bhavati
translated: By this, the part of the sūtra's thesis 'the one consisting of bliss mentioned here' is explained for the sake of connection and meaning, for the sake of the connection with the sūtra on identification, the part of the thesis 'that alone' which indicates what is to be done is explained.

original: kuta ānandamayo viṣṇurevetyataḥ pravṛttaṃ sautraṃ hetuṃ vyācaṣṭe tadeveti /🔽ityādiṣu vākyeṣu tasminviṣṇāveva prasiddhasya mukhyārthatvenoktasya brahmaśabdasya tasminnānandamaye ānandamayaṃ pratyudāhṛte 'asanneva' /
analyzed: kutas ānanda mayaḥ viṣṇuḥ eva iti atas pravṛttam sautram hetum vyācaṣṭe tat eva iti  ityādiṣu vākyeṣu tasmin viṣṇau eva prasiddhasya mukhya artha tvena uktasya brahma śabdasya tasmin ānanda maye ānanda mayam pratyudāhṛte asan eva
translated: From where is the one consisting of bliss Viṣṇu alone? Therefore, the reason stated in the sūtra is explained with 'that alone' etc.

analyzed: iti śloke abhyāsāt
translated: In the passages beginning with 'that alone', the word 'Brahman', which is well-known and stated as the primary meaning in Viṣṇu alone, of that 'Brahman', in the one consisting of bliss, which is referred to as the one consisting of bliss, in the verse 'asat eva',🔽by 'abhyāsa' (repetition).

analyzed: asakṛt śravaṇāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is by hearing repeatedly.

analyzed: abhyāsāt iti anantaram viṣṇau tātparya avagamāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: After 'abhyāsa', the remainder is 'because of the understanding of the purport in Viṣṇu'.

original: aprayojakatvaśaṅkāvāraṇāya brahmaśabdasyānyatra niravakāśatvajñāpanāya tasmin prasiddheti eveti coktam/
analyzed: aprayojaka tva śaṅkā vāraṇāya brahma śabdasya anyatra niravakāśa tva jñāpanāya tasmin prasiddhā iti eva iti ca uktam
translated: To ward off the doubt of being irrelevant, and to show that the word Brahman is not subject to misinterpretation elsewhere, it is said in that and only.

analyzed: ādi śabdena paramam yaḥ mahat brahma  vāsudevāt paraḥ
translated: By the word ādi (beginning with), the sentence He who is the supreme great Brahman is included.

analyzed: kaḥ nu brahma śabda uditaḥ bhavet
translated: Who else can be denoted by the word Brahman than Vāsudeva?

analyzed: iti vākyam gṛhyate
translated: This sentence is included.

analyzed: tat eva iti śruti arthaḥ tu jijñāsā naye bhihitaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Vedic text That alone is stated in the section on inquiry.

analyzed: etam eva iti śruti arthaḥ sarvatra adhikaraṇe vakṣyate
translated: The meaning of the Vedic text This very will be stated throughout the section.

analyzed: brahma śabdaḥ pare viṣṇau na anyatra kvacid iṣyate
translated: The word Brahman is accepted only in the supreme Viṣṇu, not anywhere else.

analyzed: asampūrṇāḥ pare yasmāt upacāreṇa vā bhavet
translated: Because others are incomplete, or it may be by figurative use.

analyzed: brahma iti paramātmā iti bhagavān iti śabdyate
translated: He is called Brahman, the Supreme Self, and the Lord.

analyzed: vāsudeva ātmakam brahma mūlamantreṇa vā yatiḥ
translated: The ascetic, by the root mantra, identifies Brahman, which is of the nature of Vāsudeva.

analyzed: ityādiṣu tasmin eva prasiddha brahma śabda abhyāsāt  brahma śabdaḥ
translated: In these and other passages, because the word Brahman is repeated only in Him.

analyzed: iti smṛtau pare
translated: In the smrti (memorable sayings), the word Brahman🔽in the supreme

analyzed: pūrṇe iti hetu garbha viśeṣaṇam
translated: is a qualifying word containing a reason.

analyzed: vā śabdaḥ vadhāraṇe
translated: The word vā (or) is for emphasis.

analyzed: tathā ca yatas viṣṇuḥ paraḥ
translated: And thus, because Viṣṇu is supreme,

analyzed: atas pare viṣṇau eva brahma śabdaḥ mukhya tayā iṣyate
translated: Therefore, 'others' - the word Brahman is accepted as primary only in Vishnu.

analyzed: aṅgīkriyate prāmāṇikaiḥ
translated: It is accepted by the authoritative ones.

analyzed: na tu viṣṇoḥ anyatra
translated: Not in anything 'other' than Vishnu.

analyzed: hiraṇyagarbha ādiṣu api iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is also in Hiranyagarbha and others.

analyzed: kutas iti atas teṣām brahma śabda mukhya artha tva abhāve hetum āha pare
translated: Why is it so? For that reason, he states the reason for the absence of the primary meaning of the word Brahman in them, 'others'.

analyzed: anye yasmāt a sampūrṇāḥ iti
translated: Others, because they are incomplete.

original: tarhi 'tasmādetadbrahma nāma rūpamannaṃ ca jāyate' / mu / /
analyzed: tarhi tasmāt etat brahma nāma rūpam annam ca jāyate
translated: Then, 'Therefore, from this Brahman, name, form, and food are born.' Mu.

analyzed: dve brahmaṇī veditavye maitriu
translated: 'Two Brahmans are to be known.' Maitri.

analyzed: brahmāṇi jīvāḥ sarve pi
translated: 'All the individual souls are Brahmans.'

original: ityādau brahmaśabdasteṣu kathamiṣyata ityata āha kvacidanyatreṣṭo 'pi brahmaśabdaḥ 'upacāreṇa' /
analyzed: ityādau brahma śabdaḥ teṣu katham iṣyate iti atas āha kvacid anyatra iṣṭaḥ pi brahma śabdaḥ upacāreṇa
translated: In this way, how is the word Brahman accepted in them? Therefore, he says that the word Brahman, even when accepted elsewhere, is 'by figurative usage'.

analyzed: parama mukhya vṛtti anya mukhya vṛttyā eva bhavet iti
translated: It should be by the primary meaning other than the supreme primary meaning.

analyzed: brahma iti bhāgavata smṛti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Smriti of the Bhagavata is 'Brahman'.

analyzed: prāk eva uktaḥ
translated: It has been stated earlier itself.

original: madhye ātmapadopetasādhāraṇasmṛtyupādānanimittaṃ tu abhyāsādityasya 'anyontara ātmā' / tai / u / /
analyzed: madhye ātma pada upeta sādhāraṇa smṛti upādāna nimittam tu abhyāsāt ityasya anyaḥ ntaraḥ ātmā taiḥ u
translated: But the reason for the use of the common Smriti containing the word Atman in the middle is 'because of repetition', of 'the inner Atman.' Tai.

original: ityādau brahmavācakātmaśabdābhyāsādityapyartho varṇanīya iti jñāpanamityuktaṃ candrikāyām /
analyzed: ityādau brahma vācaka ātma śabda abhyāsāt iti api arthaḥ varṇanīyaḥ iti jñāpanam iti uktam candrikāyām
translated: In this way, it is said in the Candrika that the meaning of the repetition of the words atma and brahma should be explained.

analyzed: vāsudeva ātmakam  iti vyāsa smṛti vākyam tu buddhyā a vihiṃsan puṣpaiḥ vā praṇavena samarcayet
translated: Having the nature of Vāsudeva.

analyzed: iti pūrva vākyena saha yojanīyam
translated: This statement from the Smṛti of Vyāsa should be connected with the previous statement: Not harming with the intellect, one should worship with flowers or the Praṇava.

original: atra hi vāsudevātmakaṃ brahmetyāderbhagavān brahmeti pratīyate iti nyāyadīpokteḥ /
analyzed: atra hi vāsudeva ātmakam brahma ityādeḥ bhagavān brahma iti pratīyate iti nyāyadīpa ukteḥ
translated: Here, from the statement having the nature of Vāsudeva, Brahman, it is understood that the Lord is Brahman, as stated in the Nyāyadyot.

analyzed: yatiḥ vāsudeva ātmakam
translated: The ascetic, having the nature of Vāsudeva,

analyzed: kṛṣṇa ākhyam brahma buddhyā
translated: the Brahman named Kṛṣṇa, with the intellect,

original: manasā samarcayedityanena yatīnāṃ mānasapūjocyate puṣpādyairvā samarcayet ityanena kāyikapūjā /
analyzed: manasā samarcayet iti anena yatīnām mānasa pūjā ucyate puṣpa ādyaiḥ vā samarcayet iti anena kāyika pūjā
translated: with the mind, should worship. By this, mental worship of the ascetics is stated. By the statement or should worship with flowers etc., bodily worship is stated.

original: 'avihiṃsan' / kasyāpi hiṃsāṃ hānimakurvanniti teṣāṃ sāmānyadharmoktiḥ /🔽anena yatīnāṃ vaiṣṇavatvaprayuktāt
analyzed: a vihiṃsan kasya api hiṃsām hānim akurvan iti teṣām sāmānya dharma uktiḥ  anena yatīnām vaiṣṇava tva prayuktāt
translated: Not harming, not causing harm or loss to anyone. This is the statement of a general duty of them.

analyzed: tulasī puṣpa ādi āharaṇa rūpāt vaiśeṣikāt dharmāt ahiṃsā lakṣaṇaḥ sāmānya dharmaḥ eva balavān iti uktam bhavati
translated: By this, it is said that for the ascetics, the general duty characterized by non-violence is stronger than the specific duties arising from their being Vaiṣṇavas, such as collecting Tulasī leaves etc.

analyzed: yathā uktam bṛhadbhāṣye sāmānya dharmaḥ balavān dharmāt vaiśeṣikāt yatas iti
translated: As it is said in the Brihad-bhasya: The general attribute is stronger than the specific attribute.🔽By the Pranava means by the Om-kāra.

analyzed: praṇavena oṅkāreṇa mūlamantreṇa
translated: By the Mūlamantra means by the Aṣṭākṣara mantra.

original: aṣṭākṣareṇa vā samarcayedityanena vācikapūjocyate iti jñātavyam / 🔽vikāraśabdān neti cen na prācuryāt / / / /
analyzed: aṣṭa akṣareṇa vā samarcayet iti anena vācika pūjā ucyate iti jñātavyam  vikāra śabdāt na iti ced na prācuryāt
translated: Or one should worship with the Aṣṭākṣara mantra. By this it should be understood that the verbal worship is being mentioned.🔽If it is argued that the word maya is not appropriate for the Supreme Self because it denotes modification, that is not so, because it is used in the sense of abundance.

analyzed: vikāra ātmaka tvāt tad abhimāni tvāt ca yujyate prakṛti ādīnām mayaṭ śabdaḥ
translated: The word maya is appropriate for Prakriti and others because they have the nature of modification and because they identify with it.

analyzed: na tu paramātmanaḥ iti mā abhūt
translated: But it should not be so for the Supreme Self.

analyzed: pracura ānanda tvāt hi ānanda mayaḥ
translated: He is Ānandamaya because He is the abundance of bliss.

analyzed: na tu tad vikāna tvāt
translated: But not because He is a modification of that.

analyzed: uktam ākṣipya samādadhat sūtram paṭhitvā ākṣepa aṃśam vyācaṣṭe vikāra iti
translated: Having quoted a sutra that refutes and establishes this, he explains the part that refutes with the words vikāre etc.

analyzed: atra caḥ hetu samuccaye
translated: And here the word ca (and) is for the purpose of including reasons.

analyzed: prakṛti śabdena cit acit prakṛtī gṛhyete
translated: By the word Prakṛti (primordial matter), the conscious and unconscious primordial matters are meant.

analyzed: ādi śabdena jīvāḥ gṛhyante
translated: By the word ādi (etc.), the individual souls are meant.

analyzed: prakṛti ādayaḥ iti ca vipariṇamyate
translated: And Prakṛtyādyaḥ (having primordial matter etc.) is modified.

analyzed: naṃ āvartate
translated: The word na (not) is repeated.

analyzed: ānanda mayaḥ iti asti
translated: Ānandamaya (full of bliss) is there.

analyzed: kim tu viṣṇuḥ iti ca
translated: But Viṣṇu is not.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ viśeṣa arthaḥ ca
translated: The word tu (but) has the sense of distinction and the sense of restriction.

analyzed: tathā ca ānanda mayaḥ na viṣṇuḥ
translated: And thus Ānandamaya is not Viṣṇu.

analyzed: kintu
translated: But.

analyzed: prakṛti ādayaḥ eva  kutas yatas tra vikāra śabdaḥ
translated: Prakriti and the rest.🔽Why? Because here there is the word 'modification'.

analyzed: vikāra arthakam ayaṭ śabdaḥ yujyate
translated: The word 'maya', which means modification, is not appropriate.

analyzed: prayujyate
translated: It is used.

analyzed: sa ca yatas vikāra tad abhimāni tvābhyām eva yujyate
translated: And that is appropriate only because of modification and the sense of being modified.

analyzed: pravartate
translated: It proceeds.

analyzed: atas prakṛti ādīnām eva yujyate
translated: Therefore, it is appropriate only for Prakriti and the rest.

analyzed: kutas jaḍa prakṛteḥ vikāra ātmaka tvāt cetana prakṛti ādīnām ca vikāra abhimāni tvāt
translated: Why? Because the inert Prakriti is of the nature of modification, and the conscious Prakriti and the rest have the sense of being modifications,

analyzed: na tu paramātmanaḥ
translated: but not for the supreme Self.

analyzed: tasya avikāri tvāt anabhimāni tvāt ca iti yojanā
translated: Because He is changeless and has no sense of ego. This is the construction.

analyzed: iti ced naḥ iti aṃśam vyācaṣṭe iti mā abhūt iti
translated: If it is argued that this is not so, he explains the part 'iti cet, na' as 'iti mābhūt'.

analyzed: śaṅkā iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is 'śaṅkā'.

original: kuta ityataḥ pravṛttaṃ sautraṃ hetuṃ vyācaṣṭe pracureti /
analyzed: kutas iti atas pravṛttam sautram hetum vyācaṣṭe pracura iti
translated: From where? Therefore, he explains the reason stated in the sutra as 'pracura' etc.

analyzed: ānanda mayaḥ kathyate iti śeṣaḥ  hi śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The remainder is 'ānandamayaḥ kathayate'.🔽The word 'hi' is a reason.

analyzed: tuśabdaḥ vadhāraṇa arthaḥ
translated: The word 'tu' is for determination.

analyzed: tathā ca hi yatas ānanda mayaḥ  padārthaḥ pracura ānanda tvāt
translated: And thus, 'hi', because 'ānandamaya'🔽is the meaning of the word, it is described by the word 'ānandamaya' because of the abundance of bliss

analyzed: pūrṇa ānanda tvāt ca nimittāt eva ānanda maya padena kathyate na tad vikāra tvāt
translated: and because of complete bliss, not because of being its modification.

original: ānandavikāratvādata iti śaṅkā mābhūditi yojanā /🔽mayaṭchabdasya prācuryarūpārthāntaramapekṣya pravṛttatvena tadvirodhābhāvāditi bhāvaḥ
analyzed: ānanda vikāra tvāt atas iti śaṅkā mā abhūt iti yojanā  mayaṭ śabdasya prācurya rūpa artha antaram apekṣya pravṛtta tvena tad virodha abhāvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The construction is: Let there be no doubt that it is so because of being a modification of bliss.🔽The meaning is that because the word 'maya' is used in dependence on another meaning of abundance, there is no contradiction with that.

original: mayaḍityākhyapratyayasya prācuryārthatvaṃ ca 'tādātmyārthe vikārārthe prācuryārthe mayaṭ tridhā' /
analyzed: mayaṭ iti ākhya pratyayasya prācurya artha tvam ca tādātmya arthe vikāra arthe prācurya arthe mayaṭ tridhā
translated: The meaning of the suffix 'maya' as meaning abundance is established by the statement: Maya is threefold in the sense of identity, modification, and abundance.

original: iti vacanātsiddhamityapi herarthaḥ /🔽yadyapi śrutisūtragatānandamaya iti vyākhyeyapadasya taddhitāntasyārthakathanāya
analyzed: iti vacanāt siddham iti api heḥ arthaḥ  yadi api śruti sūtra gata ānanda mayaḥ iti vyākhyeya padasya taddhita antasya artha kathanāya
translated: The meaning of the word 'hi' is also that this is established.🔽Although the compound word 'ānandamaya' in the śruti and sūtra should be analyzed as 'ānandaḥ pracuryo yasmin sa ānandapracuraḥ' in accordance with the meaning of the word ending in the suffix,

original: tadanukūlatayā ānandaḥ pracuro yasmin sa ānandapracuraḥ iti samāsaḥ kāryo na tadviparītaḥ
analyzed: tad anukūla tayā ānandaḥ pracuraḥ yasmin saḥ ānanda pracuraḥ iti samāsaḥ kāryaḥ na tad viparītaḥ
translated: in order to explain the meaning, not as the opposite compound

analyzed: pracuraḥ ānandaḥ smin sa pracura ānandaḥ iti
translated: 'pracura ānandaḥ asmin sa pracurānandaḥ',

original: tathāpyāndamaya iti taddhitavṛttyananuguṇānandapracuraiti samāsavākyābhidhāne brāhmaṇapracuro grāma itivat ānānandasyāpi prāptestadvāraṇāya
analyzed: tathā api ānda mayaḥ iti taddhita vṛtti ananuguṇa ānanda pracurā eti samāsa vākya abhidhāne brāhmaṇa pracuraḥ grāmaḥ iti vat ān ānandasya api prāpteḥ tad vāraṇāya
translated: nevertheless, in the expression of the compound sentence 'ānandapracura' which is not in accordance with the usage of the suffix 'maya', in order to exclude the possibility of the meaning of 'ānanda' being obtained like the sentence 'grāmaḥ pracurabrāhmaṇaḥ' (the village has many Brahmins),

analyzed: pracura ānandaḥ iti viparīta samāsaḥ kṛtaḥ
translated: the opposite compound 'pracurānandaḥ' is used.

original: kecittu sūtre prācuryādityuktatvādānandasyetyarthalabdhaṃ /🔽tathā caitadvākyānusāreṇānandapracuratvāditi samāsavākyaprayogaḥ kāryo yadyapi /
analyzed: kecid tu sūtre prācuryāt iti ukta tvāt ānandasya iti artha labdham  tathā ca etad vākya anusāreṇa ānanda pracura tvāt iti samāsa vākya prayogaḥ kāryaḥ yadi api
translated: Some, however, say that since it is said in the sutra because of abundance, the meaning of of bliss is understood.🔽And thus, in accordance with this statement, the compound sentence because of the abundance of bliss should be used. Even though

original: tathāpi uktaprayojanābhiprāyeṇa pracurānandatvāditi sautravyāsavākyaviparītasamāsaḥ kṛta ityāhuḥ /
analyzed: tathā api ukta prayojana abhiprāyeṇa pracura ānanda tvāt iti sautra vyāsa vākya viparīta samāsaḥ kṛtaḥ iti āhuḥ
translated: this is so, they say that the reverse compound because of the abundance of bliss is used with the intention of the stated purpose, contrary to the sutra statement of Vyasa.

analyzed: tat na ānanda pracuraḥ iti yathāsthita abhidhāna ityādi ṭīkā virodhāt
translated: That is not so, because it contradicts the commentary that says if it is stated as it stands, as 'abounding in bliss' and so on.

original: yadyapyānandamaya iti śrutisūtrānusāreṇa prācuryasya viśeṣyatvenoktāvapi nānānandaprāptiḥṣa prākāśapracuro ravirityukte 'pi savitaryandhakāraleśāpratīteḥ
analyzed: yadi api ānanda mayaḥ iti śruti sūtra anusāreṇa prācuryasya viśeṣya tvena uktau api nānā ānanda prāptiḥ ṣa prākāśa pracuraḥ raviḥ iti ukte savitari andhakāra leśa apratīteḥ
translated: Even though, in accordance with the scriptures and sutras, full of bliss is stated as the qualifying factor of abundance, the attainment of various kinds of bliss is not implied, just as when it is said the sun is full of light, darkness is not implied in the sun.

original: tathā cānandapracuratvādityeva vyākhyātumucitam /🔽prācuryasya vyadhikaraṇasajātīyajaivānandālpatvenāpi nirūpayituṃ śakyatvāt /
analyzed: tathā ca ānanda pracura tvāt iti eva vyākhyātum ucitam  prācuryasya vyadhikaraṇa sajātīya ja eva ānanda alpatvena api nirūpayitum śakya tvāt
translated: And thus, it is proper to explain it as because of the abundance of bliss.🔽Because abundance can be determined even by the lesser bliss of the same kind in a different substratum.

original: tathāpi prācuryasya viśeṣaṇatāyāmanānandāprāpteḥ parairapi svīkṛtatvāt viśeṣyatāyāṃ
analyzed: tathā api prācuryasya viśeṣaṇa tāyām anānanda aprāpteḥ paraiḥ api svīkṛta tvāt viśeṣya tāyām
translated: Nevertheless, because others also accept that when abundance is taken as a qualifier, bliss is not attained, and when it is taken as a qualified,

original: tu tasya samānādhikaraṇavijātīyālpatvanirūpyatvāt brāhmaṇapracuro grāma ityādāviva
analyzed: tu tasya samāna adhikaraṇa vijātīya alpatva nirūpya tvāt brāhmaṇa pracuraḥ grāmaḥ ityādau iva
translated: Because it is to be determined in relation to the smallness of the homogeneous and heterogeneous, just as in the expression a village abundant in Brahmins,

analyzed: tad prāptiḥ evā iti aṅgīkṛta tvāt ubhaya vādi siddhi anusāreṇa eva vyākhyātavya tvāt tad abhiprāyeṇa
translated: and because it is accepted that the attainment of that is itself, it should be explained in accordance with the agreement of both parties. With that intention,

analyzed: pracura ānanda tvāt iti vyākhyātam bhāṣye iti uktam candrikāyām
translated: it is explained in the commentary that it is because of the abundance of bliss. This is stated in the Candrika.

analyzed: anna ādīnām ca prācuryam eva
translated: And the abundance itself of food etc.

analyzed: adyate tti ca tai
translated: It is eaten and it eats.

analyzed: iti vyākhyānāt tad prācuryam ca yujyate
translated: By this explanation, that abundance is appropriate.

analyzed: nanu na ayam ānanda maya śabdaḥ pracura ānanda tām abhidhatte
translated: But this word full of bliss does not denote abundance of bliss.

analyzed: kintu vikāra artha tvam eva
translated: Rather, it has the meaning of modification itself.

analyzed: anna ādi vikāra artha anna maya ādi śabdaiḥ saha paṭhita tvāt iti atas āha anna ādīnām ca iti
translated: Because it is recited along with the words full of food etc., which have the meaning of modifications of food etc. Therefore he says and of food etc.

analyzed: idam ca āvartate  mayaṭ śabdaḥ iti ca anuvartate
translated: And this is repeated.🔽And the word full of is continued.

analyzed: tena samuccaya artha caśabdasya anvayaḥ
translated: Therefore, the word and is connected for the purpose of combination.

analyzed: vācya vācakayoḥ abheda vyapadeśaḥ
translated: The designation of non-difference between the denoted and the denotative.

analyzed: tathā ca na kevalam ānandasya mayaṭ śabdaḥ
translated: And thus, the word full of is not only of bliss.

analyzed: kintu anna ādīnām anna ādīnām prācuryam eva vakti iti arthaḥ
translated: But the word 'may' which is related to 'food' etc. also expresses only the abundance of food etc.

analyzed: evaśabdaḥ vikāra arthatā vyāvṛtti arthaḥ
translated: The word 'eva' (only) is for the purpose of excluding the meaning of modification.

analyzed: ādi śabdena prāṇa ādayaḥ gṛhyante
translated: The word 'ādi' (etc.) includes prāṇa (vital air) and so on.

analyzed: pūrvam anna maya tva ādeḥ ca iti
translated: Previously, 'and because of being made of food etc.' (Sūtra 1.1.9).

analyzed: atra ca anna ādīnām
translated: And here, 'of food etc.' (Sūtra 1.1.10).

analyzed: iti bahūnām grahaṇāt
translated: Because of the mention of many,
it is indicated that the word 'ānandamaya' (full of bliss) in the sūtra, by the method of indicating its own meaning, indicates other words with the same reasoning.

analyzed: nanu katham atra anna maya śabdaḥ nna prācurya arthaḥ
translated: But how can the word 'ānnamaya' (made of food) here mean abundance of food?

original: auṣadhijanitānnaprācuryasya annopajīviṣu pārthivaśarīreṣu sambhave 'pi aprākṛtavigrahe harau asambhavāt /🔽annaprācuryakathanasyātyalpatvāpādakatvāccetyata āha adyata iti /
analyzed: auṣadhi janita anna prācuryasya anna upajīviṣu pārthiva śarīreṣu sambhave api aprākṛta vigrahe harau asambhavāt  anna prācurya kathanasya ati alpatva āpādaka tvāt ca iti atas āha adyate iti
translated: Because the abundance of food produced from medicine is possible in the earthly bodies of those who subsist on food, but is impossible in Hari who has an extraordinary form,🔽and because stating the abundance of food would lead to the consequence of its being too little. Therefore it is said 'from the sentence'.

analyzed: vākyena anna śabdasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is 'of the word food.🔽After 'is proper',

analyzed: yujyate iti anantaram anna maya śabda arthaḥ  iti adhyāhāraḥ
translated: the meaning of the word 'ānnamaya' (made of food) should be supplied.

analyzed: paramātmanaḥ iti asti
translated: 'Of the Supreme Self' is supplied.

analyzed: na kevalam sahapāṭha virodha abhāvaḥ iti ca arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: not only is there no contradiction with the simultaneous reading,🔽but also...

analyzed: tathā ca ittham yojanā tad prācuryam
translated: And thus the explanation is: 'That abundance'.

analyzed: anna prācuryam anna maya śabda arthaḥ yujyate
translated: The meaning of the word 'annamaya' is suitable as the abundance of food.

analyzed: katham yatas tat paramātmanaḥ yajyate
translated: How? Because that is worshipped by the supreme self.

original: na cālpārthatvena māhātmyarūpatvābhāvātsa kathaṃ harau yujyata iti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca alpa artha tvena māhātmya rūpa tva abhāvāt sa katham harau yujyate iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that it is not suitable in Hari because it does not have the nature of greatness due to having a small meaning.

analyzed: eva yujyate
translated: Because here, in the word 'anna', the two meanings in the form of the essence of each element and the essence of the elements are suitable only in the sense of the predominance of the abstract noun, as stated by Sudha.

analyzed: ucyate na prasiddha annam
translated: It is said that it is not well-known food.

analyzed: ku etat jñāyate
translated: How is this known?

original: adyate 'tti ca bhūtāni /🔽tasmādannaṃ taducyata itivākyenānnaśabdasya vyākhyānāt /
analyzed: adyate ca bhūtāni  tasmāt annam tat ucyate iti vākyena anna śabdasya vyākhyānāt
translated: It is said in the sentence 'It is eaten and it eats the elements,'🔽therefore it is called food.

original: prasiddhānnasya bhūtāttṛtvāyogena tadgrahaṇāsambhavāditi /🔽śrutyarthastu yato bhūtaiḥ prāṇibhiḥ 'adyate' /
analyzed: prasiddha annasya bhūta attṛ tva ayogena tad grahaṇa asambhavāt iti  śruti arthaḥ tu yatas bhūtaiḥ prāṇibhiḥ adyate
translated: Because it is not possible to take that as the well-known food, since it is not suitable to be the eater of the elements.🔽But the meaning of the scripture is: Because it is eaten by the elements, by living beings.

analyzed: upajīvyate bhūtāni atti
translated: It eats the elements.

analyzed: saṃharati ca
translated: And it withdraws them.

analyzed: tasmāt tat viṣṇu ākhyam brahma annam ucyate vedeṣu iti
translated: Therefore, that Brahman called Vishnu is said to be food in the Vedas.

analyzed: evam prāṇa manaḥ śabdayoḥ prakṛṣṭa ceṣṭaka tva pūrṇa avabodha artha tvena śvāsa vāyu antaḥkaraṇa buddhi prācurya artha tāyām alpa artha tā pariharaṇīyā
translated: Similarly, in the case of the words 'prāṇa' and 'manas', in the sense of 'that which moves most' and 'that which fully understands', the meaning of 'predominance of breath-wind' and 'internal organ and cognition' should be accepted, avoiding the meaning of 'little'.

analyzed: upajīvya tvam eva ādya tvam
translated: Being the object of dependence is being the first.

analyzed: sa vā eṣaḥ tai
translated: 'He is that' (Tai.

analyzed: iti anya prārambhāt
translated: Thus, because it begins with something else.

original: nanu tathāpi pracurabhūtādyatvaṃ kathamabhisaṃhitaṃ brahmaṇaḥ /🔽bhakṣyatvarūpādyatvasya tatrāyogādityato 'dyatvaśabdārtamāha upajīvyatvamiti //
analyzed: nanu tathā api pracura bhūta ādya tvam katham abhisaṃhitam brahmaṇaḥ  bhakṣya tva rūpa ādya tvasya tatra ayogāt iti atas dya tva śabda ārtam āha upajīvya tvam iti
translated: But even so, how is the predominance of earth, etc., which is abundant, intended in Brahman?

analyzed: atra a taḥ dyate  iti anuvyākhyāna anusāreṇa ādya tvam iti chedaḥ
translated: Because the predominance in the form of being eaten is not possible there. To this, he says the meaning of the word 'adyatva' (firstness) is 'upajīvyatva' (being the object of dependence).🔽Here, in accordance with the Anuvṛtti (repetition) of 'ata ādyate' (therefore it is eaten), 'adyatva' (firstness) is to be understood.

original: tathā ca sudhoktarītyā gauṇyā vṛttyā upajīvyatvamevādyatvaṃ vivakṣitaṃ /
analyzed: tathā ca sudhā ukta rītyā gauṇyā vṛttyā upajīvya tvam eva ādya tvam vivakṣitam
translated: And thus, in accordance with the explanation given in the Sudha commentary, the intended 'adyatva' is only being the object of dependence, in the secondary sense.

analyzed: na tu carvya tvam
translated: Not being eaten.

analyzed: tat ca brahmaṇi aviruddham iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And that is not contradictory in Brahman. This is the meaning.
But in the Tattva Pradipika, it is said: 'The food of others is not the first of all beings.

analyzed: na ca tat kasya api mukhya ādyam
translated: And that is not the primary food of anyone.

analyzed: kintu tad gataḥ viṣṇuḥ eva adana phala bhūta tṛpti tuṣṭi dātṛ tvāt mukhya ādyaḥ
translated: But Vishnu present in that is the primary food, because He gives satisfaction and contentment, which are the fruits of eating.

analyzed: tasmāt upajīvya tvam eva ādya tvam
translated: Therefore, being the object of dependence is itself being the first.

analyzed: atttṛ tvāt sarva lokānām annam iti ucyate hariḥ
translated: Hari is called food because He is the owner of all worlds.

analyzed: upajīvyaḥ ca bhūtānām iti ca annam janārdanaḥ
translated: And Janardana is food because He is the support of all beings.

analyzed: iti ukteḥ iti upajīvya tvasya mukhya artha tā eva uktā
translated: Thus, it is said that the primary meaning itself is that of being the support.

analyzed: na ca virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction.
Because the Tattvapradipa was composed with the purpose of reconciling the apparent contradictions in the Upanisads, in the manner stated in the Kampana-adhyaya.

analyzed: vajra vat ityādau iva yathā kathañcid brahma paratva abhiprāyeṇa sudhā pravṛtteḥ
translated: And because the Sudha was composed with the intention that somehow or other it should be about Brahman, as in the case of the passage beginning with 'like a diamond'.

analyzed: nanu katham anna maya śabdaḥ tad prācurya arthaḥ yujyate
translated: But how can the word 'annamaya' mean 'abounding in food'?

analyzed: oṣadhībhyaḥ nnam
translated: Food from plants.

original: annātpuruṣaḥtai /u / /🔽iti prasiddhānnavikāradehamuktvā sa vā eṣa puruṣo 'nnarasamayaḥtai /u / /
analyzed: annāt puruṣaḥ taiu  iti prasiddha anna vikāra deham uktvā sa vai eṣa puruṣaḥ nna rasa mayaḥ
translated: The person from food. Taittiriya Upanishad.🔽Having spoken of the body, which is a well-known modification of food, 'That person is made of the essence of food.' Taittiriya Upanishad.

original: iti ya eva puruṣaḥ so 'nnarasamaya iti annavikārapuruṣaparāmarśādanuvādāt /
analyzed: iti yaḥ eva puruṣaḥ saḥ anna rasa mayaḥ iti anna vikāra puruṣa parāmarśāt anuvādāt
translated: The person who is referred to as 'that person' is the same as the one made of the essence of food. Thus, it is a restatement referring to the person who is a modification of food.

original: anyathā tadvirodhaḥ syādityata āha sa iti /
analyzed: anyathā tad virodhaḥ syāt iti atas āha saḥ iti
translated: Otherwise, there would be a contradiction. To this he says 'sa' (that).

analyzed: avirodhaḥ iti ākṛṣyate
translated: 'Aviruddha' (non-contradictory) is supplied.

original: tathāceti vākyena yasmādātmanaḥ ākāśādikamutpannaṃ sa eṣa puruṣa iti 'anyasya' /
analyzed: tathā ca iti vākyena yasmāt ātmanaḥ ākāśa ādikam utpannam saḥ eṣa puruṣaḥ iti anyasya
translated: And thus, by the sentence 'from that Self, space and so on have originated. He is that person', 'of another' means

analyzed: dehāt anyasya ātmanaḥ prārambhāt  parāmarśāt avirodhaḥ
translated: Because of the beginning of the Self other than the body.🔽Because of the reference, there is no contradiction.

analyzed: na parāmarśa virodhaḥ
translated: There is no contradiction with the reference.

original: kimarthamasau parāmṛśyate ityāśaṅkāpanodanāya parāmarśāditi vaktavye prārambhādityāha /
analyzed: kimartham asau parāmṛśyate iti āśaṅkā apanodanāya parāmarśāt iti vaktavye prārambhāt iti āha
translated: In order to remove the doubt as to why it is referred to, he says because of the beginning, although because of the reference should be said.

analyzed: pūrvam ātmanaḥ ākāśa ādi kāraṇatvam uktvā tasya eva anya artham
translated: Having previously stated that the Self is the cause of space and so on, for the sake of another,

analyzed: anya kāryāya anna maya ādi pañca rūpatva pradarśanāya punar prārambhāt
translated: for the sake of another effect, for the purpose of showing the five forms beginning with the one made of food, again because of the beginning.

analyzed: prakrānta tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is because of being commenced.

original: 'sa vā' / iti śrutau vaiśabdo 'vadhāraṇe prasiddhau vā /
analyzed: sa vai iti śrutau vaiśabdaḥ vadhāraṇe prasiddhau vā
translated: In the Vedic text He is, the word vai is for determination or for what is well-known.

analyzed: anna śabdaḥ bhāva pradhānaḥ
translated: The word anna is predominant in meaning.

analyzed: rasa tvam uttama tvam
translated: The state of being rasa is the state of being supreme.

analyzed: tat ca anna tva viśeṣaṇam  tathā ca yasmāt satya tva ādi lakṣaṇa upetāt ātmanaḥ ākāśa ādikam utpannam saḥ
translated: And that is a qualifier of the state of being anna.🔽And since the world beginning with space is produced from the Self endowed with the characteristics of truth and so on, He,

analyzed: ātma pada uditaḥ bhūta ādi sraṣṭā eṣaḥ
translated: the creator of beings and so on, indicated by the word Self, this,

analyzed: jīva śarīra gaḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: the person in the body of the individual soul,
the Lord who is the abode of the body, full of the six qualities, is made of the essence of food.

analyzed: uttama anna tva pūrṇaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that He is full of the state of being the supreme food.

analyzed: taittirīya bhāṣye tu annasya attṛ tva ādi
translated: But in the Taittiriya commentary, the state of being the eater etc. of food,

original: rūpasyānnamayaśarīrasya yataḥ sārabhūto viṣṇuḥ ato 'nnarasamayaḥiti annaśabdasyāvṛttyā rasaśabdasya kramavyatyāsena ca vyākhyātam /
analyzed: rūpasya anna maya śarīrasya yatas sāra bhūtaḥ viṣṇuḥ atas nna rasa mayaḥ iti anna śabdasya āvṛttyā rasa śabdasya krama vyatyāsena ca vyākhyātam  /
translated: Since Vishnu is the essence of the body made of food, which is form, therefore it is explained by the repetition of the word food and the reversal of the order of the word rasa as the essence of the taste of food.

analyzed: ye nnam brahma upāsate taiḥ
translated: Those who meditate on food as Brahman, by them.

original: ityādibrahmaśabdādbahurūpatvācca na vikāritvamavirodhaśca /🔽nanvevaṃ mayaṭchabdasyobhayārthe prayogādatrāpyubhayapakṣe doṣadarśanātpañcānāṃ mayaṭāṃ prācuryamevārtho na vikāritvamityatra kiṃ niyāmakam /
analyzed: ityādi brahma śabdāt bahu rūpa tvāt ca na vikāri tvam avirodhaḥ ca  nanu evam mayaṭ śabdasya ubhaya arthe prayogāt atra api ubhaya pakṣe doṣa darśanāt pañcānām mayaṭām prācuryam eva arthaḥ na vikāri tvam iti atra kim niyāmakam
translated: Thus, because of the word Brahman etc. and because of having many forms, there is no modification and no contradiction.🔽If so, since the word maya is used in both senses, and since the fault is seen in both cases here also, what is the determining factor here that the five mayas mean abundance only and not modification?

original: kiñcānnamayādīnāṃ pañcānāṃ brahmatābhyupagatau 'ekameva' / chā /u / /🔽ityādiśrutivirodhaḥ syāt ityata āha ye 'nnaṃ brahmeti //
analyzed: kiñca anna maya ādīnām pañcānām brahma tā abhyupagatau ekam eva chāu  ityādi śruti virodhaḥ syāt iti atas āha ye nnam brahma iti
translated: Moreover, if the five beginning with food are accepted as Brahman, there would be a contradiction with the Upanisadic text beginning with 'One only'.🔽To this he says 'Those who meditate on food as Brahman'.

analyzed: atra ādi śabdena ye prāṇam brahma upāsate
translated: Here, the word 'etc.' includes the following passages: 'Those who meditate on life as Brahman, by them' (Tai. Up. 2.1).

original: 'ānandaṃ brahmaṇo vidvān' / tai /u / /🔽'vijñānaṃ brahma cedveda' / tai /u / /
analyzed: ānandam brahmaṇaḥ vidvān  vijñānam brahma ced veda
translated: 'One who knows bliss as Brahman' (Tai. Up. 2.7).🔽'If one knows knowledge as Brahman' (Tai. Up. 2.1).

analyzed: asti brahma iti ced veda
translated: 'If one knows that Brahman exists' (Tai. Up. 2.1).

analyzed: iti vākya jātam gṛhyate
translated: These passages are included.

analyzed: asti ānanda rūpam tadvat ca
translated: There is, and it is of the nature of bliss, and so on.

analyzed: ityādi iti lupta saptamī vibhaktikam
translated: The word ādi (etc.) is a locative tatpuruṣa compound.

analyzed: ślokeṣu iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is in the verses.
The word Brahman indicates hearing it.

original: evaṃ pradarśite hetudvaye 'dhyāhṛtahetudvārānvayayogye krameṇa sādhye āha na vikāritvamiti /
analyzed: evam pradarśite hetu dvaye dhyā hṛta hetu dvāra anvaya yogye krameṇa sādhye āha na vikāri tvam iti
translated: Having thus shown the two reasons, which are suitable to be connected in order through the implied reasons, he says non-modification etc.

analyzed: mayaṭām arthaḥ iti niścīyate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is it is ascertained that the meaning of maya is that.

analyzed: avirodhaḥ virodha abhāvaḥ
translated: Non-contradiction is the absence of contradiction.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ pyarthaḥ  tathā ca ittham yojanā ye brahma
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of api (also).🔽And thus the construction is like this: Those who are food, Brahman etc.

analyzed: ityādiṣu anna maya ādīn pratyudāhṛta ślokeṣu anna maya ādi viṣaya tvena brahma śabdāt
translated: In the verses quoted with reference to the food-made etc., the word Brahman refers to the food-made etc.

original: brahmaśabdaśravaṇādanyathāsiddhatatsamabhivyāhārāt ubhayathāpi sambhavatāṃ mayaṭāṃ prācuryamevārthaḥ na vikāritvamiti niścīyate /
analyzed: brahma śabda śravaṇāt anyathā asiddha tad samabhivyāhārāt ubhayathā api sambhavatām mayaṭām prācuryam eva arthaḥ na vikāri tvam iti niścīyate
translated: From the hearing of the word Brahman, from the co-occurrence of that which is established otherwise, it is ascertained that the meaning of maya, which is possible in both ways, is abundance only, not modification.

analyzed: atas na niyāmaka ākṣepaḥ yuktaḥ
translated: Therefore, the objection of lack of restriction is not appropriate.

analyzed: evam ekasya eva brahmaṇaḥ bahu rūpa tvāt ca  śabdāt ekasya eva bahu rūpa tva vacana upapatteḥ ekam eva
translated: In the same way, because the same Brahman has many forms,

analyzed: iti śruti virodhaḥ pi na iti
translated: the statement of the same having many forms is appropriate. Therefore, there is no contradiction with the scripture the one only etc.

analyzed: pūrvam tasmin eva prasiddha brahma śabda abhyāsāt
translated: Previously, it was said: Because of the repetition of the well-known word Brahman in that very [Upaniṣad].

analyzed: iti uktvā atra brahma śabdāt iti etāvat mātra ukteḥ prayojanam tu brahma śabdasya ānanda vijñāna mayayoḥ iva anyeṣu abhyāsa abhāvāt teṣu asiddhi parihāreṇa
translated: Here, the purpose of stating only as much as because of the word Brahman is that, unlike in the case of bliss and consciousness, the word Brahman is not repeated in other [Upaniṣads], so in order to avoid the non-establishment of Brahman in them,

analyzed: brahma śabda śravaṇa rūpa sarva sādhāraṇa hetu artha kathanam eva eti uktam candrikāyām
translated: it is said in the Candrikā that the statement of the common reason in the form of hearing the word Brahman itself is the purpose.

analyzed: na ca pṛthak kalpanā yuktā
translated: And the assumption of a separate [meaning] is not proper.

analyzed: sva rūpam ca yujyate pracura prakāśaḥ raviḥ iti vat
translated: And the nature [of the word] is proper, like the sun, which is abundant light.

analyzed: atra anyaiḥ ānanda mayaḥ eva brahma
translated: Here, others have said that Brahman is bliss alone.

analyzed: tad gata mayaṭaḥ eva prācurya artha tā
translated: The suffix maya in that [bliss] itself has the meaning of abundance.

analyzed: anna maya ādayaḥ tu kośāḥ
translated: But the food-made and others are sheaths.

analyzed: tad gatānām mayaṭām ca vikāra artha tvam iti uktam
translated: And the suffixes maya in them have the meaning of modification.

analyzed: tat ayuktam iti āha na ca iti
translated: That is not proper, he says with and not etc.

analyzed: prāya paṭita maya ṭām pṛthak kalpanā
translated: The assumption of a separate [meaning] of the suffix maya, which is used mostly,

analyzed: artha dvaividhya kalpanā na yuktā
translated: the assumption of a twofold meaning is not proper.

original: tataścānnamayādīnāṃ madhye ekasyaiva brahmatvakalpanā ca na yuktaiva /
analyzed: tatas ca anna maya ādīnām madhye ekasya eva brahma tva kalpanā ca na yuktā eva
translated: And therefore, the assumption that only one among the food-made and others is Brahman is not proper at all.

analyzed: prāya pāṭha virodhena kliṣṭa tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is troublesome due to contradicting the general usage.

analyzed: yaḥ tu vādī anna maya ādīnām pañcānām api abrahmatām brūte
translated: But the disputant who maintains that the five, beginning with the one consisting of food, are not Brahman,

original: sa tu sūtrakāreṇaiva pūrvapakṣīkṛta iti na tatpakṣaṃ pratyākṣipadbhāṣyakāraḥ /
analyzed: sa tu sūtrakāreṇa eva pūrvapakṣīkṛtaḥ iti na tad pakṣam pratyākṣipat bhāṣyakāraḥ
translated: he is made the pūrvapakṣin by the author of the Sūtras himself; hence the author of the Bhāṣya does not refute his opinion.

original: tattvapradīpe tu na ceti vākyaṃ na ca māyinā pṛthakkalpanā 'satyaṃ jñānamanantaṃ brahma' / tai /u / /
analyzed: tattvapradīpe tu na ca iti vākyam na ca māyinā pṛthak kalpanā satyam jñānam anantam brahma
translated: But in the Tattva-prakāśa, the sentence beginning with na ca (of the Bhāṣya) is explained thus: The illusionist does not make a separate assumption (of the five sheaths being Brahman). Brahman is truth, knowledge, and infinite. (Tai. Up. 2.1.)

analyzed: tasmāt vai etasmāt ātmanaḥ
translated: Therefore, from this Self (Tai. Up. 2.6).

analyzed: iti atra brahma ucyate
translated: Here Brahman is spoken of.

original: annamayādayaḥ pañcakośā mitho bhinnāḥ teṣāṃ brahmaśabdoktatve 'pi abrahmatvam/
analyzed: anna maya ādayaḥ pañca kośāḥ mithas bhinnāḥ teṣām brahma śabda ukta tve pi abrahma tvam
translated: The five sheaths beginning with the one consisting of food are mutually distinct. Even though they are spoken of as Brahman, they are not Brahman.

analyzed: antya pucchasya eva brahmatvam
translated: Only the final sheath is Brahman.

analyzed: anna maya ādi atikramaḥ mokṣaḥ
translated: Transcending the one consisting of food etc. is liberation.

analyzed: vakṣyamāṇānām cakṣuḥ śrotra manaḥ vācām na anna maya ādiṣu anuvṛttiḥ
translated: The eye, ear, mind, and speech mentioned later do not continue in the one consisting of food etc.

analyzed: annam brahma iti vyajānāt
translated: He knew food to be Brahman (Tai. Up. 2.2).

analyzed: ityādau pañcamasya ānandasya brahmatvam
translated: Here, the fifth bliss is Brahman.

analyzed: etam ānanda mayam ātmānam upasaṅkramya
translated: Having approached this blissful Brahman Self (Tai. Up. 2.5).

analyzed: iti etasmāt brahma ānanda maya ādi atikrama nirguṇa vākyāt pṛthak eva imān lokān
translated: From this passage speaking of the attributeless Brahman, which transcends the blissful Brahman etc., separately, these worlds (Tai. Up. 2.6).

original: ityādiko vākyaśeṣaḥ saguṇavākyaikavākyatāpannaḥ tatphalapratipādaka ityādikā yuktā /
analyzed: ityādikaḥ vākyaśeṣaḥ sa guṇa vākya eka vākya tā āpannaḥ tad phala pratipādakaḥ iti ādikā yuktā
translated: The remaining passage beginning with this is proper as stating its result, being syntactically connected with the passage about Brahman having qualities.

analyzed: ukta hetubhiḥ atyanta asaṅga tatvāt iti antya pakṣa nirākaraṇa para tayā vyākhyātam
translated: It has been explained as being intended to refute the last view, because it is utterly incoherent due to the reasons stated.

analyzed: na ca evam etad virodhaḥ ṭīkāyāḥ iti vācyam
translated: And it should not be said that this is contradictory to the commentary.

original: bhāṣyakāraḥ savistaraṃ viśiṣya na nirācakhyāviti ṭīkābhiprāyābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: bhāṣyakāraḥ sa vistaram viśiṣya na nirācakhyau iti ṭīkā abhiprāya abhyupagamāt
translated: Because it is accepted that the meaning of the commentary is that the author of the Bhāṣya did not refute it in detail.

analyzed: nanu na brahmaṇi pracura ānandaḥ  ityādi prayogaḥ yujyate  tasya ānanda ādi svarūpa tvāt ghṛta pracuraḥ odanaḥ
translated: But it is not proper to use expressions like Brahman is not full of bliss,🔽because bliss etc. are of the nature of Brahman itself. For such expressions are used only in cases of difference, as in rice with plenty of ghee.

original: ityādau bhedasthala eva tathā prayogādityata āha svarūpe ceti /
analyzed: ityādau bheda sthale eva tathā prayogāt iti atas āha svarūpe ca iti
translated: To this he says And in the case of the nature itself, etc.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ pyarthaḥ
translated: The word ca (and) has the meaning of api (also).

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ śabda padārthaḥ
