translated: The word iti (thus) is the meaning of the word śabda (word).

analyzed: raviḥ iti vat
translated: As in the case of the sun, etc.

analyzed: iti anantaram vyavahāraḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Usage is to be supplied after this.

analyzed: svarūpe ca iti asya āvṛttiḥ
translated: And in the case of the nature itself, this is repeated.

original: tathā ca prakāśasvarūpe 'pi sūryabimbe viśeṣabalāt 'pracuraprakāśo raviritivat' /
analyzed: tathā ca prakāśa svarūpe sūrya bimbe viśeṣa balāt pracura prakāśaḥ raviḥ iti vat
translated: And thus, even in the case of the sun-disk, which is of the nature of light, due to the force of the particular attribute, the sun is full of light, etc.,

original: evaṃrūpavyavahāravat ānandādisvarūpe 'pi harau viśeṣeṇa tathā vyavahāro yujyata eveti na tadanupapattirityarthaḥ /
analyzed: evaṃrūpa vyavahāra vat ānanda ādi svarūpe pi harau viśeṣeṇa tathā vyavahāraḥ yujyate eva iti na tad anupapattiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that just as there is usage in the form of such and such, so too usage in that way with regard to Hari in the form of bliss etc. is quite proper. Thus there is no inconsistency in that.

analyzed: tad hetu vyapadeśāt ca
translated: And because of the declaration of the cause of that.

analyzed: kaḥ hi eva anya ātmakaḥ prāṇyāt
translated: For who else, being of another nature, would breathe?

original: yadeṣa ākāśa ānando na syāt' / tai / / iti /
analyzed: yat eṣa ākāśaḥ ānandaḥ na syāt iti
translated: If this space were not bliss.

analyzed: ānanda maya mātrasya viṣṇu tve
translated: If the bliss-filled one were only Vishnu.

original: hetvantararūpaṃ prācuryameva mayaḍartha ityatra ca hetuṃ pratipādayatsūtramupanyasyati taddhetviti //
analyzed: hetu antara rūpam prācuryam eva mayaṭ arthaḥ iti atra ca hetum pratipādayat sūtram upanyasyati tad hetu iti
translated: And in this, the meaning of maya is abundance itself, which is a different reason. The sutra, which teaches the reason for that, is presented. The declaration of the cause of that.

analyzed: ānanda mayaḥ iti tat tu iti ca anuvartate
translated: The word that is repeated in bliss-filled and truth.

analyzed: tat ityasya avṛttiḥ
translated: That is repeated.

analyzed: sa ca asau hetuḥ ca iti api vigrahaḥ
translated: And that is the cause, is another analysis.

analyzed: tathā ca na kevalam brahma śabda abhyāsāt
translated: And thus, not only because of the repetition of the word Brahman,

analyzed: kintu tad hetu vyapadeśāt
translated: but also because of the declaration of the cause of that.

original: tasminnānandamayaprakaraṇe tasya viṣṇoḥ tasmin anandapūrṇatvenānandamayatve prācuryasyaiva
analyzed: tasmin ānanda maya prakaraṇe tasya viṣṇoḥ tasmin ananda pūrṇa tvena ānanda maya tve prācuryasya eva
translated: In that section on the bliss-filled one, of that Vishnu, in the fullness of bliss, in the abundance itself being the meaning of maya,

analyzed: mayaṭ artha tve ca tad hetu vyapadeśāt loka ceṣṭaka tva ākhya hetu ukteḥ ca ānanda pūrṇa tvena eva ānanda maya śabda vācyaḥ
translated: because of the declaration of the cause of that, because of the statement of the reason called the activity of the world, the bliss-filled one is spoken of by the word bliss-filled only in terms of fullness of bliss.

original: viṣṇureveti sūtravṛttimabhipretya tameva hetuvyapadeśaṃ darśayati kohīti /🔽'yat' / yadā yadi 'eṣaḥ ākāśaḥ' /
analyzed: viṣṇuḥ eva iti sūtra vṛttim abhipretya tam eva hetu vyapadeśam darśayati  yat yadā yadi eṣaḥ ākāśaḥ
translated: With the intention of the aphorism and commentary that it is Viṣṇu alone, he shows that very designation of the reason, beginning with 'ko hi'.

original: āsamantātprakāśamāno viṣṇurānandaḥ pūrṇānando na syāt tadāsau lokaṃ na pravartayediti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: ā samantāt prakāśamānaḥ viṣṇuḥ ānandaḥ pūrṇa ānandaḥ na syāt tadā asau lokam na pravartayet iti śeṣaḥ
translated: 'Yadi' - if 'this space' - Viṣṇu, who shines everywhere, were not bliss, not full bliss, then he would not cause the world to function - this is the remainder.

analyzed: ānanda udrekam antareṇa kāraṇa antara abhāvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that without the abundance of bliss, he would function due to the absence of any other cause.

analyzed: yadi asau na lokam pravartayet
translated: If he would not cause the world to function,

analyzed: tadā kaḥ hi eva anyāt
translated: then 'ko hi' - who would cause the world to function?

analyzed: kaḥ vā janaḥ lokam ceṣṭayet
translated: 'Kaḥ' - what person would cause the world to function?

analyzed: kaḥ ca prāṇyāt
translated: 'Kaḥ' - who would cause to breathe?

analyzed: dharma ādau ca kaḥ pravartayet
translated: And who would cause to engage in dharma and so on?

analyzed: na kaḥ pi
translated: No one.

analyzed: anyasya asvātantryāt iti taittirīya bhāṣya ṭīkā rītyā śruti arthaḥ
translated: Because others are not independent - this is the meaning of the Taittirīya Bhāṣya Tīkā.

original: sudhāyāṃ tu ṇyarthānandarbhāvena na ko 'pi lokikīṃ vaidikīṃ pravṛttiṃ kuryāditi vyākhyātam /
analyzed: sudhāyām tu lokikīm vaidikīm pravṛttim kuryāt iti vyākhyātam
translated: But in Sudhā, it is explained that no one would perform worldly or Vedic activity by the meaning of 'ko' as the absence of bliss.

analyzed: iti iti asya iti tad hetu vyapadeśāt iti anvayaḥ
translated: The word 'iti' is connected with 'iti tadhetuvyapadesāt' (therefore, because of the designation of the reason).

analyzed: māntravarṇikam eva ca gīyate
translated: And it is sung as described in the mantra.

analyzed: brahma a vidā āpnoti param
translated: 'One who knows Brahman attains the highest.'

analyzed: iti sūcayitvā satyam jñānam anantam
translated: Having thus indicated, he says, 'Truth, knowledge, infinite is Brahman' (Tai. 2.1).🔽

analyzed: iti mantra varṇa lakṣitam param eva brahma śabda anusandhānāt gīyate
translated: Having thus indicated, it is sung as the supreme Brahman itself, characterized by the words of the mantra Brahman is true, knowledge, infinite, by the connection with the words.

analyzed: yat uktam brahma śabdāt ānanda maya ādīnām viṣṇu tvam iti na tat yuktam
translated: What was said, that the words Brahman and so on prove that the blissful and so on are Viṣṇu, is not correct.

original: brahmaśabdasya aparabrahmaṇi jīve 'pyupapatteḥ/🔽tasya parabrahmaṇi mukhyatve 'pi viṣṇoḥ ānandamayāvayavatvoktyādinā bādhakenāmukhyārthasyaiva
analyzed: brahma śabdasya apara brahmaṇi jīve pi upapatteḥ  tasya para brahmaṇi mukhya tve viṣṇoḥ ānanda maya avayava tva ukti ādinā bādhakena amukhya arthasya eva
translated: Because the word Brahman is applicable to the lower Brahman and the individual soul also.🔽Even though it is primary in the supreme Brahman, it is still possible to take it as having a secondary meaning due to the contradiction of Viṣṇu being stated as a part of the blissful one and so on.

analyzed: grahaṇa upapatteḥ iti āśaṅkām pariharat ānanda maya ādi śabda vācyasya viṣṇu tve yukti antaram
translated: In order to remove this doubt, he states another reason for the fact that Viṣṇu is denoted by the words blissful and so on.

analyzed: vadan sūtram paṭhitvā vyācaṣṭe māntravarṇikam iti
translated: Having recited the sūtra, he explains it with That which is indicated by the words of the mantra.

analyzed: yatas ityādau yojyam
translated: Yataḥ and so on should be connected.

analyzed: na te iti pratijñā anuvartate
translated: Na te continues the promise.

original: tathā ca yataḥ 'satyaṃ jñānamanantaṃ brahma' / tai /u / /
analyzed: tathā ca yatas satyam jñānam anantam brahma
translated: And thus, because Brahman is true, knowledge, infinite, TaittU

analyzed: iti mantravarṇe  mantra akṣare tad ātmaka vākya viśeṣe lakṣitam
translated: In the words of the mantra,🔽Not indicated in the particular sentence consisting of those mantra syllables.

analyzed: lakṣaṇavat tayā proktam eva param eva brahma na a lakṣitam
translated: It is said to have the nature of definition, but is not unindicated.

analyzed: na aparam iti eva arthaḥ
translated: It is not other than that. This is the meaning.

analyzed: anna maya ādi śabdaiḥ gīyate
translated: Are spoken of by the words ‘made up of food’ etc.

analyzed: pratipādyate atas pi ānanda maya ādayaḥ na apare
translated: Are taught. Therefore also the ‘made up of bliss’ etc. are not different.

analyzed: kintu param eva brahma iti yojanā
translated: But the highest Brahman only, is the meaning. This is the construction.

original: kuto 'nnamayādiśabdairmantravarṇalakṣitasyaiva pratipādanaṃ jñāyata ityata uktam śabdānusandhānāditi /
analyzed: kutas nna maya ādi śabdaiḥ mantra varṇa lakṣitasya eva pratipādanam jñāyate iti atas uktam śabda anusandhānāt iti
translated: From where is it known that the teaching is of the passage of the mantra alone, indicated by the words ‘made up of food’ etc.? In answer to this it is said: ‘Because of the connection of the words.’🔽‘Of the words’—of the words ‘truth, knowledge, infinite’ and of the words ‘made up of food’ etc.

original: 'śabdānāṃ' / satyaṃ jñānamanantam ityevaṃrūpāṇām annamayādiśabdānāṃ ca arthānusandhānāt jātāt 'anusandhānāt'🔽ekārthatvajñānādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: śabdānām satyam jñānam anantam iti evaṃrūpāṇām anna maya ādi śabdānām ca artha anusandhānāt jātāt anusandhānāt  ekārtha tva jñānāt iti arthaḥ
translated: ‘Because of the connection’—because of the knowledge of the identity of meaning. This is the meaning.

original: mantravarṇe 'pi brahmetyevoktatvātkathaṃ tadarthānāmapyannamayādiśabdānāṃ parabrahmārthatājñaptirityata āha brahmaviditi /
analyzed: mantravarṇe pi brahma iti eva ukta tvāt katham tad arthānām api anna maya ādi śabdānām para brahma artha tā jñaptiḥ iti atas āha brahma vid iti
translated: Since in the passage of the mantra also Brahman only is mentioned, how is it known that the words ‘made up of food’ etc. also, which have the same meaning, have the highest Brahman for their meaning? In answer to this he says ‘Brahman’ etc.

analyzed: pravṛtte iti śeṣaḥ
translated: ‘Has proceeded’ is the remainder.

analyzed: asya buddhyā viviktena mantra varṇa padena anvayaḥ
translated: It is connected with the words ‘passage of the mantra’ which is distinguished by the intellect.

original: tathā ca yato 'brahmavidāpnoti param' / tai /u / / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca yatas brahma vidā āpnoti param iti
translated: And thus, since ‘the knower of Brahman attains the highest’ (Tai. Up. 2.1),

original: parabrahmatajjñānatatprāptīḥ sūcayitvā saṅkṣepeṇaktvā tatra prāptaśaṅkāpanodāya pravṛtto mantravarṇaḥ /
analyzed: para brahma tad jñāna tad prāptīḥ sūcayitvā saṅkṣepeṇa aktvā tatra prāpta śaṅkā apanodāya pravṛttaḥ mantra varṇaḥ
translated: having indicated the highest Brahman, its knowledge, and its attainment, the passage of the mantra has proceeded to remove the doubt that has arisen there, by briefly stating it.

analyzed: tatas tra lakṣitam param
translated: Then, it is understood that the highest Brahman is indicated here.🔽The meaning is that it is known to be Brahman itself.

analyzed: brahma eva iti jñāyate iti arthaḥ sūtre
translated: In the sutra,

analyzed: ānanda maya ādiḥ tat tu iti ca anuvartate
translated: the truth beginning with the one consisting of bliss is continued.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ yathā iti arthe yukti sayuccaye ca
translated: The word ca (and) means in the same way and in addition.

original: tathā ca na kevalaṃ brahmaśabdādevānandamayādiviṣṇvākhyaṃ parabrahmaiva nāparabrahmetyavasīyate /🔽kintu yato māntravarṇikaṃ 'satyaṃ jñānam' /
analyzed: tathā ca na kevalam brahma śabdāt eva ānanda maya ādi viṣṇu ākhyam para brahma eva na apara brahma iti avasīyate  kintu yatas māntravarṇikam satyam jñānam
translated: And thus, it is not only concluded that the one consisting of bliss etc. is only the highest Brahman called Vishnu, and not the lower Brahman, on the basis of the word Brahman alone.🔽But rather, because the highest Brahman, which is described by the Vedic sentence Truth, knowledge

original: iti vedavākyena lakṣaṇavattayā proktaṃ paraṃ brahamaivānnamayādiśabdaiḥ 'gīyate' /
analyzed: iti veda vākyena lakṣaṇavat tayā proktam param gīyate
translated: as having the characteristic of being mentioned in the mantra, is sung (glorified) by the words beginning with the one consisting of food,

analyzed: pratipādyate ca
translated: and is also taught.

analyzed: atas tad samākhyānāt ārthikāt api iti sūtra arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the sutra is: because of the designation, even though it is figurative.

analyzed: brahma vid para brahma jñānī param
translated: One who knows Brahman (is one) who knows the highest Brahman. The highest

analyzed: paramam brahma āpnoti
translated: (is the highest) Brahman.

original: parabrahmaprāptikāmaḥ parabrahma jānīyāt iti śruteḥ phalito 'rthaḥ /
analyzed: para brahma prāpti kāmaḥ para brahma jānīyāt iti śruteḥ phalitaḥ rthaḥ
translated: One who desires to attain the highest Brahman should know the highest Brahman. This is the meaning of the Upanishad.

analyzed: kim tat brahma iti śaṅkāyām satyam ityādi pravṛttam
translated: When there is doubt as to what that Brahman is, the passage beginning with Truth is uttered.

analyzed: tatra satya śabdena uktam yat gati jīvana nāśa prāpaka tvam tat eva anna maya prāṇa maya śabdābhyām ucyate
translated: There, what is said by the word Truth - the state of being the cause of the destruction of going, life, and attainment - that is expressed by the words the one consisting of food and the one consisting of life-breath.

analyzed: ananta śabdena uktam deśataḥ kālataḥ vastutas ca aparicchinna tvam
translated: The word 'ananta' (infinite) indicates the non-limitation in space, time and substance.

original: paramātmānantaḥ pūrṇānandatvādityānandamayaśabdenopapādyata iti satyādiśabdānāṃ annamayādiśabdānāṃ cakārthatvam anusandheyam /
analyzed: paramātmā anantaḥ pūrṇa ānanda tvāt iti ānanda maya śabdena upapādyate iti satya ādi śabdānām anna maya ādi śabdānām cakārtha tvam anusandheyam
translated: The word 'anandamaya' (full of bliss) explains the infinity of the Supreme Self as being due to His being full of bliss. Thus the meaning of the words 'sat' (existence) etc. and 'annamaya' (consisting of food) etc. should be understood.

original: atra deśānantyaṃ nāma anavadhikaparimāṇatvam /🔽kālānantyaṃ nāma anavacchinnasattākatvam /
analyzed: atra deśa ānantyam nāma anavadhika parimāṇa tvam
translated: Here, spatial infinity means having an infinite magnitude.🔽Temporal infinity means having existence without beginning or end.

analyzed: vastu ānantyam nāma aparicchinna saṅkhyā guṇa karma vigrahavat tvam
translated: Substantial infinity means having an unmeasured number, qualities, actions and forms.

original: na cāvayavatvavirodhaḥ /🔽'sa śiraḥ / sa dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣaḥ /
analyzed: na ca avayava tva virodhaḥ  sa śiraḥ sa dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with being a part.🔽'He is the head. He is the right wing.

analyzed: saḥ uttaraḥ pakṣaḥ
translated: He is the left wing.

analyzed: saḥ ātmā
translated: He is the body.

analyzed: sa puccham iti tasya eva avayava tva ukteḥ caturvedaśikhāyām
translated: He is the tail.' Thus, in the Chaturveda-shikha, it is said that He Himself is the part.

analyzed: nanu viṣṇoḥ ānanda maya tvam na yuktam
translated: Now, it is not proper for Vishnu to be the one full of bliss.

analyzed: tasya tad avayava tvāt
translated: Because He is a part of that (Brahman).

analyzed: na ca asiddhiḥ
translated: And it is not unestablished.

analyzed: brahma puccham iti ukteḥ
translated: Because it is said that Brahman is the tail.

analyzed: avayavinaḥ ca avayava tva virodhāt iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: And because it is contradictory for an entity with parts to be a part, therefore it is said 'na ca' (and not).

analyzed: tasya ityāt kṛṣyate
translated: 'Tasyah' (His) is extracted.

analyzed: tasya viṣṇoḥ ānanda maya tve tad avayava tva ukti virodhaḥ na iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no contradiction in stating that Viṣṇu is the bliss-body and is a part of that [bliss].

original: avayavatve ca avayavitvasya virodho 'pi neti caśabdārthaḥ /
analyzed: avayava tve ca avayavi tvasya virodhaḥ api na iti caśabda arthaḥ
translated: And the meaning of the word ca [in the commentary] is that even the contradiction of being a whole and being a part is not [a contradiction].

original: kuta ityato 'vayavina evāvayavatvasyāvayavitvasya ca śrutyuktatvenāvayavyāderavayavādyabhedādityāśayena tāṃ śrutimudāharati sa iti /
analyzed: kutas iti atas vayavinaḥ eva avayava tvasya avayavi tvasya ca śruti ukta tvena avayavi ādeḥ avayava ādi abhedāt iti āśayena tām śrutim udāharati saḥ iti
translated: Why? From this, with the idea that the very whole is stated to be a part and a whole by scripture, and that therefore the whole, etc. are not different from the part, etc., he cites that scripture, saying He [is the head].

analyzed: saḥ nārāyaṇaḥ śiraḥ śīrṣam
translated: He [is] Nārāyaṇa. The head [is] the head.

analyzed: śiraḥ saḥ iti vā
translated: Or the head is he.

analyzed: evam uttaratra api vyākhyeyam
translated: This should be explained in the same way in the following [passages] as well.

analyzed: dvitīya ādi tad śabdāḥ smṛti anusārāt pradyumna ādi parāḥ
translated: The second and following that [words] refer to Pradyumna and so on, according to the Smṛtis.

analyzed: pakṣaḥ bāhuḥ uttaraḥ  savyaḥ ātmā
translated: The wing [is] the arm. The upper [is] the left.

analyzed: madhya dehaḥ puccham
translated: The self [is] the middle body. The tail [is] the feet.

analyzed: pādau iti iti asya evaṃrūpāyām catur veda śikhāyām tasya eva avayavi bhūtasya eva viṣṇoḥ avayava tva ukteḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in this four-Veda-crest [hymn], which is of this form, it is said that only that very whole Viṣṇu is a part.

analyzed: eva śabdena avayava avayavi bhedaḥ nivāritaḥ
translated: The word eva [in the commentary] excludes the difference between part and whole.

analyzed: evam avayavasya avayavi tve na kevalam iyam śrutiḥ
translated: Thus, in the case of a part being a whole, this scripture [is not the only one to state this].

original: kintu bhāṣye upalakṣaṇayā gṛhītā 'padaṃ pucchaṃ pratiṣṭhā vai puruṣaḥ' /🔽iti tattvapradīpodāhṛtaśrutirapi pramāṇatayā grāhyā /
analyzed: kintu bhāṣye upalakṣaṇayā gṛhītā padam puccham pratiṣṭhā vai puruṣaḥ  iti tattvapradīpa udāhṛta śrutiḥ api pramāṇa tayā grāhyā
translated: But in the commentary, the statement The tail is the foot, the male is the support quoted in the Tattvapradīpa, should also be accepted as an authoritative scripture by implication.

analyzed: asmin pakṣe bhāṣya gata avayava śabdaḥ vayavi paraḥ
translated: In this view, the word part in the commentary is a derivative from the root ṛśi meaning to break and refers to the whole.

original: śiro nārāyaṇaḥ pakṣo dakṣiṇassavya eva ca /
analyzed: śiraḥ nārāyaṇaḥ pakṣaḥ dakṣiṇaḥ savyaḥ eva ca
translated: Nārāyaṇa is the head, the right wing, and the left wing,

analyzed: pradyumnaḥ ca aniruddhaḥ ca sandohaḥ vāsudevakaḥ
translated: Pradyumna and Aniruddha are the testicles, and Vāsudeva is the penis.

analyzed: sandohaḥ vāsudevaḥ śiraḥ vā
translated: Nārāyaṇa and the testicles are Vāsudeva, or the head is also Vāsudeva,

original: pucchaṃ saṅkarṣaṇaḥ proktaḥ eka eva tu pañcadhā //
analyzed: puccham saṅkarṣaṇaḥ proktaḥ ekaḥ eva tu pañcadhā
translated: The tail is said to be Saṅkarṣaṇa, but he is one only in five ways.

analyzed: aṅga aṅgi tvena bhagavān krīḍate puruṣottamaḥ
translated: The Supreme Being plays as the parts and the whole.

analyzed: aiśvaryāt na virodhaḥ ca cintyaḥ tasmin janārdane
translated: There is no contradiction to be considered in that Janārdana due to his lordship.

analyzed: atarkye hi kutas tarkaḥ tu aprameye kutas pramā
translated: For how can there be reasoning in what is inconceivable, or how can there be a means of knowledge in what is unmeasurable?

analyzed: iti bṛhatsaṃhitāyām
translated: Thus it is said in the Brhatsaṃhitā.

original: avayavina avayavatvaṃ viruddhamityāśaṅkāṃ śrutyā parihṛtyātra smṛtiṃ cāha śira iti /
analyzed: avayavinaḥ avayava tvam viruddham iti āśaṅkām śrutyā parihṛtya atra smṛtim ca āha śiraḥ iti
translated: Fearing that the whole being a part is contradictory, having resolved it by scripture, here he quotes a Smṛti text, beginning with the head.

original: atra citrādau likhyamānanavanārīrūpe avayavibhūtānāmanekastrīṇāmekadehāvayavatvaṃ tathā nārāyaṇādipañcarūpāṇāṃ ekāvayavatvamucyate/
analyzed: atra citra ādau likhyamāna nava nārī rūpe avayavi bhūtānām aneka strīṇām eka deha avayava tvam tathā nārāyaṇa ādi pañca rūpāṇām eka avayava tvam ucyate
translated: Here, in the picture etc. being drawn, the many women who are the parts of the whole, have the nature of one body, and similarly the five forms of Narayana etc. are said to have the nature of one part.

analyzed: ādyaḥ caḥ pakṣa samuccaye
translated: The first ca is for the inclusion of the alternative views.

analyzed: rūpayoḥ paraspara samuccaye dvau
translated: The two cas are for the inclusion of the two forms.

analyzed: avayavi bhūtaḥ eva nārāyaṇaḥ śiraḥ iti eva śabda anvayaḥ
translated: Narayana, who is the part of the whole, is the head - this is the connection with the word eva.

analyzed: evam avayavi bhūtaḥ pradyumnaḥ dakṣiṇaḥ pakṣaḥ bāhuḥ
translated: Similarly, Pradyumna, who is the part of the whole, is the right wing, the arm.

analyzed: aniruddhaḥ savyaḥ
translated: Aniruddha is the left.

analyzed: vāsudevaḥ sandohaḥ
translated: Vasudeva is the 'sandhu',

analyzed: madhya dehaḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: the middle body - this is the connection.

analyzed: api vā iti nipāta samudāyaḥ pakṣa antare
translated: The group of particles api ve is for another alternative.

analyzed: pūrvasmin pakṣe nārāyaṇasya
translated: In the previous view, Narayana is

analyzed: śīrṣa tvam vāsudevasya madhya deha tvam
translated: the head, and Vasudeva is the middle body.

original: asmin pakṣe tu tadaṃśe vaiparītyamityupāsanābhedena pakṣabhedoktiḥ/
analyzed: asmin pakṣe tu tad aṃśe vaiparītyam iti upāsanā bhedena pakṣa bheda uktiḥ
translated: But in this view, there is a reversal in that part - thus, the difference in views is stated by the difference in meditation.

analyzed: saṅkarṣaṇaḥ tu ubhayatra puccham
translated: However, Sangkarshana is the 'tail' in both cases.

analyzed: pādau proktaḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: The feet are said to be - this is the connection.

analyzed: tuśabdena dvi rūpa tvam suparṇa rūpa tva viśeṣaḥ vā jñāyate
translated: The word tu indicates the twofold nature or the specific nature of being Suparna.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha ekaḥ iti
translated: What then? Therefore it is said: one.

analyzed: evam puruṣottamaḥ
translated: Thus, Purushottama.

analyzed: kṣara akṣara puruṣābhyām uttamaḥ bhagavān kṛṣṇaḥ ekaḥ eva
translated: The Supreme Lord Kṛṣṇa is superior to the perishable and imperishable Puruṣas, He is 'one alone'.

original: pañcadhā vibhaktaḥ eka evāyavaiḥ abhinna eva na tu bhinnaḥ /
analyzed: pañcadhā vibhaktaḥ ekaḥ eva āyavaiḥ abhinnaḥ eva na tu bhinnaḥ
translated: He is divided into five aspects, He is one alone, not different from the parts, but not different.

original: 'aṅgatvena' / avayavatvena 'aṅgitvena' /🔽avayavitvena prakāreṇa tadbhāvaṃ prāptaḥ krīḍata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: aṅga tvena avayava tvena aṅgi tvena  avayavi tvena prakāreṇa tad bhāvam prāptaḥ krīḍate iti arthaḥ
translated: 'As parts' means as components, 'as the whole' means as the composite.🔽The meaning is that He assumes that state in the form of the composite and plays.

analyzed: itthaṃbhūta lakṣaṇe tṛtīyā
translated: The instrumental case is used in the sense of 'such a nature'.

original: nanvastavevaṃ tāvatā na virodhaparihāro jāta ityata āha aiśvaryāditi /
analyzed: nanu astava ivam tāvatā na virodha parihāraḥ jātaḥ iti atas āha aiśvaryāt iti
translated: But even if this is so, the contradiction has not been resolved, so it is said: 'due to His lordship'.

analyzed: tasmin avayavi bhāva ādi āpanne janārdane tasmin
translated: In Janārdana, who has the nature of the composite and so on, 'in Him',

analyzed: avayava tva ādau tad viṣaye virodhaḥ
translated: there is no contradiction regarding His being a part and so on, which is the object of that [nature].

analyzed: saha anavasthāna rūpaḥ na cintyaḥ
translated: It is inconceivable, in the form of co-existence.

analyzed: na kenacid kalpyaḥ
translated: It should not be imagined by anyone.

analyzed: kutas aiśvaryāt
translated: Why? 'Due to His lordship'.

analyzed: īśvara sāmarthyāt tayoḥ ekatra avasthāna rūpa avirodha upapatteḥ īśvara śaktiḥ ca aghaṭita ghaṭikā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Because the non-contradiction in the form of co-existence of those two is possible due to the power of the Lord, and the power of the Lord is not dependent on anything else, this is the idea.

analyzed: evam tasmin
translated: Thus, 'in Him',

analyzed: avayave tasmin
translated: in the part, 'in Him',

analyzed: avayavi tve na virodhaḥ
translated: there is no contradiction in being the composite.

analyzed: kutas ekaikasya avayavasya sarva īśvara tvāt iti api vyākhyeyam
translated: Why? It should also be explained that it is because each part is the Lord of all.

original: evaṃ na virodha ityetat avayavāvayavinorabhede 'yamavayavī ayam avayava iti bhedavyavahāravirodho 'pi netyapi vyākhyeyam /
analyzed: evam na virodhaḥ iti etat avayava avayavinoḥ abhede yam avayavī ayam avayavaḥ iti bheda vyavahāra virodhaḥ na iti api vyākhyeyam
translated: Thus there is no contradiction. This should also be explained as follows: Even in the non-difference of the whole and the parts, there is no contradiction in the usage of difference, such as this is the whole, this is the part.

analyzed: tatra hetuḥ tu viśeṣa balāt śakti vyakti bhāvāt iti caśabdena sūcitaḥ
translated: The reason for this is indicated by the word ca (and) as follows: From the manifestation of potency due to the power of the distinctions.

analyzed: atas eva caśabdaḥ nukta samuccaya arthaḥ aiśvaryāt ca iti anveti
translated: For this very reason, the word ca (and) has the meaning of including what is not stated, and it is connected with from lordship.

analyzed: kiñca kim tarka anya pramāṇena avayavinaḥ vayava tvam avayavasya avayavi tvam ca viruddham
translated: Moreover, is the fact that the whole has parts and the part has a whole contradictory to any other means of knowledge other than reasoning?

analyzed: uta avayavī na avayavaḥ avayavi tvāt
translated: Or is the whole not a part because it is a whole?

analyzed: avayavaḥ vā na avayavī avayava tvāt loka vat iti tarka pada ukta anumānena
translated: Or is the part not a whole because it is a part, like in the world, by inference stated by the word tarka (reasoning)?

analyzed: na ādyaḥ siddha tvāt
translated: Not the first, because it is not established.

analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ iti āha atarkyaḥ iti
translated: Not the second, he says inconceivable.

original: 'hi' / yasmādatarkyaḥ tasmāt 'atarkye' /🔽tarkāgocare bhagavati tadviṣaye 'tarkaḥ' /🔽avayavī nāvayavaḥ avayavitvāt ityādirūpo hetuḥ 'kutaḥ' /
analyzed: hi yasmāt atarkyaḥ tasmāt atarkye  tarka agocare bhagavati tad viṣaye tarkaḥ  avayavī na avayavaḥ avayavi tvāt ityādi rūpaḥ hetuḥ kutas
translated: Hi (for), because it is inconceivable, therefore in the inconceivable.🔽In the inconceivable, which is beyond the scope of reasoning, the argument🔽The whole is not a part because it is a whole, and so on, is either a proof or a refutation. Kutaḥ (from where)?

analyzed: sādhakaḥ bādhakaḥ vā na iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is not.

original: kiñca loke parimitaśaktitva eva virodhadarśanāt viṣṇorvirodhopayogiparimitaśaktiśūnyatvāt tarkyatvāṅgīkāre 'pi na virodha
analyzed: kiñca loke parimita śakti tve eva virodha darśanāt viṣṇoḥ virodha upayogi parimita śakti śūnyatvāt tarkya tva aṅgīkāre pi na virodha
translated: Moreover, since contradiction is seen only in the world in the case of limited power, and since Vishnu is devoid of limited power which is useful for contradiction, even if the acceptance of reasonability is admitted, there is no contradiction.

analyzed: iti āha aprameyaḥ iti  aprameye deśa kāla guṇaiḥ aparicchinne bhagavati pramā
translated: To this he says 'incomprehensible'.

analyzed: etāvat eva sāmarthyam na atas dhikam iti śakti paricchedaḥ kutas
translated: In the incomprehensible, i.e. in the Lord who is not limited by space, time and qualities, there is 'measurement', i.e. the determination of power as 'this much is the power, not more than this'. 'How' is this?

original: netyarthaḥ /🔽tathā ca paroktatarkasya sopādhikatvenāpramāṇatvānna virodhitvamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: na iti arthaḥ  tathā ca para ukta tarkasya sopādhika tvena apramāṇa tvāt na virodhi tvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is 'no'.

analyzed: anena atarkya  iti asya asat tarka agocaraḥ iti arthaḥ iti uktam bhavati
translated: And thus, since the reasoning stated by the opponent is not a means of valid knowledge due to being fallacious, it does not have the nature of contradicting. This is the idea.🔽By this, it is said that the meaning of 'incomprehensible' is 'not the object of false reasoning'.

analyzed: iti bṛhatsaṃhitāyām ityasya tasya eva avayava tva ukteḥ  iti anuṣaktena anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning of 'in the Brihat-samhita' is connected with the following: 'because it is said to be a part of that'.

analyzed: rasa śabdena viśeṣaṇāt tat tat sāra bhūtam cit mātram eva ucyate
translated: By the word 'rasa', only the pure consciousness which is the essence of each is referred to, due to its being a qualifier.

analyzed: idam iti ca dṛśyamāna sannihita tvāt
translated: And 'this' is used because it is seen to be present.

original: nanu yaduktaṃ sa vā iti vākye 'sya paramātmana eva parāmarśaḥ na annātpuruṣaḥ ityuktadehasyeti tadayuktam /
analyzed: nanu yat uktam sa vai iti vākye sya paramātmanaḥ eva parāmarśaḥ na annāt puruṣaḥ iti ukta dehasya iti tat ayuktam
translated: Now, what was said in the sentence 'That is He' that this refers only to the supreme Self, not to the body mentioned in the sentence 'The person is made of food', that is incorrect.

original: ātmano dūrasthatvāddehasya sa samāpasthatvātsamīpoktaparityāgena dūrasthaparāmarśāṅgīkāre kāraṇābhāvāt /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ dūra stha tvāt dehasya sa samāpa stha tvāt samīpa ukta parityāgena dūra stha parāmarśa aṅgīkāre kāraṇa abhāvāt
translated: The body is far away from the self, and he is near, so there is no reason to accept the reference to the far away self by abandoning the near one mentioned.

original: kiñca puruṣapadena prakṛtasyaiva puruṣapadenoktatvāt ātmanaśca tena aprakṛtatvātpuruṣapadena parāmarśāyogaḥ / na ca
analyzed: kiñca puruṣa padena prakṛtasya eva puruṣa padena ukta tvāt ātmanaḥ ca tena aprakṛta tvāt puruṣa padena parāmarśa ayogaḥ na ca
translated: Moreover, since the self is mentioned by the word puruṣa itself, and since the self is not the subject, it is not proper to refer to it by the word puruṣa. And it cannot be said that

analyzed: prakṛtim puruṣam ca evam viddhi anādī ubhau api
translated: Know that both Prakriti and Purusha are beginningless.

original: puruṣaḥ prakṛtistho hi bhuṅkte prakṛtijān guṇān //
analyzed: puruṣaḥ prakṛti sthaḥ hi bhuṅkte prakṛti jān guṇān
translated: For the Purusha, dwelling in Prakriti, enjoys the qualities born of Prakriti.

original: iti vākyadvayasthapuruṣapadena ekavidhenaiva vyavasthāyā paramātmajīvayoruktigrahaṇavadihāpi ekavidhenaiva dviruktena puruṣapadena vyavasthayārthadvayoktyaṅgīkāro
analyzed: iti vākya dvaya stha puruṣa padena ekavidhena eva vyavasthāyā paramātma jīvayoḥ ukti grahaṇa vat iha api ekavidhena eva dviruktena puruṣa padena vyavasthayā artha dvaya ukti aṅgīkāraḥ
translated: Just as the two statements are understood to refer to the supreme self and the individual self by the word puruṣa used in the same way, so here also the two meanings are accepted to be stated by the word puruṣa used twice in the same way.

analyzed: stu iti vācyam  tatra duḥkha anubhavitṛ tva rūpa bhedaka śruti vat prakṛte bhedaka abhāvena annāt puruṣaḥ iti atra dehaḥ
translated: This cannot be said.

original: sa vā ityatra ca paramātmaivocyata iti vyavasthāṅgīkārāyogādityata āha raseti //
analyzed: sa vā iti atra ca paramātmā eva ucyate iti vyavasthā aṅgīkāra ayogāt iti atas āha rasa iti
translated: There, as there is no difference-maker in the statement The Purusha is from food, like the scriptural statement that distinguishes the experiencer of suffering, it is not proper to accept the distinction that the body is mentioned there and the supreme self is mentioned in the statement That is.🔽Therefore, he says rasa etc.

analyzed: sa vai eṣaḥ iti vartate
translated: That is continues.

analyzed: tat iti āvartate
translated: The word tat (that) is repeated.

analyzed: evam ucyate iti ca
translated: And the word ucyate (is said).

analyzed: anyat vihāya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is having abandoned other.

original: tathā ca sa vā iti vākyena cideva cinmātraṃ brahmacaitanyameva ucyate parāmṛśyate na dehaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca sa vā iti vākyena cit eva cit mātram brahma caitanyam eva ucyate parāmṛśyate na dehaḥ
translated: And thus, by the sentence That is..., only consciousness, pure consciousness, Brahman, pure intelligence, is referred to, not the body.

analyzed: na ca tasya dūra ukti virodhaḥ
translated: And it should not be said that there is a contradiction with the statement of distance,

analyzed: puruṣa padena aprakṛta tva virodhaḥ ca iti vācyam  yatas tat ātmanaḥ ākāśaḥ sambhūtaḥ
translated: or a contradiction with being not the subject due to the word puruṣa (person).

original: ityākāśādipuruṣāntaśabdairuktaṃ tattatsārabhūtam ākāśādipadārthaśreṣṭhabhūtaṃ cinmātraṃ brahmaiva sa vā iti parāmarśavākyenocyate /
analyzed: iti ākāśa ādi puruṣa anta śabdaiḥ uktam tat tat sāra bhūtam ākāśa ādi padārtha śreṣṭha bhūtam cit mātram brahma eva sa vā iti parāmarśa vākyena ucyate
translated: Because it is said by the words beginning with ākāśa (space) and ending with puruṣa (person) that that which is the essence of that, the best of the meanings of the words beginning with ākāśa (space), is Brahman, pure consciousness, alone, and it is said by the sentence referring to it as That is....

original: evaṃ tarhi puruṣapadena dvayorapi prakṛtatvādubhayaparāmarśo 'yamastviti na ca vācyam /
analyzed: evam tarhi puruṣa padena dvayoḥ api prakṛta tvāt ubhaya parāmarśaḥ yamaḥ tu iti na ca vācyam
translated: If that is so, then it should not be said that this is a reference to both, because both are the subject, due to the word puruṣa (person).

original: yataḥ tatsārabhūtaṃ puruṣasārabhūtaṃ cinmātraṃ brahmaivānyadehādikaṃ vihāya saḥ iti parāmarśavākyenocyate /
analyzed: yatas tat sāra bhūtam puruṣa sāra bhūtam cit mātram brahma eva anya deha ādikam vihāya saḥ iti parāmarśa vākyena ucyate
translated: Because it is said by the sentence referring to it as That, having abandoned other bodies etc., is..., that which is the essence of that, the essence of the person, is Brahman, pure consciousness, alone.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha rasa iti
translated: Why is it so? To this he says rasa (essence) etc.

analyzed: rasa śabda ghaṭita anna rasa maya śabdena viśeṣaṇāt sāra anna maya tva rūpa puruṣa viśeṣaṇa abhidhānāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The word rasa is used to specify the essence of food, which is the essence of the person.

original: jaḍāmiśrajīvavilakṣaṇabrahmabodhārthaṃ mātrapadam /🔽rasaśabdena rasaśabdārthena mukhyatvena viśeṣaṇāt viśeṣitatvāt annatvarūpaviśeṣaṇasyeti vā /
analyzed: jaḍa amiśra jīva vilakṣaṇa brahma bodha artham mātra padam  rasa śabdena rasa śabda arthena mukhya tvena viśeṣaṇāt viśeṣita tvāt anna tva rūpa viśeṣaṇasya iti vā
translated: The word mātra is used to indicate Brahman, which is different from the inert and mixed jīva.🔽Or, by the word rasa, which is the primary meaning of the word rasa, the attribute of being food is specified.

analyzed: tatas ca atra anna rasaḥ nna sāraḥ nna śabda artheṣu mukhya āttṛ tva ādi lakṣaṇaḥ tad pracuraḥ iti sudhā ukteḥ
translated: And therefore, here, the essence of food, the essence of food, the essence of food, is abundant with that characteristic of being the primary enjoyer, etc., as stated in the Sudha commentary.

analyzed: ṭīkāyām caitanya mātram brahma eva iti anvayaḥ
translated: And in the commentary, the meaning is that consciousness alone is Brahman.

analyzed: nanu anuvāka antare anna maya prāṇa maya manaḥ maya vijñāna maya ānanda mayāḥ me śuddhi antām yājñikī
translated: Now, in another anuvāka (section of the Veda), it is prayed: May the food-made, life-made, mind-made, knowledge-made, and bliss-made (bodies of mine) be purified. May the sacrificial (rites be performed).

analyzed: iti prārthita śuddhīnām anna maya ādi kośānām abhidhānam
translated: The names of the food-made and other sheaths, which are to be purified, are mentioned.

original: kintu / tattatsārabhūtaṃ tattatkośaniyāmakaṃ tadgataṃ brahmacaitanyameva ucyate /
analyzed: kintu tat tat sāra bhūtam tat tat kośa niyāmakam tad gatam brahmacaitanyam eva ucyate
translated: But the Brahman-consciousness present in each of them, which is the essence of each of them and which governs each of the sheaths, is itself spoken of.

original: kutaḥ / atra sa vā eṣaḥ tai /u / /
analyzed: kutas atra sa vā eṣaḥ taiu
translated: Why? Because here it is said That is He (Tai. Up. 2.1).

original: ityādau raso vai saḥ ityante cānnamayādīnāṃ kośavyāvṛttyarthaṃ tadbhedārthameva rasaśabdena viśeṣaṇāt viśeṣitatvādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: ityādau rasaḥ vai saḥ iti ante ca anna maya ādīnām kośa vyāvṛtti artham tad bheda artham eva rasa śabdena viśeṣaṇāt viśeṣita tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: In the beginning, with the words that bliss and at the end, with the words that is the essence, the essence of food and so on are qualified by the word essence itself, in order to distinguish them from the sheaths and to distinguish them from each other. This is the meaning.
Being qualified in the beginning means being composed.

analyzed: tathā ca śabda antara nyāyena anna maya ādi apekṣayā anna rasa maya ādīnām bhedaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, by the method of using another word, the difference of the essence of food and so on from the essence of food and so on, in relation to the essence of food and so on, is the meaning.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a mere indication.

analyzed: vyavahita ākāśa ādi kāraṇa ātma parāmarśinā tad śabdena ca viśeṣaṇāt iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should also be seen that it is because it is qualified by the word that, which refers to the distant cause, the Self of space and so on.

analyzed: nanu yadi paridṛśyamāna dehaḥ eva na anna mayaḥ
translated: If the visible body itself is not made of food,

original: kintu brahmaiva tasyaiva ca saḥ ityādau parāmarśaḥ /
analyzed: kintu brahma eva tasya eva ca saḥ ityādau parāmarśaḥ
translated: but Brahman itself is referred to in the beginning with the words that is He,

analyzed: tadā tasya idam eva śiraḥ
translated: then the statement this is its head (Tai. 2.1)

analyzed: iti pratyakṣa nirdeśaḥ na upapadyate
translated: is not logically possible.

original: na ca vācyam upaniṣaddraṣṭā munirbrahmāparokṣīkṛtya pratyakṣato nirdiśatīti /
analyzed: na ca vācyam upaniṣad draṣṭā muniḥ brahma a parokṣīkṛtya pratyakṣataḥ nirdiśati iti
translated: And it cannot be said that the sage who sees the Upanishad, having made Brahman directly perceptible, points it out directly.

analyzed: tathā sati tena a parokṣīkṛta prāṇa maya ādau api tathā nirdeśa prasaṅgāt
translated: If that were so, then in the case of the essence of life and so on, which are made directly perceptible by Him, there would be the contingence of a similar statement.

original: kiñca svasyāparokṣato jñātatvena śabdānapekṣaṇāt upadeśyapuruṣāṇāṃ cāparokṣāyogyatvānnirdeśavaiyarthyamityata tadasyetyapi vyākhyeyam /
analyzed: kiñca svasya aparokṣataḥ jñāta tvena śabda anapekṣaṇāt upadeśya puruṣāṇām ca aparokṣa ayogya tvāt nirdeśa vaiyarthyam iti atas tat asya iti api vyākhyeyam
translated: Moreover, since it is known by itself through non-perception, and since the persons to be instructed are not capable of non-perception, the instruction is useless. Therefore, it should also be explained as this of that.

analyzed: tathā ca asya anna maya bhagavat śiraḥ pakṣa ādeḥ dṛśyamāna pratyakṣa siddha deha śiraḥ pakṣa ādau
translated: And thus, in the visible directly perceived body, head, and wings of the food-made Lord,

analyzed: vastra varma antarvarti jānu vīra avayava vat sannihita tvāt samyak niyāmaka tvena sthita tvāt
translated: like the knee and hero parts that are present inside the cloth and armor, it exists as the perfect controller,

original: lakṣaṇayā brahmaśirasi idamiti nirdeśo yujyata iti yojanā /
analyzed: lakṣaṇayā brahmaśirasi idam iti nirdeśaḥ yujyate iti yojanā
translated: and the designation this in the head of Brahman is proper through secondary meaning. This is the construction.

analyzed: lakṣaṇā bījam śakya sambandham darśayitum dṛśyamānā iti
translated: To show the possible connection, the seed of secondary meaning, it is said in the visible.

original: tathā ca vastraprāvṛte varmāntargate vā jānunīdaṃ jānviti vyavahāravadayamapi vyavahāro yujyata eveti na tadvirodha iti bhāvaḥ / 🔽ananyo 'pyanyaśabdena tathaiko bahurūpavān /
analyzed: tathā ca vastra prāvṛte varma antargate vā jānuni idam jānu iti vyavahāra vat ayam api vyavahāraḥ yujyate eva iti na tad virodhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ  ananyaḥ pi anya śabdena tathā ekaḥ bahu rūpavān
translated: And thus, like the usage this knee for knees covered by cloth or inside armor, this usage is also proper. This is the meaning, that there is no contradiction with that.

analyzed: procyate bhagavān viṣṇuḥ aiśvaryāt puruṣottamaḥ
translated: Even though not different, the one Lord Vishnu, the best of beings, is said to be different by the word other and to have many forms due to His lordship.

analyzed: iti brahmāṇḍe purāṇe
translated: Thus in the ancient Purana Brahma-Andam.

analyzed: nanu anna maya ādīnām pañcānām brahma tā anupapannā tasmāt vai etasmāt anna rasa mayāt
translated: But it is not proper that the five, beginning with the one consisting of food, are Brahman, because they are said to be different from each other, as in the text, Therefore, from this one consisting of the essence of food,

original: anyo 'ntara ātmā prāṇamayaḥ' / tai /u / /🔽iti parasparaṃ bhinnatvenoktatvāt /🔽evamekasyaiva brahmaṇo bahurūpatvāt na 'ekameva' /
analyzed: anyaḥ ntara ātmā prāṇa mayaḥ taiu  iti parasparam bhinna tvena ukta tvāt  evam ekasya eva brahmaṇaḥ bahu rūpa tvāt na ekam eva
translated: another inner self, consisting of breath (Tai. Up. 2.1).

original: iti śrutivirodhaḥ ityapyayuktamapramitatvādityata āha ananya iti //
analyzed: iti śruti virodhaḥ iti api ayuktam apramita tvāt iti atas āha ananyaḥ iti
translated: Thus, because Brahman has many forms, it is not contradictory to the Upanisadic text, One only (Br. 4.4.22). This is also improper because it is not established. Therefore he says non-different.

analyzed: apiḥ yadi api iti adi arthe
translated: The word api means even though.

analyzed: tathāśabdaḥ samuccaye
translated: The word tatha means and.

analyzed: tathā ca puruṣottamaḥ bhagavān viṣṇuḥ  an anyaḥ pi
translated: And thus, the Lord, the best of beings, is Vishnu.🔽Even though non-different,

original: abhinno 'pi anyo bhinna iti śabdena procyata /
analyzed: abhinnaḥ anyaḥ bhinnaḥ iti śabdena procyata
translated: even though non-distinct, he is said to be different by the word.

analyzed: tathā yadi api ekaḥ tathā api bahu rūpavān bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: Thus, even though one, he has many forms. This is the meaning.

analyzed: katham iti atas ubhaya ghaṭakam āha
translated: How is this? To explain this, which includes both, he says

analyzed: aiśvaryāt iti  acintya śakteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: by the power of lordship.🔽The meaning is: of one whose power is inconceivable.

analyzed: upalakṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a metaphor.

analyzed: anna maya ādi pañca kośa gata anyatva antara tva ādayaḥ dharmāḥ tad gata bhagavat rūpeṣu upacaryante iti api draṣṭavyam
translated: It should also be seen that the attributes of otherness, difference, etc., which are found in the five sheaths beginning with the one consisting of food, are figuratively applied to the forms of the Lord found there.

analyzed: atas eva tṛtīye sthāna bhedāt aiśvaryāt ca
translated: For this very reason, in the third (chapter), it is said, Because of the difference of place and lordship (3.29.25).

analyzed: iti bhāṣye sthāna bheda ākhyam hetu antaram abhihitam
translated: Thus, in the Bhāṣya, another reason called the difference of location is stated.

analyzed: taittirīya bhāṣye tu bheda abhāve pi saṅkhyā viśeṣa yukta tvāt anya tva uktiḥ iti uktam
translated: But in the Taittirīya Bhāṣya, it is said that even in the absence of difference, otherness is stated due to the presence of a particular number.

original: brahmāṇḍe purāṇe ityanantaram uktatvānna virodha ityanvayaḥ/
analyzed: brahmāṇḍe purāṇe iti anantaram ukta tvāt na virodhaḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that there is no contradiction because it is stated after in the Purāṇa called Brahṇḍa.

analyzed: na ca ukta prāptyā viriñca ādiḥ ucyate
translated: And Viriñca and others are not stated due to the attainment mentioned.

analyzed: na itaraḥ nupapatteḥ  /
translated: The other is not so, because of impossibility.

analyzed: na hi anya jñānāt mokṣaḥ upapadyate
translated: For liberation is not possible through the knowledge of anything else.

analyzed: tam evam vidvān amṛtaḥ iha bhavati
translated: One who knows Him thus becomes immortal in this world.

original: nānyaḥ panthā ayanāya vidyate' / tai / ā / /
analyzed: na anyaḥ panthāḥ ayanāya vidyate taiḥ ā
translated: There is no other path for going. Taitt. Āra.

analyzed: iti hi uktam
translated: For this is said.

original: nanu brahmaśabdasya sādhāraṇatvāt taddhetuvyapadeśasya viṣṇuniṣṭhatayā spaṣṭapratibhānāt🔽mantravarṇasamākhyāyāśca anyaliṅgādibhyo durbalatvena sāvakāśatvāt ananyathāsiddhahetvantarasya
analyzed: nanu brahma śabdasya sādhāraṇa tvāt tad hetu vyapadeśasya viṣṇu niṣṭha tayā spaṣṭa pratibhānāt  mantra varṇa samākhyāyāḥ ca anya liṅga ādibhyaḥ durbala tvena sa avakāśa tvāt ananyathāsiddha hetu antarasya
translated: But since the word Brahman is common, and since the designation of its cause is clearly manifested as belonging to Viṣṇu,🔽and since the designation based on the words of the mantra is weak due to other indications such as other liṅgas, and is therefore inconclusive, and since there is no other reason that is not otherwise established,

original: cābhāvādānandamayādayo viriñcādaya eva santviti śaṅkāṃ pariharatsūtramavatārayati na ceti //🔽co 'vadhāraṇe /
analyzed: ca abhāvāt ānanda maya ādayaḥ viriñca ādayaḥ eva santu iti śaṅkām pariharat sūtram avatārayati na ca iti  caḥ va dhāraṇe
translated: let Anantamaya and others be Viriñca and others. To remove this doubt, the sūtra begins with not so.🔽The word ca is for emphasis.

analyzed: viriñca ādayaḥ iti anena anveti
translated: It is connected with Viriñca and others.

analyzed: tathā ca ukta prāptyā  brahma śabda śatānanda tva aṣṭamūrti tva bahu bhāva ādi rūpa ukta prāpakena anna maya ādi śabdaiḥ viriñca ādiḥ eva ucyate
translated: And thus by what is obtained by statement.

analyzed: na viṣṇuḥ iti na
translated: By the statements that are obtained in the form of hundreds of names of Brahman, having a hundred anandas, having eight forms, being manifold, etc., Virincha and others alone are spoken of by the words beginning with annamaya, not Vishnu.🔽No.

analyzed: kintu
translated: But.

analyzed: viṣṇuḥ eva taiḥ ucyate
translated: Vishnu alone is spoken of by them,

analyzed: na viriñca ādiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: not Virincha and others. This is the meaning.

original: kuto neti hetvākāṅkṣāyāṃ sūtramupanyasya pratijñāṃśasya na cetyādibhāṣyeṇaiva vyākhyātatvātsautramananyathāsiddhahetumeva vyācaṣṭe netara
analyzed: kutas na iti hetu ākāṅkṣāyām sūtram upanyasya pratijñā aṃśasya na ca ityādi bhāṣyeṇa eva vyākhyāta tvāt sautram ananyathāsiddha hetum eva vyācaṣṭe
translated: When there is expectation of a reason for why not, the sutra is presented. Since the part of the proposition has already been explained by the commentary beginning with not, he explains only the reason that is not otherwise established in the sutra with not that other.

analyzed: iti
translated: Not that other etc.

analyzed: hi śabdaḥ hetau
translated: The word hi is a reason.

analyzed: anya jñānāt
translated: From the knowledge of another.

analyzed: viṣṇu anya viriñca ādi jñānāt
translated: From the knowledge of Virincha and others who are other than Vishnu.

analyzed: yadi api ayam na itaraḥ iti ukta sādhye na hetuḥ  tathā api tasya ananyathāsiddha tva upapādaka tvāt hetutva uktiḥ
translated: Although this is not a reason for the conclusion stated as not that other,🔽nevertheless, it is stated as a reason because it explains the non-otherwise-established nature of that.

original: asya hetuvākyasya adhyāhṛtahetuvākyadvārā na ceti pratijñayānvayaḥ /
analyzed: asya hetu vākyasya adhyāhṛta hetuvākya dvārā na ca iti pratijñayā anvayaḥ
translated: This reason statement is connected with the proposition not through an implied reason statement.

analyzed: anena ānanda maya ādiḥ viṣṇoḥ itaraḥ viriñca ādiḥ na kutas
translated: By this, it is said that annamaya and others are not different from Vishnu, but Virincha and others are. Why?

analyzed: brahma vidā āpnoti param
translated: One who knows Brahman attains the highest (Tai. Up. 2.1).

analyzed: sarvam vai te nnam āpnuvanti
translated: They obtain all food (Tai. Up. 2.1).

analyzed: sarvam eva te āyuḥ yanti
translated: They go to all that is his life.

analyzed: ityādinā ānanda maya ādeḥ mukti hetu jñāna viṣaya tva ukteḥ
translated: Thus, etc.

analyzed: tasya ca itaratra anupapatteḥ
translated: And because that is not possible in the other.

analyzed: ayogāt iti sūtra arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: The meaning of the sutra is stated as: because of incompatibility.

original: viṣṇujñānādeva mokṣo netarajñānādityetatkuta ityata āha tamiti /
analyzed: viṣṇu jñānāt eva mokṣaḥ na itara jñānāt iti etat kutas iti atas āha tam iti
translated: The meaning is: Liberation is only from the knowledge of Vishnu, not from the knowledge of others. From where is this? Therefore it is said: tam.🔽Hi, because. Tam eva.

analyzed: hi yasmāt tam evam
translated: Thus, etc.

original: iti śrutyā mokṣasya viṣṇujñānādanya upāyo nāstītyuktam /
analyzed: iti śrutyā mokṣasya viṣṇu jñānāt anyaḥ upāyaḥ na asti iti uktam
translated: By this scripture it is said that there is no other means to liberation than the knowledge of Vishnu.

analyzed: tasmāt viṣṇoḥ anya jñānāt mokṣaḥ na upapadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, liberation from the knowledge of Vishnu other than is not possible. This is the meaning.

analyzed: śruti arthaḥ tu prāk eva uktaḥ
translated: But the meaning of the scripture has been stated earlier itself.

analyzed: bheda vyapadeśāt ca
translated: And because of the designation of difference.

analyzed: te ye śatam prajāpateḥ ānandāḥ taiḥ
translated: Those who are the hundred joys of Prajapati, by them.

analyzed: adṛśye nātmye nirukte nilayane bhayam pratiṣṭhām vindate
translated: In the unseen, non-self, undefined, unfixed abode, one finds fearlessness and support.

analyzed: atha saḥ bhayam gataḥ bhavati taiḥ
translated: Then he has gone to fearlessness. By them.

analyzed: sa yaḥ ca ayam puruṣe taiḥ
translated: He who is this person, by them.

analyzed: ityādi bheda vyapadeśāt
translated: Thus, etc. Because of the designation of difference.

original: hetvantareṇa brahmādīnāmānandamayatvaṃ parākurvatsūtraṃ paṭhitvā vyācaṣṭe bhedeti /
analyzed: hetu antareṇa brahma ādīnām ānanda maya tvam parākurvat sūtram paṭhitvā vyācaṣṭe bheda iti
translated: The sutra refuting the Brahman etc. as the embodiment of bliss by another reason is recited and explained as follows: by difference, etc.

original: atra pūrvahetusamuccāyakena caśabdenānandamayādirnetara iti pratijñāvākyānuvṛtterapi sūcanāt /
analyzed: atra pūrva hetu samuccāyakena caśabdena ānanda maya ādiḥ na itaraḥ iti pratijñā vākya anuvṛtteḥ api sūcanāt
translated: Here, by the word ca (and) which indicates the combination of the previous reasons, it also indicates the continuation of the sentence the one consisting of bliss, etc., is not the other.

original: tadvihāya sūtroktaṃ bhedavyapadeśaṃ darśayati te ye śatamiti //
analyzed: tat vihāya sūtra uktam bheda vyapadeśam darśayati te ye śatam iti
translated: Leaving that aside, he shows the distinction taught in the sutra, saying Those who are a hundred...🔽The word etc.

analyzed: ādi śabdaḥ ānandāḥ  iti atas paraḥ yojyaḥ  tatra ādyena te ye śatam
translated: should be added after bliss.

analyzed: iti asya pūrva uttara taittirīya vākyāni gṛhyante
translated: Among them, the first one includes the Taittiriya passages before and after Those who are a hundred...

analyzed: dvitīyena yatas vācaḥ nivartante
translated: The second one includes From which speech turns back,

analyzed: a prāpya manasā saha
translated: not reaching it along with the mind,

analyzed: ānandam brahmaṇaḥ vidvān
translated: knowing the bliss of Brahman,

analyzed: ityādi
translated: those who are... and so on.

analyzed: yat vā sakṛt śrutaḥ eva sarva saṅgrāhakaḥ
translated: Or, it can be heard only once and includes everything.

analyzed: anena na ānanda mayaḥ itaraḥ viriñcaḥ kutas
translated: By this, the other Viriñca is not the one consisting of bliss. Why?

analyzed: bheda vyapadeśāt  viriñcasya te ye śatam taiu
translated: Because of the distinction taught.🔽Of Viriñca, it is said in Those who are a hundred... and Those who are...

analyzed: ityādinā rudrāt śataguṇa ānanda tva ukteḥ  ānanda mayasya ca yatas vācaḥ
translated: that he has a hundred times the bliss of Rudra.🔽And of the one consisting of bliss, it is said in From which speech turns back...

analyzed: ityādinā aparimita ānanda tva ukteḥ
translated: and so on that he has unlimited bliss.

analyzed: evam na rudraḥ
translated: Thus, Rudra is not [the one consisting of bliss].

analyzed: tasya hiraṇyagarbhāt śatāṃśoḥ nānanda tva ukteḥ
translated: Because it is said that he has a hundred times less bliss than Hiranyagarbha.

analyzed: na api prakṛti ādayaḥ
translated: Nor are Prakriti and others.

analyzed: adṛśyena ātmye
translated: In By the invisible Self...
In the passage beginning with 'prakriti', because of the mention of distinguishing attributes such as the nature of independence which is not suitable for prakriti etc.

analyzed: na api ānanda mayaḥ brahma ādi jīva samudāyaḥ  tasya sa yaḥ ca ayam
translated: Nor is the aggregate of individual souls beginning with Brahma made of bliss.🔽Because of the mention of distinguishing attributes such as the state of all individual souls, high and low, in the passage 'and he who is this',

original: iti apakṛṣṭotkṛṣṭasarvajīsthitirūpabhedakadharmokteḥ jīvasamudāyasya cānevaṃvidhatvāditi sūtrārtha ukto bhavati /
analyzed: iti apakṛṣṭa utkṛṣṭa sarva jī sthiti rūpa bhedaka dharma ukteḥ jīva samudāyasya ca anevaṃvidha tvāt iti sūtra arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: and because the aggregate of individual souls is not of such a nature. This is the meaning of the sutra.

original: ete ca sarve vyapadeśāḥ taittirīyaśrutigatāḥ /🔽tatra 'prajāpatiḥ śivaḥ śepho liṅgamityabhidhīyate' /
analyzed: ete ca sarve vyapadeśāḥ taittirīya śruti gatāḥ  tatra prajāpatiḥ śivaḥ śephaḥ liṅgam iti abhidhīyate
translated: And all these designations are found in the Taittiriya Upanishad.🔽There, according to the Shaiva Purana statement 'Prajapati, Shiva, Shepha are called Linga',

analyzed: iti śaiva purāṇa vacanāt prajāpateḥ
translated: the meaning of the first sentence is that 'of Prajapati',

analyzed: rudrasya ye śatam
translated: of Rudra, 'those which are a hundred',

analyzed: śataguṇitāḥ ānandāḥ te brahmaṇaḥ
translated: the blisses multiplied by a hundred, 'of Brahma',

analyzed: caturmukhasya ekaḥ ānandaḥ iti prathama vākyasya arthaḥ
translated: of the four-faced one, is one bliss.

analyzed: adṛśye sākalyena ajñeye anātmye
translated: 'In the invisible', which is not knowable in its entirety, 'in the non-self',

original: ātmanaḥ ime ātmyāḥ jīvagīṇāḥ na vidyante ātmyāḥ yasmin so 'nātmyaḥ tasmin jīvaguṇavidhure /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ ime ātmyāḥ jīva gīṇāḥ na vidyante ātmyāḥ yasmin saḥ na ātmyaḥ tasmin jīva guṇa vidhure
translated: in which the self-related, the individual souls, do not exist, which is devoid of the qualities of individual souls, that is the non-self.

original: athavā ātmanaḥ svāmino 'yamātmyaḥ svāmisambandhī sa netyanātmyaḥ tasmin /
analyzed: athavā ātmanaḥ svāminaḥ yam ātmyaḥ svāmi sambandhī sa na iti anātmyaḥ tasmin
translated: Or, in the self-related, which belongs to the self, the master, that is not, in that which is devoid of the self-related.

analyzed: svāmi rahitaḥ iti yāvat
translated: That is, devoid of the Lord.

analyzed: anirukte sākalyena nirvacana agocare
translated: In the 'unspecified', that which is not the object of verbal expression in its entirety.

analyzed: anilayane an anya āśraye ānanda maya śabda vācye viṣṇau tad viṣaye yaḥ dhikārī abhayam
translated: In the 'unfixed', in the 'bliss-filled' Vishnu, who is not dependent on anything else, the one who is qualified 'obtains fearlessness'.

analyzed: yathā bhavati tathā dhyāna rūpām pratiṣṭhām
translated: As it happens, he finds 'abiding' in the form of meditation.

analyzed: sthitim vindate prāpnoti  karoti iti yāvat  atha anantaram saḥ  upāsakaḥ abhayam
translated: He attains, that is, he accomplishes.

analyzed: bhaya rahitam bhagavantam gataḥ
translated: 'Then', afterwards, 'he', the worshipper, 'has gone' to the fearless, that is, the fear-free Lord.

analyzed: prāptaḥ bhavati iti dvitīya bheda vyapadeśasya arthaḥ  puruṣe puruṣa pada upalakṣita apakṛṣṭa jīveṣu yaḥ
translated: This is the meaning of the designation of the second difference.

analyzed: ayam ānanda mayaḥ viṣṇuḥ asti  yaḥ ca āditye
translated: 'In the person', in the inferior living beings indicated by the word 'person', 'he', this bliss-filled Vishnu, exists.

analyzed: āditya pada upalakṣita utkṛṣṭa jīveṣu asti saḥ  ubhayatra sthitaḥ viṣṇuḥ ekaḥ
translated: And 'he who is in the sun', in the superior living beings indicated by the word 'sun', exists.

analyzed: abhinnaḥ iti tṛtīya bheda vyapadeśasya arthaḥ
translated: Vishnu, who is present in both, is 'one', non-different. This is the meaning of the designation of the third difference.

analyzed: yatas vācaḥ ityādiḥ tu prāk eva vyākhyātaḥ
translated: 'From which the words' etc. has already been explained earlier.

analyzed: na ca tat tvam asi chā
translated: And there is no contradiction with the Upanisadic texts such as 'That thou art' (Chandogya 6.8.7),

analyzed: aham brahma asmi bṛ 🔽ityādi śruti virodhaḥ
translated: 'I am Brahman' (Brhadaranyaka 1.4.10), etc.

analyzed: nāmāni sarvāṇi yam āviśanti
translated: All names enter into him.

analyzed: bhāllaveya śruti
translated: The Bhallāveya Śruti

analyzed: iti tad tad śabda vācya tva ukteḥ
translated: Thus, because it is said that it is denoted by such and such words.

analyzed: nanu astu ānanda mayaḥ param brahma
translated: But let Ānandamaya be the Supreme Brahman.

original: tathāpi tena kathaṃ brahmādīnāṃ bhedaḥ sambhavati /🔽tadbhedasya 'tattvamasi' /
analyzed: tathā api tena katham brahma ādīnām bhedaḥ sambhavati  tad bhedasya tat tvam asi
translated: Even so, how can the difference of Brahmā and others be possible by that?

analyzed: ityādi śruti viruddha tvāt iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: Because that difference is contradicted by the Śruti passage That thou art (Ch. 6.8.7), etc. To this he says not etc.

analyzed: bheda vyapadeśasya iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder is of the designation of difference.

analyzed: caḥ samuccaye
translated: The word ca (and) is for inclusion.
Because only the designation of difference, which is included in the removal of the doubt of contradiction, accomplishes the intended meaning.

analyzed: evam anyatra api  tvam tat brahma asi iti advaita rīti ādya
translated: It is the same in other places also.

analyzed: śruti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Śruti passage beginning with You are that Brahman is in the non-dualistic way.

analyzed: dvatīyasyāḥ tu aham smi iti
translated: But the second is I am non-different from Brahman.

analyzed: ādyam uddālakena śvetaketum pratyupadiṣṭam chandoga vākyam
translated: The first is the Chāndogya passage taught by Uddālaka to Śvetaketu.

analyzed: dvitīyam bṛhadāraṇyake vāmadeva uktam
translated: The second is stated by Vāmadeva in the Bṛhadāraṇyaka.

analyzed: atra ubhayatra api viśiṣṭayoḥ aikya asambhavāt tattvam aham brahma padaiḥ lakṣita caitanyayoḥ aikyam ucyate
translated: Here in both places, because the identity of the qualified is not possible, the identity of the consciousness indicated by the words That and I am Brahman is stated.

analyzed: ādi śabdena tat yaḥ haṃ saḥ sau yaḥ sau saḥ haṃ aiā
translated: The word 'ādi' includes the following śruti passages: 'That which I am, He is. He who is He, I am.' 'Ai'.

analyzed: yaḥ saḥ asau puruṣaḥ saḥ ham asmi  ityādi śrutiḥ gṛhyate
translated: 'He who is that Puruṣa, I am He.' 'Ī'.

original: kuto netyatastatraitacchrutīnāṃ parabrahmārthakatvena advaitārthatvābhāvāditi hetūpaskāramabhipretya teṣāṃ parabrahmārthatve pramāṇamāha
analyzed: kutas nā iti atas tatra etad śrutīnām para brahma arthaka tvena advaita artha tva abhāvāt iti hetu upaskāram abhipretya teṣām para brahma artha tve pramāṇam āha
translated: From where is it not so? With this in mind, intending the reason 'because these śruti passages have the meaning of the supreme Brahman, not the meaning of non-duality', he states the means of knowledge for their having the meaning of the supreme Brahman:

analyzed: nāmāni iti śrutyā tasya brahmaṇaḥ tad tad śabdaiḥ
translated: 'Nāmāni' etc. The meaning is that by this śruti it is said that Brahman is denoted by those words 'tat tat'

analyzed: tattvam ādi padaiḥ vācya tva ukteḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: or by the words 'tattva' etc.

original: tathā ca padasamanvayenaiteṣāṃ brahmaparatvānnaitadvirodha iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca pada samanvayena eteṣām brahma paratvāt na etad virodhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, because of the connection of words, these have the meaning of Brahman, so there is no contradiction with this.

analyzed: tad prakāraḥ tu tata tvāt tat
translated: The mode of that is: because of being that, it is that.

analyzed: tvam pada bodhya jīva antaryāmi tvāt abhimukha tvāt vā tvam
translated: Because of being the immanent Self of the individual soul denoted by the word 'tvam', or because of being manifest, it is 'tvam'.

analyzed: asanāt jagat saṃharaṇāt asiḥ
translated: Because of assuming, i.e. withdrawing the world, it is 'asi'.

analyzed: aheya tvāt haṃnāmaka jīva bhinna tvāt vā aham
translated: Because of being not to be abandoned, or because of being different from the individual soul called 'ham', it is 'aham'.

analyzed: pūrṇa tvāt brahma
translated: Because of being complete, it is Brahman.

analyzed: asanāt minuteḥ asmi
translated: Because of assuming, i.e. creating, it is 'asmi'.

analyzed: yat vā su mita tvāt smi iti uktaḥ jīvaḥ
translated: Or, the individual soul is said to be 'smi' because of being well-known.

analyzed: tat bhinnam pūrṇam brahma asmi iti ucyate iti
translated: Brahman, which is different from that and complete, is said to be 'asmi'.

analyzed: jñāna rūpa tvāt nitarām yantṛ tvāt ca yaḥ
translated: He is so called because He is of the nature of knowledge and is the supreme controller.

original: saraṇātsāratvācca saḥ /🔽amuṣmin amuṣmin sthitatvātparokṣatvācca asāvasauśabdavācyaḥ ityaitareyaśrutyarthaḥ /
analyzed: saraṇāt sāra tvāt ca saḥ  amuṣmin amuṣmin sthita tvāt parokṣa tvāt ca asau asau śabda vācyaḥ iti aitareya śruti arthaḥ
translated: He is so called because He moves and is the essence.🔽He is so called because He exists in that and is beyond the senses. This is the meaning of the Aitareya Upanishad.🔽The word that refers to the person who is in the breath.

analyzed: asau prāṇe sthitaḥ puruṣaḥ
translated: The word that refers to the person who is in the breath.

analyzed: pūrṇa ṣaḍguṇaḥ iti īśāvāsya śruti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Isha Upanishad is that He is the full possessor of the six qualities.

original: idaṃ hi viśvaṃ bhagavānivetaro yato jagatsthānanirodhasambhavaḥ /
analyzed: idam hi viśvam bhagavān iva itaraḥ yatas jagat sthāna nirodha sambhavaḥ
translated: This universe is indeed not different from the Lord, from whom comes the existence, continuance and origin of the world.

analyzed: asarvaḥ sarvaḥ iti api turaśrutiḥ
translated: The Vedic text also says that He is all and yet not all.

analyzed: astu vā etad śrutīnām aikya para tvam vākya anvaya rītyā
translated: Or let this be the unity of the Vedic texts according to the method of the connection of sentences.

analyzed: tathā api nā aikya śruti virodhaḥ bheda śruteḥ śaṅkanīyaḥ
translated: Even so, the contradiction of the Vedic texts about difference should not be suspected.

original: bhagavataḥ sarvaikyaśruteḥ sarvasvāmitvanimittaikyaparatvādityāśayena tatra pramāṇatvena bhāgavatasmṛtiṃ paṭhati idaṃ hīti //
analyzed: bhagavataḥ sarva aikya śruteḥ sarva svāmitva nimitta aikya paratvāt iti āśayena tatra pramāṇa tvena bhāgavata smṛtim paṭhati idam hi iti
translated: With the idea that the Vedic texts about the unity of all with the Lord are about the unity due to His being the owner of all, he quotes the Bhagavata Smriti as the proof.

analyzed: bhagavān svayam itaraḥ pi
translated: The word Lord refers to the Supreme Self.🔽The word other refers to the individual self.

analyzed: jagataḥ bhinnaḥ u pi san idam  pramitam viśvam iva ucyate tat tvam asi
translated: Even though different from the world, He is said to be this,

analyzed: aham brahma asmi
translated: like the known universe, in statements such as That thou art and I am Brahman.

analyzed: iti ādi vacaneṣu
translated: The word this refers to the individual self.🔽The word that refers to the Supreme Self.

analyzed: yathā uktam prathama tātparye
translated: As stated in the first chapter: The other Lord is like the universe.

analyzed: kutas yatas
translated: Why? From whom.

original: kāraṇāt 'jagatsthānanirodhasambhavaḥ' /🔽jagataḥ sthānaṃ sthitiḥ nirodho nāśaḥ sambhavaḥ utpattiḥ te yasmādbhavanti sa tathoktaḥ /🔽yadvā sthāpayati nirodhayati sambhāvyatyasmāditi tathoktaḥ /
analyzed: jagataḥ sthānam sthitiḥ nirodhaḥ nāśaḥ sambhavaḥ utpattiḥ te yasmāt bhavanti sa tathā uktaḥ  yat vā sthāpayati nirodhayati sambhāvyati asmāt iti tathā uktaḥ
translated: From the cause, the existence, cessation and origin of the world.🔽The existence of the world is its persistence, cessation is its destruction, and origin is its creation. From whom these occur, he is said to be so.🔽Or, he is said to be so because the world is established, ceased, and created from him.

original: athavā tiṣṭhatyasmāt niruddhyate pralīyate 'smin sambhāvayatīti sa tathoktaḥ /
analyzed: athavā tiṣṭhati asmāt niruddhyate pralīyate smin sambhāvayati iti sa tathā uktaḥ
translated: Or, the world persists from him, is destroyed in him, and is created by him, he is said to be so.

analyzed: tathā ca jagat sṛṣṭi ādi kartā iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus, he is the creator of the world and so on.

original: evambhūtsya jagadbhedaḥ pramāṇasiddha iti jñāpanāya hiśabdaḥ /
analyzed: evambhūt sya jagat bhedaḥ pramāṇa siddhaḥ iti jñāpanāya hi śabdaḥ
translated: The word hi is to show that the distinction of the world, which is of this nature, is established by valid means of knowledge.

original: tattvapradīpe tu bahuvrīhiṃ vinā idaṃ viśvaṃ bhagavāniva /
analyzed: tattvapradīpe tu bahuvrīhim vinā idam viśvam bhagavān iva
translated: But in the Tattvapradipa, without a bahuvrihi compound, this universe is like the Lord.

analyzed: etad adhīna tvāt
translated: Because it is dependent on him.

analyzed: sa tu itaraḥ
translated: But he is different.

analyzed: kaḥ yatas yasmāt
translated: Who? From whom. From whom the existence, cessation and origin of the world.

analyzed: jagat sṛṣṭi ādikam iti uktam
translated: The creation and so on of the world is said.

analyzed: atra ṭīkāyām ca bhagavān idam viśvam iva iti anvayaḥ
translated: And in the commentary here, the construction is the Lord is like this universe.

analyzed: svāmi tvena aikya vyapadeśaḥ iti etat eva āha asarvaḥ iti
translated: The oneness is spoken of by way of ownership. This is what is said by not all etc.

analyzed: tura śrutiḥ
translated: Tu is a particle of contradiction.

original: bhagavān sarvabhinno 'pi sarvasvāmitvāt sarva ityabhedena vedādiṣūcyate ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: bhagavān sarva bhinnaḥ sarva svāmi tvāt sarvaḥ iti abhedena veda ādiṣu ucyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that although the Lord is different from all, He is spoken of as all without distinction in the Vedas etc. because He is the owner of all.

analyzed: iti api iti śruti sthaḥ apiḥ samuccaye
translated: Even so - the particle api in the śruti is for the purpose of including.

analyzed: yatas iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Yataḥ is to be supplied.

analyzed: asya atas pi na virodhaḥ iti anvayaḥ
translated: The construction is: Therefore, there is no contradiction in this.

analyzed: vidyā ātmani bhidā bodhaḥ
translated: The knowledge of difference in the Self.

analyzed: bheda dṛṣṭyā abhimānena nissaṅgena api karmaṇā
translated: Even by one who is detached, by the action of the false notion of difference due to the view of difference.

original: nanu bhedajñānasya mithyājñānatvātkathaṃ tadanusāreṇaikyaśrutayo yojyanta ityāśaṅkāṃ bhāgavatavākyena pariharati vidyeti //
analyzed: nanu bheda jñānasya mithyājñāna tvāt katham tad anusāreṇa aikya śrutayaḥ yojyante iti āśaṅkām bhāgavata vākyena pariharati vidyā iti
translated: But how can the statements about oneness be interpreted in accordance with that, since the knowledge of difference is a false knowledge? This doubt is resolved by a statement from the Bhāgavata.

original: idaṃ ca kā vidyetyuddhavapraśnasyottaratvena kṛṣṇenoktaṃ vacanamekādaśaskandhe /🔽'ātmani' / paramātmani 'bhidābodho' /
analyzed: idam ca kā vidyā iti uddhava praśnasya uttara tvena kṛṣṇena uktam vacanam ekādaśa skandhe  ātmani paramātmani bhidā bodho
translated: And this is said by Kṛṣṇa as the answer to Uddhava's question What is knowledge? in the eleventh canto.

analyzed: jīvāt bheda jñānam jīve vā yat īśvarāt bheda jñānam
translated: In the Self - in the Supreme Self. The knowledge of difference - the knowledge of difference from the individual soul, or if it is the knowledge of difference from the Lord in the individual soul.

analyzed: sā eva vidyā iti arthaḥ
translated: That itself is knowledge. This is the meaning.

original: na ca bhidāyā abodha iti vyākhyeyam /
analyzed: na ca bhidāyāḥ abodhaḥ iti vyākhyeyam
translated: And it should not be explained as not the knowledge of difference.

analyzed: ajñānasya vidyā tva abhāvāt
translated: Because ignorance is not knowledge.

original: nanu bhedajñānasya puruṣārthahetutvāt kathaṃ tasya vidyātvamityata āha bhedeti /
analyzed: nanu bheda jñānasya puruṣa artha hetu tvāt katham tasya vidyā tvam iti atas āha bheda iti
translated: Now, since the knowledge of difference is the cause of human goals, how can that be knowledge? To this he says 'difference' etc.

analyzed: idam ca bhāgavate tṛtīya skandha gatam vākyam
translated: And this is a statement in the third chapter of the Bhagavata.

analyzed: ādyaḥ sthira carāṇām yaḥ veda garbhaḥ saha ṛṣibhiḥ
translated: He who is the first of the moving and unmoving, who is the essence of the Vedas along with the sages,

analyzed: yoga īśvaraiḥ kumāra ādyaiḥ siddhaiḥ yoga pravartakaiḥ
translated: The lord of yoga, Kumara and others, the perfected beings who propagate yoga,

analyzed: iti pūrva vākyena
translated: This should be connected with the previous statement.

analyzed: kartṛ tvāt sa guṇam brahma puruṣam puruṣa ṛṣabham
translated: Because of being the agent, the Brahman with qualities, the man, the best of men,

analyzed: sa saṅgatya punar kāle kālena īśvara mūrtinā
translated: He, having come together again at the time, by the time in the form of the Lord,

analyzed: jāte guṇa vyatikare yathāpūrvam prajāpate
translated: When there is a disturbance of the gunas, as before, O Prajapati,

analyzed: iti uttara vākyena ca saha yojanīyam
translated: This should be connected with the following statement.

analyzed: tad prakāraḥ tu yaḥ sthira carāṇām
translated: The way that is to be done is that he who is of the moving and unmoving,

analyzed: sthāvara jaṅgamānām ādyaḥ
translated: Of the immobile and moving, is the first.

analyzed: hiraṇyagarbhaḥ saḥ ṛṣibhiḥ
translated: He who is Hiranyagarbha, he, along with the sages,

analyzed: manuṣya uttamam ārabhya garuḍa śeṣa antaiḥ jñānibhiḥ yoga siddhaiḥ sanatkumāra ādyaiḥ saha bheda dṛṣṭyā
translated: Starting from the best of men up to Garuda and Shesha, the knowers, the perfected beings in yoga, Sanatkumara and others, with the view of difference,

analyzed: jīva īśvara ādi bheda jñānena abhimānena
translated: With the knowledge of the difference between the individual soul and the Lord, with pride,

original: abhito harermānena parameśvare bahumānena āgraheṇa ca 'niḥsaṅgena karmaṇāpi' /
analyzed: abhitas hareḥ mānena parameśvare bahu mānena āgraheṇa ca niḥsaṅgena karmaṇā api
translated: On all sides, by the measure of Hari, with great respect to the Supreme Lord, and with attachment.

analyzed: phala abhisandhiḥ ahita nivṛtta karmaṇā ca muktaḥ san kartṛ tvāt  jagat kartṛ tvāt nimittāt sa guṇam
translated: Having become liberated, by action also without attachment, and by action free from the desire for results.🔽By the cause of being the agent, by being the cause of the creation of the world, he is with qualities.

analyzed: sārvajña ādi guṇa sampūrṇam puruṣa ṛṣabham
translated: He is the best of men, full of the qualities of omniscience and so on.

analyzed: kṣara akṣarebhyaḥ varam puruṣam
translated: He is the Purusha, superior to the perishable and imperishable.

analyzed: paramapuruṣa ākhyam brahma kāle  pralaya kāle saṅgatya
translated: Brahma, called the Supreme Purusha, enters into Time.

analyzed: praviśya punar kālena  kāla ākhyena īśvara mūrtinā
translated: At the time of dissolution, having merged, again by Time.

analyzed: mūrtyā kāle  sṛṣṭi kāle jāte  utpanne sati aguṇa vyatikare
translated: By the form of the Lord called Time, in Time.

analyzed: sattva ādi guṇa vikriyā hīne viṣṇu loke yathāpūrvam
translated: At the time of creation, when born, when arisen, in the world of Vishnu, free from the modifications of the qualities like sattva, as before.

analyzed: pūrva vat prajāyate sarva mukta adhipatiḥ jāyate iti sudhāyām uktaḥ
translated: As before, he is born as the lord of all the liberated souls, as stated in the Sudha commentary.

analyzed: karmanirṇayaṭīkāyām tu na kevalam sa guṇam
translated: But in the Karma-nirnaya Tika, he is not only with qualities,

analyzed: kintu
translated: but also

analyzed: brahma purṇam puruṣam iti
translated: Brahma, the complete Purusha.

analyzed: bhagavataḥ nāma kīrtanam
translated: This is the glorification of the Lord's names.

analyzed: puruṣa tva uktyā asmāt ādi sālakṣaṇyam prāptam
translated: By the mention of being a Purusha, the similarity with the primordial nature is obtained.

analyzed: tad parihārāya puruṣa ṛṣabham iti
translated: To avoid that, it says the best of men.

analyzed: tad upapādanāya kartṛ tvāt saguṇam brahma iti viśeṣa arthaḥ uktaḥ
translated: To explain that, it says Brahman with qualities to specify that it is Brahman with qualities because of being the agent.

original: tattvapradīpe tu abhimāneneti padaṃ abhito mānena viśeṣajñāneneti vyākhyāya /
analyzed: tattvapradīpe tu abhimānena iti padam abhitas mānena viśeṣa jñānena iti vyākhyāya
translated: But in Tattvapradipa, the word abhimane is explained as with special knowledge by the mind on all sides.

analyzed: guṇa vyatikare
translated: The word guṇavyatikare

analyzed: iti padam chitvā sa
translated: is split and sa

analyzed: brahma ādi jīva saṅghaḥ pralaye jñāna aiśvarya ādi ananta guṇam brahma saṅgatya  prāpya punar kāle
translated: is explained as the group of souls beginning with Brahma, who, at the time of dissolution, attain Brahman, who has infinite qualities like knowledge and power,🔽and again at the time of creation,

analyzed: sṛṣṭi kāle kālena
translated: by time,

analyzed: jñāna ātmanā īśvara mūrtinā
translated: by the form of God,

analyzed: viṣṇu rūpeṇa guṇa vyatikare
translated: by the form of Vishnu, in the mixture of qualities,

original: guṇānāṃ sattvādīnāṃ vyatikare vaiṣamye jāte sati yathāpūrvaṃ jñānādiguṇatāratamyaṃ parasparabhedaṃ ca avihāya tadviśiṣṭa eva 'prajāyate' /
analyzed: guṇānām sattva ādīnām vyatikare vaiṣamye jāte sati yathāpūrvam jñāna ādi guṇa tāratamyam paraspara bhedam ca a vihāya tad viśiṣṭaḥ eva prajāyate
translated: when there is a mixture of inequality of qualities like sattva, the group of souls beginning with Brahma is born again,

analyzed: prakarṣeṇa muktau abhivyajyate
translated: manifesting in liberation with excellence.

analyzed: na tu tad abhinnaḥ bhavati iti vyākhyātam
translated: It is not explained that they become non-different from that.

analyzed: ayam padacchedaḥ ṭīkākṛtaḥ sammataḥ
translated: This is also accepted by the commentator who divided the words.

analyzed: tad pakṣe guṇa vyatikare kāle
translated: In his view, guṇavyatikare kāle

analyzed: sṛṣṭi kāle iti arthaḥ
translated: means at the time of creation.

analyzed: ubhayatra api yathāpūrvam iti asya saṃsāre iva iti artha
translated: In both cases, the meaning of 'as before' is 'as in the world'.

analyzed: pūrva kalpe iva iti vā
translated: Or, in the previous kalpa (period of the world).

analyzed: juṣṭam yadā paśyati anyam īśam asya mahimānam iti vīta śokaḥ
translated: 'When he sees the Lord as accepted by all, as the greatness of this (soul), then he is free from sorrow.'

analyzed: atra eva arthe atharvaṇa vākyam pramāṇayati juṣṭam iti
translated: In this very matter, he establishes the authority of the Atharvaṇa text with 'Jushtam'.

analyzed: juṣṭam sarva sevyam īśam svatantram
translated: Accepted by all, the Lord, the independent one.

original: ata eva anyaṃ jīvādbhinnaṃ viṣṇum iti tadetatsatyam mu / /
analyzed: atas eva anyam jīvāt bhinnam viṣṇum iti tat etat satyam
translated: For this very reason, Viṣṇu, different from the individual soul. Thus this is true.

original: ityādinā prāguktaprakāreṇa asya mahimānaṃ ca yadā paśyati /
analyzed: ityādinā prāc ukta prakāreṇa asya mahimānam ca yadā paśyati
translated: In this way, when he sees the greatness of this (soul),

original: paśyo jīvaḥ tadā vītaśoko mukto bhavatītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: paśyaḥ jīvaḥ tadā vīta śokaḥ muktaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: then the seeing soul becomes free from sorrow, liberated. This is the meaning.

original: tattvapradīpe tu juṣṭaṃ devaiḥ asya jīvasya īśam anyaṃ yadā paśyati mahimānaṃ mahimaguṇātmakaṃ tadā tadaiva vītaśoko bhavati na duḥkhaleśamapi 🔽spṛśati jīvaḥ /
analyzed: tattvapradīpe tu juṣṭam devaiḥ asya jīvasya īśam anyam yadā paśyati mahimānam mahima guṇa ātmakam tadā tadā eva vīta śokaḥ bhavati na duḥkha leśam api  spṛśati jīvaḥ
