translated: But in the Tattva Pradipika, it is explained that when the soul sees the Lord as accepted by the gods, as different from itself, as the greatness consisting of the qualities of greatness, then at that very time it becomes free from sorrow, and the soul does not touch even a bit of sorrow.

original: na tu mahimaguṇavihīnam anyamanīśamasevitaṃ paśyan vītaśoko bhavatīti vyākhyātam /
analyzed: na tu mahima guṇa vihīnam anyam anīśam asevitam paśyan vīta śokaḥ bhavati iti vyākhyātam
translated: But seeing another who is devoid of the qualities of greatness, who is not the Lord, and who is not served, one does not become free from sorrow.

analyzed: yadi api iyam śrutiḥ viśeṣaṇa bheda vyapadeśābhyām
translated: Although this scripture, by the difference in qualifications and designation,

original: ityatra ayamanyomārga ityukte prasiddhamārgādanyatvabodhavat anyamīśamityukte īśaśabditasya brahmaṇaḥ prasiddheśādrudrāt anyatvapratīterbrahmaṇo
analyzed: iti atra ayam anyaḥ mārgaḥ iti ukte prasiddha mārgāt anya tva bodha vat anyam īśam iti ukte īśa śabditasya brahmaṇaḥ prasiddha īśāt rudrāt anya tva pratīteḥ brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Here, just as when it is said this is another path, it conveys the meaning of being different from the well-known path, similarly when it is said another Lord, it conveys the meaning of Brahman denoted by the word Lord being different from Rudra, the well-known Lord. Thus, it is stated as a means of knowing Brahman's

analyzed: rudrāt anya tve pramāṇa tvena uktā  na tu brahmaṇaḥ jīvāt anya tve
translated: difference from Rudra.🔽But not as a means of knowing Brahman's difference from the individual soul.

analyzed: nā api īśatvam anyatve hetūkṛtam
translated: Nor is Lordship made the reason for difference.

original: tathāpi tat vyākhyānānantaramabhipretyeti na tadvirodhaḥ /🔽ata eva dyubhvādinaye bhedavyapadeśāt bra /sū / /
analyzed: tathā api tat vyākhyāna anantaram abhipretya iti na tad virodhaḥ  atas eva dyu bhū ādi naye bheda vyapadeśāt brasū
translated: Nevertheless, this is not contradictory to that, as it is intended after the explanation.🔽For this very reason, in the Dyu-bhuva section, it is stated as a means of knowledge in the difference between the individual soul and the Lord,

analyzed: iti atra jīva īśa bhede pi iyam pramāṇa tayā udāhṛtā
translated: in the passage because of the designation of difference (Brahma. Sutra 1.1.11).

original: 'asarvaḥ sarva ivātmaiva sannanātmeva pratyaṅparāṅivaika īyate bahudheyate'
analyzed: asarvaḥ sarvaḥ iva ātmā eva san anātmā iva pratyaṅ parāṅ iva ekaḥ īyate bahudhā iyate
translated: The non-all, as if all, being the self alone, is perceived as if not the self, as if near and far, as if one, as if manifold.

analyzed: sa puruṣaḥ saḥ īśvaraḥ sa brahma
translated: That is the Person. That is God. That is Brahman.

original: evaṃ svāmitvārthatayā parābhimatādvaitaśrutīrvyākhyāya vākyasamanvayāśrayaṇena antaryāmitayāpi tāḥ śrutismṛtibhyāṃ vyācaṣṭe asarva iti /
analyzed: evam svāmi tva artha tayā para abhimata advaita śrutīḥ vyākhyāya vākya samanvaya āśrayaṇena antaryāmi tayā api tāḥ śruti smṛtibhyām vyācaṣṭe asarvaḥ iti
translated: Having thus explained the non-dualistic passages accepted by others as having the meaning of ownership, he explains them as referring to the internal controller through the scriptures and Smritis, with the words the non-all etc.

original: yadyapi asarvaḥ iti vākyam ātmaśabdasya svāmitvārthatvamupetya svāmitvena nimittenaikyaśrutayaḥ pravṛttā ityatra pramāṇatayodāhṛtam /
analyzed: yadi api asarvaḥ iti vākyam ātma śabdasya svāmi tva artha tvam upetya svāmi tvena nimittena aikya śrutayaḥ pravṛttāḥ iti atra pramāṇa tayā udāhṛtam
translated: Although the sentence He is not all is cited as a proof that the statements of oneness are based on the ground of ownership, assuming that the word Self means ownership,

original: tathāpi svāmitvenevāntaryāmitayāpyaikyaśrutayaḥ pravṛttā ityubhayatrāpyasya pramāṇatvasambhavādubhayatrāpi pramāṇatayodāharaṇaṃ yuktam /
analyzed: tathā api svāmi tvena iva antaryāmi tayā api aikya śrutayaḥ pravṛttāḥ iti ubhayatra api asya pramāṇa tva sambhavāt ubhayatra api pramāṇa tayā udāharaṇam yuktam
translated: nevertheless, since it is possible for it to be a proof in both cases, that it is a proof in both cases that the statements of oneness are based on the ground of being the inner controller as well as on the ground of ownership, it is proper to cite it as a proof in both cases.

original: tattvapradīpakṛtāmapi svāmitvenevāntaryāmitayāpyaikyaśrutayaḥ pravṛttā ityubhayatrāpi asarvaḥ iti śrutiḥ pramāṇamityabhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: tattvapradīpa kṛtām api svāmi tvena iva antaryāmi tayā api aikya śrutayaḥ pravṛttāḥ iti ubhayatra api asarvaḥ iti śrutiḥ pramāṇam iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: The intention of the authors of the Tattva Pradipika is that the scripture He is not all is a proof in both cases, that the statements of oneness are based on the ground of being the inner controller as well as on the ground of ownership.

original: na caivaṃ tattadantaryāmitvenāpi tattacchabdavācyatvaṃ viṣṇorastītyāha sarvāntaryāmikaḥ iti tattvapradīpavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: na ca evam tad tad antaryāmi tvena api tad tad śabda vācyatvam viṣṇoḥ asti iti āha sarva āntaryāmikaḥ iti tattvapradīpa virodhaḥ
translated: And it should not be said that there is a contradiction with the Tattva Pradipika, since Vishnu is denoted by those words even by being the inner controller of each, in this way.

analyzed: atra pada samanyava abhiprāya pratīteḥ iti vācyam
translated: Here, it should not be said that it is because the intention of the Padasamanya is understood.

original: antaryāmitvenāpītyuktyā na kevalaṃ nāmāni iti śrutibalāttattacchabdapravṛttinimittatvena tattacchabdavācyatvaṃ viṣṇoḥ /
analyzed: antaryāmi tvena api iti uktyā na kevalam nāmāni iti śruti balāt tad tad śabda pravṛtti nimitta tvena tad tad śabda vācyatvam viṣṇoḥ
translated: By the statement even by being the inner controller, it is said that Vishnu is denoted by those words by being the basis for the application of those words, not only by the power of the scripture those names.

original: api tu antaryāmitvenāpītyetāvanmātrapratīteḥ atra padasamanvaye tātparyānavagamāt /
analyzed: api tu antaryāmi tvena api iti etāvat mātra pratīteḥ atra pada samanvaye tātparya anavagamāt
translated: But even in the sense of being the inner controller, since only that much is understood, and since the purpose of the connection of the words here is not known,

original: mahāvākyagatasyaitadādiśabdasyaikaikasya sarvāntaryāmikaḥ iti smṛtibalāt antaryāmitvanimittena viṣṇuvācitve 'pi padāntarāṇānyaparatvena vākyasamanvayasyaiva 🔽vaktavyatvāt /
analyzed: mahāvākya gatasya etat ādi śabdasya ekaikasya sarva antaryāmikaḥ iti smṛti balāt antaryāmi tva nimittena viṣṇu vāci tve pi vākya samanvayasya eva  vaktavya tvāt
translated: even though the word that occurring in the great sentence is to be taken as referring to Vishnu by reason of being the inner controller, on the strength of the Smriti, still the connection of the sentence must be stated by reason of the other words having a different purport.

original: yadā nāmāni iti śrutibalāt kriyākārakādisarvārthavācisarvapadasya viṣṇuvācitvābhyupagamaḥ tadaiva padasamanvayaḥ /
analyzed: yadā nāmāni iti śruti balāt kriyā kāraka ādi sarva artha vāci sarva padasya viṣṇu vāci tva abhyupagamaḥ tadā eva pada samanvayaḥ
translated: When the word name is accepted as referring to Vishnu by the strength of the Shruti, then the connection of the words is stated.

original: na tvekaikasya viṣṇuvācitva iti na virodhaḥ tathā cāntaryāmitvanimittena tattvamasyādivākyagatatvamahamādipadānāṃ viṣṇuvācitve tvaṃ tvadantaryāmī
analyzed: na tu ekaikasya viṣṇu vāci tve iti na virodhaḥ tathā ca antaryāmi tva nimittena tattvamasi ādi vākya gata tvam aham ādi padānām viṣṇu vāci tve tvam tvad antaryāmī
translated: But not when each word is accepted as referring to Vishnu. There is no contradiction. Thus, in the sentence That art thou, the words that, I, etc. are to be taken as referring to Vishnu by reason of being the inner controller. You are the inner controller of that.

analyzed: tat brahma
translated: That is Brahman.

analyzed: aham mad antaryāmī brahma iti vākya anvayaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: I am the inner controller of that. Brahman. Thus the connection of the sentence is to be seen.

original: na caivami asi asmi iti kriyāpadānvayāyogaḥ /
analyzed: na ca evam asi asmi iti kriyāpada anvaya ayogaḥ
translated: And in this way, the connection of the words you are and I am is not improper.

original: jīvaviśiṣṭāntaryāmivācakasya tvamādiśabdasya dagdhṛśabdasyāyasīvāntaryāmiṇi mukhyavṛttiḥ /🔽jīvetvamukhyavṛttirityāśrayaṇenāmukhyārthavivakṣayā asi asmītyādipadaprayogopapatteḥ /🔽yadyapi nimittakathanaprakaraṇe vidyātmani bhedadṛṣṭyā juṣṭaṃ yadā iti vākyatrayasyānvayābhāvaḥ /
analyzed: jīva viśiṣṭa antaryāmi vācakasya tvam ādi śabdasya dagdhṛ śabdasya āyasī iva antaryāmiṇi mukhya vṛttiḥ  jīva itu amukhya vṛttiḥ iti āśrayaṇena amukhya artha vivakṣayā asi asmi ityādi pada prayoga upapatteḥ  yadi api nimitta kathana prakaraṇe vidyā ātmani bheda dṛṣṭyā juṣṭam yadā iti vākya trayasya anvaya abhāvaḥ
translated: But the word you and so on, which denotes the inner controller qualified by the individual soul, has primary meaning in the inner controller of iron,🔽and in the individual soul it has secondary meaning. Thus, the use of words like you and I is justified by the intention to speak of secondary meanings.🔽Although in the context of explaining the cause, there is no connection of the three sentences when it is enjoyed with the knowledge-self,

original: tathāpi svāmitvanimittenaikyavyapadeśa ityatra śrutismṛtyorupanyāne sati tatra prāptaśaṅkāparihārasyāvaśyakatvenāvasarasaṅgatyā tadvākyatrayapravṛtteḥ
analyzed: tathā api svāmi tva nimittena aikya vyapadeśaḥ iti atra śruti smṛtyoḥ upanyāne sati tatra prāpta śaṅkā parihārasya āvaśyaka tvena avasara saṅgatyā tad vākya traya pravṛtteḥ
translated: nevertheless, since the mention of the Śruti and Smṛti is necessary for the removal of doubts that arise there, the three sentences are used by the method of connection with the topic.

original: ityādeḥ ityasāyatrākarṣaṇena na virodhaḥ ityasyānukarṣaṇena cānvayo draṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: ityādeḥ na virodhaḥ iti asya anukarṣaṇena ca anvayaḥ draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: And the connection should be seen by the attraction of from this and the attraction of there is no contradiction.

original: śrutyarthastu viṣṇuḥ asarvo 'pi sarvanātmako 'pi sarva iva sarvātmaka iva sarvātmakatvena īyate /
analyzed: śruti arthaḥ tu viṣṇuḥ sarvaḥ iva sarva ātmakaḥ iva sarva ātmaka tvena īyate
translated: The meaning of the Śruti is: Viṣṇu, although not all, although having the nature of all, is perceived as all, as having the nature of all, as having the nature of all.

original: kuta ityatastatrāntaryāmitvaṃ hetutvenābhipretya anantaryāmitvapratītyā tasyāsiddhimāśaṅkyāha ātmaiveti /
analyzed: kutas iti atas tatra antaryāmi tvam hetutvena abhipretya anantaryāmi tva pratītyā tasya asiddhim āśaṅkya āha ātmā eva iti
translated: From what? Therefore, intending the state of being the inner controller there as the reason, suspecting the non-establishment of the state of being the inner controller due to the cognition of being the outer controller, he says the Self alone, etc..

original: ātmaiva antaryāmyeva san anātmeva anantaryāmitvena īyate jñāyate rāmakṛṣṇādirūpeṣu /
analyzed: ātmā eva antaryāmī eva san anātmā iva anantaryāmi tvena īyate jñāyate rāma kṛṣṇa ādi rūpeṣu
translated: The Self alone, the inner controller alone, exists as if it were not the inner controller, is known in the forms of Rama, Krishna, etc.

analyzed: tathā ca ajñāna mūlā anantaryāmi tva pratītiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, the cognition of being the outer controller has ignorance as its root - this is the idea.

analyzed: nanu viṣṇoḥ antaryāmi tve pratyaktvam syāt tat ca anupapannam
translated: But if Vishnu were the inner controller, he would be the direct object of perception, and that is not possible.

analyzed: parāktvena pratīteḥ iti atas āha pratyaṅ iti
translated: Because he is cognized as the indirect object. In response to this, he says direct, etc.

analyzed: bhagavān pratyaṅ deha antargataḥ pi parāṅ iva bahis mātra vṛtti tvena iyate
translated: The Lord, though present within the body, is cognized as if he were external, as if he were present only outside.

analyzed: tathā ca bahis mātra vṛtti tva pratītiḥ bhrāntiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, the cognition of being present only outside is a delusion - this is the idea.

original: nanu viṣṇau viruddhānekadharmābhyupagame bhedāpattyā ekameva iti śrutivirodha ityata āha eka iti /
analyzed: nanu viṣṇau viruddha aneka dharma abhyupagame bheda āpattyā ekam eva iti śruti virodhaḥ iti atas āha ekaḥ iti
translated: But if contradictory attributes are accepted in Vishnu, there would be the fault of multiplicity, and thus there would be a contradiction with the Upanisadic text that he is one only. In response to this, he says one, etc.

analyzed: ekaḥ eva bahudhā bahu rūpeṇa iyataḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he alone is cognized in many ways, in many forms.

analyzed: tathā ca ekasya eva rūpa bāhulyāt sarva dharma upapattiḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, because he alone has many forms, all attributes are possible - this is the idea.

analyzed: dvi grahaṇāt sarvatra kriyā sambandhaḥ sūcitaḥ
translated: The use of the word two indicates the connection of action everywhere.

original: tattvapradīpe tu pratyaṅ parāṅiva abhimukho 'pyanabhimukha iva eka eva bahudheyate jñāyate prāpyate ca ityuktam /
analyzed: tattvapradīpe tu pratyaṅ parāṅ iva abhimukhaḥ pi anabhimukhaḥ iva ekaḥ eva bahudhā iyate jñāyate prāpyate ca iti uktam
translated: But in the Tattvadipika, it is said that the one who is behind is as if facing, but not facing, and is known and attained in many ways.

analyzed: antaryāmi tva nimittena sarva ātmaka tvena vyapadiśyamānaḥ kim sarvajñaḥ
translated: Is the one who is designated as the all-pervading Self omniscient?

analyzed: kva ca vyapadiśyata
translated: And where is he designated?

original: ityata āha sa puruṣa iti /🔽anena puruṣa evedaṃ sarvam tai /ā / /
analyzed: iti atas āha sa puruṣaḥ iti  anena puruṣaḥ eva idam sarvam taiā
translated: To this he says that Purusha.

analyzed: iti śrutim upādatte
translated: By this, he cites the Shruti: This entire universe is made of that.

analyzed: sampūrṇa ṣaḍguṇa tvāt deha ākhya pure śayanāt vā puruṣa saṃjñaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that he is called Purusha because he possesses all six qualities, or because he lies in the city called the body.

original: sthalāntaramāha sa iti /🔽anena sarvaṃ khalvidaṃ brahma chā / /
analyzed: sthala antaram āha saḥ iti  anena sarvam khalu idam brahma chā
translated: He states another point: He.

analyzed: iti śrutim upādatte
translated: By this, he cites the Shruti: This entire universe is Brahman.

original: saḥ sarvātmakatvena vyapadiśyamāno bhagavān brahma sarvatra pūrṇatvādbrahmasaṃjña ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: saḥ sarva ātmaka tvena vyapadiśyamānaḥ bhagavān brahma sarvatra pūrṇa tvāt brahma saṃjñaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the Lord, who is designated as the all-pervading Self, is called Brahman because He is full everywhere.

original: nanvanyatrādṛṣṭamantargatasya bahirgatatvādikaṃ kathaṃ ghaṭata ityata āha sa īśvara iti /
analyzed: nanu anyatra adṛṣṭam antargatasya bahis gata tva ādikam katham ghaṭate iti atas āha saḥ īśvaraḥ iti
translated: But how can the unseen state of being within become external, etc.? To this he says He is the Lord.

original: saḥ hariḥ yataḥ īśvaraḥ acintyaśaktyupetaḥ atastasmin anyatrāghaṭitamapi sarvaṃ ghaṭata iti //
analyzed: saḥ hariḥ yatas īśvaraḥ acintya śakti upetaḥ atas tasmin anyatra aghaṭitam api sarvam ghaṭate iti
translated: That Hari is the Lord, possessing inconceivable power, therefore, even what is not possible in others is possible in Him.

analyzed: sarva āntaryāmikaḥ viṣṇuḥ sarva nāmnā abhidhīyate
translated: Vishnu, the immanent in all, is denoted by the word all.

original: eṣo 'haṃ tvamasau ceti na tu sarvasvarūpataḥ //
analyzed: eṣaḥ ham tvam asau ca iti na tu sarva svarūpataḥ
translated: But not as the form of all, as I, you, and he.

analyzed: na etat icchanti puruṣam ekam kuru kula udvaha
translated: They do not accept this, O perpetuator of the Kuru dynasty.

analyzed: ityādeḥ ca
translated: And from this injunction.

analyzed: smṛtau kapratyayaḥ sarva deha gatasya api viṣṇoḥ ajñāta tvam āha
translated: The affix kvip in the compound sarvātman indicates that Vishnu, though present in all bodies, is unknown.

original: yadvā yāmo niyamanaṃ tatra bhava ityarthe ṭhak /
analyzed: yat vā yāmaḥ niyamanam tatra bhavaḥ iti arthe ṭhak
translated: Or, the affix ṭhak is used in the sense of yatra bhavat tatra (where there is, there is that).

original: yato viṣṇuḥ sarvāntaryāmikaḥ sarvāntarniyāmakaḥ ata eva eṣa ātmeti hovāca chā / /
analyzed: yatas viṣṇuḥ sarva antaryāmikaḥ sarva antar niyāmakaḥ atas eva eṣaḥ ātmā iti ha uvāca chā
translated: Since Vishnu is the immanent in all, the controller of all, therefore he said this is the Self.

analyzed: saḥ ham asmi ī
translated: I am that.

analyzed: tat tvam asi chā
translated: That art thou.

analyzed: yaḥ sa au asau puruṣaḥ ī
translated: He who is that person.

original: iti vākyasthena eṣo 'haṃtvamasāviti sarvanāmnā sarvavācakasarvanāmasaṃṅakaśabdena sarvamiti nāmnā cābhidhīyate /
analyzed: iti vākya sthena eṣaḥ han tvam asau iti sarvanāmnā sarva vācaka sarva nāma saṃṅaka śabdena sarvam iti nāmnā ca abhidhīyate
translated: By the word all occurring in the sentence, which is a pronoun denoting everything, he is denoted by the name all.

analyzed: na tu sarva svarūpa tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: But not because He is the form of all, is the meaning.

analyzed: śreṣṭha vastu aikya arthatayā api aikya śrutīḥ smṛtyā vyākhyāti  na etat iti
translated: He explains the statements of identity by smrti as having the meaning of identity with the best thing, by saying They do not accept this.

original: mokṣadharme hi vaiśampāyanaṃ prati he brahman bhedavākyāt bahavaḥ puruṣāḥ pratipattavyāḥ /🔽aikyavākyaṃ tu pradhānapuruṣaparamiti vā /
analyzed: mokṣa dharme hi vaiśampāyanam prati he brahman bheda vākyāt bahavaḥ puruṣāḥ pratipattavyāḥ  aikya vākyam tu pradhāna puruṣa param iti vā
translated: For in the Dharma of Liberation, to Vaishampayana, O Brahmana, many persons are to be understood from the statements of difference.🔽But the statement of identity is about the primary and the individual soul.

analyzed: uta aho aikya vākyāt ekaḥ eva puruṣaḥ
translated: Or rather, from the statement of identity, there is only one person.

analyzed: dvaita vākyam tu vyāvahārika bheda param iti
translated: But the statement of duality is about the difference in practical usage.

original: tathā puruṣabāhulyamupetyaikyavākyasya śreṣṭhaparatvapakṣe 'pi ātmasu kiṃ sarve samāḥ /
analyzed: tathā puruṣa bāhulyam upetya aikya vākyasya śreṣṭha para tva pakṣe ātmasu kim sarve samāḥ
translated: Thus, accepting the multiplicity of souls, even in the case of the statement of identity being about the supreme, are all souls equal?

analyzed: uta ekaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ
translated: Or is one supreme?

analyzed: dvitīye kaḥ sau atra puruṣeṣu śreṣṭhaḥ
translated: In the second case, who is that supreme person among souls?

analyzed: sa katham hi śreṣṭhaḥ
translated: And how is he supreme?

original: taṃ tathā ca bhavān vaktumarhatītyāśayena kṛtasya janamejayapraśnasya vaiśampāyanenoktamuttaram
analyzed: tam tathā ca bhavān vaktum arhati iti āśayena kṛtasya janamejaya praśnasya vaiśampāyanena uktam uttaram
translated: With the intention that you should speak thus, the answer given by Vaishampayana to the question asked by Janamejaya is

analyzed: na etat icchanti puruṣam ekam kuru kula udvaha
translated: They do not desire this, O perpetuator of the Kuru lineage, that there is only one person.

analyzed: bahūnām puruṣāṇām hi yathā ekā yoniḥ ucyate
translated: For as one womb is said to be of many persons,

analyzed: tathā tam puruṣam viśvam ākhyāsyāmi guṇa adhikam
translated: So I will explain that person, the universe, as having superior qualities.

analyzed: iti asya arthaḥ etat matam na icchanti vidvāṃsaḥ
translated: The meaning of this is that the wise do not desire this view.

analyzed: etat iti kim iti atas tat vivṛṇoti puruṣam ekam iti
translated: This - what? Therefore, he explains it: one person.

original: tathā ca vedāḥ ekameva puruṣaṃ vadantītyetanmataṃ jñānino necchantītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca vedāḥ ekam eva puruṣam vadanti iti etat matam jñāninaḥ na icchanti iti arthaḥ
translated: And thus, the Vedas speak of only one Purusha. This view is not accepted by the knowers of Brahman.

original: yadvā etasmin jagati ekaṃ puruṣaṃ necchanti /
analyzed: yat vai etasmin jagati ekam puruṣam na icchanti
translated: Or, they do not accept one Purusha in this world.

analyzed: kintu bahavaḥ puruṣāḥ santi iti
translated: But there are many Purushas.

analyzed: tarhi advaita śruti virodhaḥ iti na vācyam
translated: Then it should not be said that it contradicts the non-dualistic scriptures.

analyzed: yatas bahūnām śreṣṭhaḥ ekaḥ eva
translated: Because the best among many is only one.

analyzed: tat parama aikya vākyam
translated: That is the statement of oneness.

analyzed: bahūnām kaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ
translated: Who is the best among many?

analyzed: sa katham śreṣṭhaḥ
translated: How is he the best?

analyzed: iti asya uttaram āha bahūnām iti
translated: The answer to this is given by bahūnām etc.

original: he kurukulodvaha eteṣāṃ bahūnāṃ puruṣāṇām ātmānāṃ madhye yā yoniḥ yaḥ kāraṇabhūtaḥ🔽ekā śreṣṭhaḥ yathā ca śreṣṭha ucyate śrutyādau tathā tena prakāreṇa taṃ viśvaṃ pūrṇaṃ
analyzed: he kuru kula udvaha eteṣām bahūnām puruṣāṇām ātmānām madhye yā yoniḥ yaḥ kāraṇa bhūtaḥ  ekā śreṣṭhaḥ yathā ca śreṣṭhaḥ ucyate śruti ādau tathā tena prakāreṇa tam viśvam pūrṇam
translated: O supporter of the Kuru lineage, among these many Purushas, the souls, the one who is the cause,🔽the one best, as he is called the best in the scriptures etc., by that way, I will explain that all-pervading, complete,

original: guṇādhikaṃ puruṣam ākhyāsyāmi vyākhyāsyāmīti prameyadīpikāvyāsatīrthīyadiśā smṛtyarthaḥ /
analyzed: guṇa adhikam puruṣam ākhyāsyāmi vyākhyāsyāmi iti prameyadīpikā vyāsatīrthīya diśā smṛti arthaḥ
translated: superior Purusha, according to the Smriti commentary of Prameyadipika Vyastri.

analyzed: anena para abhimata aikya vākyam uttama vastu aikya param
translated: By this, the statement of oneness accepted by others refers to the oneness of the supreme object.

original: tathā ca sarvotkṛṣṭaṃ yadekaṃ brahmatattvamasi tasmādatyavaro 'si atyavaro 'smīti śrutyartha ukto bhavati /
analyzed: tathā ca sarva utkṛṣṭam yat ekam brahma tattvam asi tasmāt atyavaraḥ si atyavaraḥ smi iti śruti arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: And thus, the highest of all is that one Brahman-reality, you are that. Therefore, you are extremely superior. You are extremely superior - this is the meaning of the Upanishad.

original: ityādeśca ityasya na ca tattvamasītyādivirodhaḥ ityanenānvayaḥ /
analyzed: ityādeḥ ca ityasya na ca tat tvam asi ityādi virodhaḥ iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: And from this, and not the contradiction of That thou art, etc. - this is connected with this.

analyzed: uktā ca prāptiḥ  brahma eva san bṛ
translated: And the attainment has been stated.🔽'Being Brahman itself' - also.

analyzed: iti api jīvaḥ eva brahma śabdaḥ
translated: The word Brahman is only about the individual soul.

analyzed: upapadyate ca virodhe
translated: And it is appropriate in the case of contradiction.

analyzed: nanu advaita śruti abhāve katham advaitam bheda śruti ādinā niṣidhyate
translated: But if there is no non-dualistic scripture, how is non-duality refuted by the scriptures teaching difference, etc.?

analyzed: tasya apratyakṣa tvena śrutim vinā prāpti abhāvāt
translated: Because, being imperceptible, it cannot be attained without scripture.

original: aprāptasya ca pratiṣedhāyogāt ityata āha uktā ceti //
analyzed: aprāptasya ca pratiṣedha ayogāt iti atas āha uktā ca iti
translated: And what is not attained cannot be denied. To this he says 'And the attainment has been stated'.

analyzed: caḥ sādhya samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for including what is to be established.

original: co yato na ca tattvamasi ityādinā jīveśvaikyasya prāptiḥ śrutyarthāparijñānanimittā prasaktiruktā /
analyzed: yatas na ca tat tvam asi ityādinā jīva īśvara aikyasya prāptiḥ śruti artha aparijñāna nimittā prasaktiḥ uktā
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is because the attainment of the non-duality of the individual soul and God, which is due to ignorance of the meaning of the scriptures, has been stated by 'That thou art', etc.

analyzed: atas na tad niṣedha anupapattiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no inappropriateness in denying that. This is the meaning.

original: nanvetacchrutīnāmavirodhakatve 'pi bhedaśruteḥ brahmaiva san brahmāpyeti iti śrutivirodhastu bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: nanu etad śrutīnām avirodhaka tve pi bheda śruteḥ brahma eva san brahma apyeti iti śruti virodhaḥ tu bhaviṣyati
translated: But even if these scriptures do not contradict, there will be contradiction with the scripture 'Being Brahman itself, he goes to Brahman' by the scripture teaching difference.

original: atra brahmaiveteyavakāreṇa jīvasyābrahmatāniṣedhena tadadhīnatvādinā nimittena abrahmabhūte brahmatvavyavahāra ityuktagaterasambhavādityata
analyzed: atra jīvasya abrahma tā niṣedhena tad adhīna tva ādinā nimittena abrahma bhūte brahmatva vyavahāraḥ iti ukta gateḥ asambhavāt iti atas
translated: Here, by the word Brahman alone, the non-Brahman nature of the individual soul is denied, and by the reason of its dependence and so on, the usage of Brahmanhood is said to be in Brahmanhood, which is not Brahman. Thus, because of the impossibility of the stated meaning,

analyzed: āha brahma eva iti
translated: he says Brahman alone, etc.

analyzed: apiḥ samuccaye
translated: Api is for the purpose of including.

analyzed: na kevalam tattvam asi ityādikam aviruddham
translated: Not only is That thou art and so on not contradictory,

analyzed: kintu brahma eva san iti bṛhadāraṇya vākyam api iti arthaḥ
translated: but also the sentence of the Brhadaranyaka Upanishad Brahman alone and so on. This is the meaning.

analyzed: kutas iti atas āha jīve eva iti
translated: Why? Therefore he says in the individual soul alone, etc.

analyzed: saptamīyam viṣaya arthe
translated: The locative case is for the purpose of object.

original: tathā ca yato brahmaiva san iti vākye śruto 'yamādyo brahmaśabdaḥ brahmāṇi jīvāḥ sarve 'pi iti śruterjīva eva /
analyzed: tathā ca yatas brahma eva san iti vākye śrutaḥ yama ādyaḥ brahma śabdaḥ brahmāṇi jīvāḥ sarve iti śruteḥ jīvaḥ eva
translated: And thus, in the sentence Brahman alone, the first word Brahman heard is in the individual soul alone, because of the Vedic text All individual souls are Brahman.

analyzed: na para brahmaṇi atas iti arthaḥ
translated: Not in the supreme Brahman. This is the meaning.

analyzed: yat vā jīvaḥ iti prathama antam
translated: Or, jīva is in the first case.

original: tathā ca iti vākye śrutādyabrahmaśabdokto jīva eva /
analyzed: tathā ca iti vākye śruta ādya brahma śabda uktaḥ jīvaḥ eva
translated: And thus, the individual soul spoken of by the first word Brahman heard in the sentence Brahman alone is in the individual soul alone.

analyzed: na para brahma iti arthaḥ
translated: Not in the supreme Brahman. This is the meaning.

original: tathā ca iti vākye śrutādyabrahmaśabdokto jīva eva /
analyzed: tathā ca iti vākye śruta ādya brahma śabda uktaḥ jīvaḥ eva
translated: And thus, the individual soul spoken of by the first word Brahman heard in the sentence Brahman alone is in the individual soul alone.

analyzed: na para brahma iti arthaḥ
translated: Not in the supreme Brahman. This is the meaning.

original: tathā ca saḥ muktajīvo brahmaiva san jīva eva san jīvabhāvamavihāyaiva pralaye parabrahmāpnoti /
analyzed: tathā ca saḥ mukta jīvaḥ brahma eva san jīvaḥ eva san jīva bhāvam a vihāya eva pralaye para brahma āpnoti
translated: And thus that liberated soul, being Brahman itself, while being a living being, without abandoning the state of being a living being, attains the supreme Brahman at the time of dissolution.

original: apihitassan praviśatīti śrutyarthopapatteḥ noktabhedavyapadeśasyaitacchrutivarodha iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: apihitaḥ san praviśati iti śruti artha upapatteḥ na ukta bheda vyapadeśasya etad śruti varodhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning of the Upanisadic text is that while being covered, it enters. Thus, the teaching of difference mentioned above is not contradicted by this Upanisadic text. This is the idea.

analyzed: yathā uktam bṛhadbhāṣye
translated: As it is said in the Bṛhat-bhāṣya:

analyzed: brahma śabda uktaḥ jaḍāt bahu guṇa tvataḥ iti
translated: The living being is also denoted by the word Brahman, because of having many qualities more than the insentient.

original: prāpnoti paramaṃ brahma pralaye pralaye sadā / iti //
analyzed: prāpnoti paramam brahma pralaye pralaye sadā iti
translated: It attains the supreme Brahman at every dissolution.

analyzed: yadi api mukti avabhede pareṇa iyam śrutiḥ āśaṅkitā
translated: Although this Upanisadic text was doubted by the opponent in the case of non-difference in liberation,
it is stated in the same way in the Viṣṇu-tattva-viniścaya-ṭīkā.

analyzed: tathā ca muktau iti vācyam
translated: And thus it should be said in liberation,

analyzed: na tu pralaye iti
translated: but not at the time of dissolution.

analyzed: tathā api sarva jīva sādhāraṇyāya pralayaḥ iti uktiḥ
translated: Nevertheless, the statement at the time of dissolution is for the sake of being common to all living beings.

original: nanu brahmaśabdasya parabrahmaṇyeva mukhyatvānna jīve 'sau yujyata ityata āha upapadyata iti /
analyzed: nanu brahma śabdasya para brahmaṇi eva mukhya tvāt na jīve sau yujyate iti atas āha upapadyate iti
translated: But since the word Brahman is primary only in the supreme Brahman, it is not proper for the living being. In response to this, it is said it is proper.

analyzed: caḥ pi arthaḥ
translated: The word ca has the meaning of also.

original: tathā ca brahmaśabdo yadyapi parabrahmaṇi mukhyaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca brahma śabdaḥ yadi api para brahmaṇi mukhyaḥ
translated: And thus, although the word Brahman is primary in the supreme Brahman,

original: tathāpi virodhe svīyapūrvottaravākyavirodhe prāmāṇāntaravirodhe vā sati jīve 'pyupapadyata ityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tathā api virodhe svīya pūrva uttara vākya virodhe prāmāṇa antara virodhe vā sati jīve pi upapadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Still, in case of contradiction, when there is contradiction with one's own earlier or later statements or with other means of valid knowledge, the meaning is that it is possible even in the case of the individual soul.

original: prakṛte ca brahmāpyeti ityuttarabhāvisvavākyena paramaṃ sāmyam iti pūrvavākyena bhedagrāhipratyakṣādinā ca virodho 'stīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: prakṛte ca brahma apyeti iti uttara bhāvi sva vākyena paramam sāmyam iti pūrva vākyena bheda grāhi pratyakṣa ādinā ca virodhaḥ sti iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And in the present context, the meaning is that there is contradiction with the statement Brahman attains the supreme which comes later, with the statement the supreme equality which comes earlier, and with perception etc. which apprehend difference.

analyzed: pramāda ātmaka tvāt bandhasya vimukta tvam ca yujyate
translated: And because bondage consists in error, being liberated is also proper.

original: nanu tathāpi bhedavyapadeśasya vimuktaśca vimucyate kaṭha / /🔽iti kaṭhaśrutivirodhaḥ /
analyzed: nanu tathā api bheda vyapadeśasya vimuktaḥ ca vimucyate kaṭha  iti kaṭha śruti virodhaḥ
translated: But even so, there is contradiction with the Katha Upanishad, which says The liberated one is liberated (Katha.

original: atra saṃsāre 'pi jīvasya muktatvoktyā tadanyathānupapattyā parabrahmatvāvagamāt ityata āha pramādeti //
analyzed: atra saṃsāre pi jīvasya mukta tva uktyā tad anyathā anupapattyā para brahma tva avagamāt iti atas āha pramāda iti
translated: Here, by stating that the individual soul is liberated even in this world, and by the impossibility of any other explanation, it is understood to be the supreme Brahman. To this he says because of error etc.

analyzed: caśabdaḥ pi arthe samuccaye ca
translated: The word ca (and) has the sense of api (even) and samuccaya (collection).

original: tathā ca api jīvasya parabrahmatvābhāve 'pi vimuktatvaṃ vimuktatvavacanaṃ ca yujyate /
analyzed: tathā ca api jīvasya para brahma tva abhāve pi vimukta tvam vimukta tva vacanam ca yujyate
translated: And thus, even in the absence of the individual soul being the supreme Brahman, being liberated and the statement of being liberated are proper.

original: na kevalaṃ brahmaśabda upapadyate iti cārthaḥ /
analyzed: na kevalam brahma śabdaḥ upapadyate iti ca arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that not only the word Brahman is appropriate.

analyzed: katham bandhasya svataḥkartṛ tva bhoktṛ tva abhimāna rūpasya jīva gata saṃsārasya pramāda ātmaka tvāt  pramāda pada ukta ajñāna mūla tvena tad nimitta pratītika tvena asvābhāvika tvāt pramāda pada ukta ajñāna mūla tvena  tad nimitta pratītika tvena asvābhāvika tvāt
translated: How? Because the bondage, which is the form of the self-assumed agency and enjoyership of the individual soul in the form of worldly existence, is due to carelessness,🔽because it is not natural, being caused by the ignorance mentioned by the word 'carelessness' and being the basis of that notion.

analyzed: asvābhāvike ca avidyamāna pada prayoga darśanāt iti arthaḥ
translated: And because the use of the word 'non-existent' is seen in the non-natural. This is the meaning.

analyzed: atas na tad virodhaḥ iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no contradiction with that. This is the idea.

analyzed: bandhasya ajñāna mūla tvam ca
translated: And the root of bondage is ignorance. This is established by the words of Sanatsujata to Dhritarashtra, quoted in the Tattvapradipa Nyayamrita:

original: ubhe satye kṣatriyādya pravṛtte🔽moho mṛtyuḥ saṅgato yaṃ kavīnām /
analyzed: ubhe satye kṣatriya adya pravṛtte  mohaḥ mṛtyuḥ saṅgataḥ yam kavīnām
translated: Both truth and untruth proceed from the Kshatriya and others.🔽Delusion, which is associated with death, is the cause of poets.

analyzed: pramādam vai mṛtyum aham bravīmi
translated: I say that carelessness is indeed death.

analyzed: tathā apramādāt amṛta tvam bravīmi  iti tattvapradīpa nyāyāmṛta udāhṛta bhārata vacana siddham dhṛtarāṣṭram prati sanatsujāta vākyam etat
translated: Similarly, I say that immortality comes from carefulness.

original: he kṣatriyādya mṛtyuḥ saṃsāra tadabhāvarūpāmṛtatvaṃ cetyubhe api satye eva pravṛtte /
analyzed: he kṣatriya adya mṛtyuḥ saṃsāra tad abhāva rūpa amṛta tvam ca iti ubhe api satye eva pravṛtte
translated: O Kshatriya and others, both death, i.e., worldly existence, and immortality, which is the absence of that, indeed proceed from truth.

analyzed: tayoḥ madhye mṛtyuḥ mohaḥ ajñāna adhīnaḥ tad mūlaḥ
translated: Among them, death, i.e., ignorance, is dependent on delusion and is rooted in it.

original: tarhi mithyā syādityato netyāha pramādaṃ vā iti /🔽ahaṃ mṛtyuṃ saṃsāraṃ pramādaṃ asvābhāvikaṃ bravīmi /
analyzed: tarhi mithyā syāt iti atas na iti āha pramādam vā iti  aham mṛtyum saṃsāram pramādam a svābhāvikam bravīmi
translated: Then it would be false. To this he says, or negligence.🔽I say that death, saṃsāra, and negligence are unessential.

original: amṛtatvaṃ muktatvaṃ tu apramādāt pramādāpāyāt bravīmītyarthaḥ /
analyzed: amṛta tvam mukta tvam tu apramādāt pramāda apāyāt bravīmi iti arthaḥ
translated: But immortality, liberation, I say, comes from non-negligence, from the absence of negligence. This is the meaning.

analyzed: muktiḥ hitvā anyathā rūpam sva rūpeṇa vyavasthitiḥ
translated: Liberation is the state of remaining in one's own form after abandoning the other form.

analyzed: iti hi bhāgavate
translated: Thus it is in the Bhāgavata.

analyzed: bandhasya asvābhāvika tvam kutas siddham iti atas āha muktiḥ iti
translated: From where is the unessentialness of bondage established? To this he says liberation.🔽Other form.

analyzed: anyathārūpam  a svābhāvikam rūpam hitvā  tyaktvā sva rūpeṇa
translated: The unessential form.🔽After abandoning,🔽after renouncing. In one's own form,

analyzed: nija rūpeṇa avasthitiḥ eva muktiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: in one's own nature. The state of remaining is itself liberation. This is the meaning.

analyzed: bhāgavataḥ iti asya pramāda ātmaka tva ukteḥ iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: In the Bhāgavata is connected with because it is said to be of the nature of negligence.

analyzed: na ca tad tad anumāna virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with those inferences.

original: nanu bhedokteḥ śrutivirodhābhāve 'pi jīvo brahmābhinnaḥ cetanatvāt brahmavat /
analyzed: nanu bheda ukteḥ śruti virodha abhāve pi jīvaḥ brahma abhinnaḥ cetana tvāt brahma vat
translated: Even if there is no contradiction with the scriptures due to the statement of difference, the individual self is non-different from Brahman because of being conscious, like Brahman.

analyzed: bhedaḥ mithyā bheda tvāt candra bheda vat
translated: The difference is false because of being a difference, like the difference of the moon.

analyzed: vimatāni śarīrāṇi mad bhogāyatanāni mad śarīra vat
translated: The bodies that are the objects of my enjoyment are mine because of being bodies, like my body.

analyzed: iti anumāna virodhaḥ tu bhaviṣyati iti atas āha na ca iti
translated: Thus there will be contradiction with inference. To this he says 'and not' etc.

analyzed: caḥ virodha samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for non-contradiction and inclusion.

analyzed: tathā ca na kevalam śruti virodha abhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, not only is there no contradiction with scripture,

original: kintu tasyāḥ bhedokteḥ tenādvaitaparikalpitānumānena virodho 'pi netyarthaḥ /
analyzed: kintu tasyāḥ bheda ukteḥ tena advaita parikalpita anumānena virodhaḥ api na iti arthaḥ
translated: but also there is no contradiction with the inference imagined by the non-dualists, of which it is said that there is difference. This is the meaning.

analyzed: anena sautraḥ caśabdaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: By this, the word 'ca' (and) in the sutra is explained.

analyzed: kāmāt ca na anumāna apekṣā
translated: And because of desire, there is no need for inference.

analyzed: yathākāmam hi anumātum śakyate
translated: For inference can be made according to desire.

analyzed: atas na tattve pṛthak anumānam apekṣyate
translated: Therefore, for reality, separate inference is not required.

analyzed: tatra hetu ākāṅkṣāyām sūtram upanyasya vyācaṣṭe kāmāt iti
translated: There, when there is a need for a reason, he presents the sutra and explains it with 'kama' (desire) etc.

analyzed: hi yatas bheda sādhanāya para upanyastam anumānam
translated: 'Hi' (for). Because the inference presented by the opponent for the sake of establishing non-difference,

analyzed: anumāna tvena para abhimatam pṛthak
translated: which is accepted by the opponent as inference, is separate,

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi viruddham śruti sāhāyya rahitam ca atas tattve
translated: contradictory to perception etc., and devoid of the support of scripture, therefore it is not required for the sake of knowledge of reality.

analyzed: viṣaye jñāna upalakṣakam etat  tattva jñāna artham na apekṣyate
translated: This is an indication of the knowledge of reality.🔽It is not required for the sake of the knowledge of reality.

analyzed: tattva jñāna kāraṇam na bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: It does not become the cause of the knowledge of reality. This is the meaning.

analyzed: na ca aprayojaka tā
translated: And it is not that there is no purpose.

analyzed: hi yatas yathākāmam
translated: 'Hi' (for). Because it is according to desire.

original: yatheccham īśvaro na svatantraḥ cetanatvāt devadattavat /
analyzed: yatheccham īśvaraḥ na svatantraḥ cetana tvāt devadatta vat
translated: God is not independent, because He is conscious, like Devadatta.

original: jaḍa ātmā vastutvādityādirūpeṇa na tattve atattve 'pi anumātuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: jaḍaḥ ātmā vastu tvāt ityādi rūpeṇa na tattve atattve pi anumātum śakyate
translated: The self is inert, because it is an entity, etc. cannot be inferred in reality or unreality.

original: ataḥ anena pratyakṣādiviruddhasyāpi pramāṇatve cetanatvavastutvāderapi pramāṇatvaṃ syāt aviśeṣāditi vipakṣe bādhakatarka ukto bhavati /
analyzed: atas anena pratyakṣa ādi viruddhasya api pramāṇa tve cetana tva vastu tva ādeḥ api pramāṇa tvam syāt aviśeṣāt iti vipakṣe bādhaka tarkaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, this is said to be the counter-argument in the contrary case, that even if what contradicts perception, etc. is a means of valid knowledge, then consciousness and substantiality, etc. would also be means of valid knowledge, because there is no distinction.

analyzed: sūtre kāmāt
translated: In the sutra, 'without desire'.

original: ityekadeśotkīrtanena yathākāmāditi samagraśabdo lakṣyate jyotiśśabdena jyotiṣṭomaśabdavat ityāśayena yathākāmamityuktam /
analyzed: iti eka deśa utkīrtanena yathākāmāt iti samagra śabdaḥ lakṣyate jyotiḥ śabdena jyotiṣṭoma śabda vat iti āśayena yathākāmam iti uktam
translated: By mentioning a part, as if 'as desired' is indicated as a complete word, like the word 'jyotistoma' with the word 'jyoti'. With this idea, 'as desired' is said.

analyzed: hi iti anena pañcamī vyākhyātā
translated: By 'hi', the fifth case is explained.

analyzed: tattve iti anena asmin ityasya ākarṣaḥ dhyā āhāraḥ vā jñāpitaḥ
translated: By 'in reality', the attraction or insertion of 'in this' is indicated.

analyzed: anumānam iti anena na anumā
translated: By 'inference', 'not inference'.

analyzed: iti bhinna pada tvam pṛthak
translated: By 'separate', the separateness of words is indicated.

analyzed: iti anena nañaḥ viruddha arthaka tvam āśritya na anumā
translated: By 'not', relying on the contradictory meaning of the negative particle, 'not inference'.

analyzed: iti aikapadyam ca sūcitam  na apekṣyate
translated: The unity of words is also indicated.

analyzed: iti anena na śabda ghaṭita samāsam aṅgīkṛtya na apekṣā
translated: By 'not to be depended upon', accepting the compound formed by the word 'na', 'not to be depended upon'.

analyzed: iti aṃśaḥ vyākhyātaḥ
translated: This part has been explained.

original: smṛtyanusāreṇa sūtre bhāṣye ca tattvajñānāsādhanatvaprakaṭanāya parābhimatānumāne sādhanagocarecchāviṣayatvaniṣedhaḥ /
analyzed: smṛti anusāreṇa sūtre bhāṣye ca tattva jñāna asādhana tva prakaṭanāya para abhimata anumāne sādhana gocara icchā viṣaya tva niṣedhaḥ
translated: In accordance with the Smṛti, in the aphorism and commentary, in order to reveal the non-means-ness of true knowledge, the prohibition of being the object of desire in the inference accepted by the opponent is stated.

analyzed: tathā ca ayam sūtra arthaḥ anumā
translated: And thus this is the meaning of the aphorism: 'Anumā'.

analyzed: anumāna tvena para abhimatam abheda sādhakam anumānam asmin tattve
translated: The inference accepted by the opponent as an inference proving non-difference, in this truth, 'is not required'.

analyzed: tattva jñāna artham na apekṣā
translated: For the sake of true knowledge.

original: na apekṣā yasyāṃ sā tathāktā tattvajñānakāraṇaṃ na bhavati /
analyzed: na apekṣā yasyām sā tathā aktā tattva jñāna kāraṇam na bhavati
translated: Not required, in which that is so, it does not become the cause of true knowledge.

analyzed: kutas etat yatas iyam anumā na anumā
translated: Why is this? Because this inference 'is not an inference'.

analyzed: pratyakṣa ādi viruddhā anumā
translated: An inference contrary to perception and other means of knowledge.

original: tadviruddhāpi sadanumā kiṃ na syāt / na syāt /
analyzed: tad viruddhā api sat anumā kim na syāt na syāt
translated: Even though contrary to that, can it not be a valid inference? It cannot be.

analyzed: kutas yathākāmāt asyāḥ
translated: Why? 'Because of desire'. Of this.
Desire is will, because it has activity following from that.

original: tathā ca pratyakṣādiviruddhāyā api prāmāṇye uktarītyā atattvaviṣaye pravṛttāyā anumāyā api prāmāṇyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā ca pratyakṣa ādi viruddhāyāḥ api prāmāṇye ukta rītyāḥ atattva viṣaye pravṛttāyāḥ anumāyāḥ api prāmāṇyam syāt
translated: And thus, even if a valid cognition contrary to perception and other means of knowledge is accepted, an inference engaged in a non-true object in the manner stated would also be a valid cognition.

analyzed: aviśeṣāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that there is no difference.

analyzed: yatas evam atas na dvaita śruteḥ anumāna virodhaḥ pi iti
translated: And since this is so, therefore there is no contradiction of inference even for the statement of duality.

analyzed: uktam ca skānde
translated: And it is said in the Skanda Purāṇa:

analyzed: yathākāmā anumā yasmāt tasmāt sā anapagā śruteḥ
translated: Since inference is according to desire, therefore it is not opposed to scripture.

analyzed: pūrva apara avirodhāya ca iṣyate na anyathā kvacid iti
translated: It is accepted for the purpose of avoiding contradiction between earlier and later [passages], not otherwise anywhere.

analyzed: atra eva smṛti sammatim āha uktam ca iti
translated: Here he quotes the agreement of Smṛti: And it is said...

analyzed: caḥ samuccaye
translated: The word ca (and) is for inclusion.

analyzed: na kevalam sūtrakṛtā
translated: Not only by the author of the sūtra.

analyzed: skānde pi uktam iti
translated: It is also said in the Skanda [Purāṇa].

analyzed: kim uktam iti atas tat paṭhati yathā iti
translated: What is said? Therefore he quotes that: As...

analyzed: padārtha anativṛtti arthaḥ yam yathāśabdaḥ
translated: This word yathā (as) is for the purpose of not going beyond the meaning of the word.

analyzed: liṅgam ārṣam
translated: The mark is Ārṣa (of the Ṛṣis).

analyzed: yat vā na ayam avyayībhāvaḥ
translated: Or this is not an avyayībhāva compound.

analyzed: kintu anatikrāntaḥ kāmaḥ yayā iti bahuvrīhi samāsaḥ
translated: But it is a bahuvrīhi compound, meaning that which does not go beyond desire.

analyzed: pravartate iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Pravartate (functions) is implied.

original: apavṛttaṃ viruddhaṃ gaṃ gamanaṃ yasyāḥ sā apagā /
analyzed: apavṛttam viruddham gam gamanam yasyāḥ sā apagā
translated: That which has a going (gamana) that is opposed (apāvṛtta) is apāgā.

analyzed: na apagā anapagā iti vigrahaḥ
translated: The analysis is: na apāgā (not gone away) anapāgā (not departed).

analyzed: tathā ca yasmāt anumā
translated: And since it is anumā (inference),

analyzed: śruti ādi viruddham pṛthak anumānam yathākāmā
translated: the inference that is opposed to scripture etc. is yathākāmā (according to desire).

analyzed: kāmam an atikramya pravartate
translated: It functions without going beyond desire.

analyzed: puruṣa icchā anusāreṇa pravṛttimatī iti yāvat
translated: It functions according to the will of the person, that is the meaning.

analyzed: tasmāt śruteḥ anapagā
translated: Therefore, śruteḥ anupāgā (not opposed to scripture).

analyzed: śruti anukūlā tad aviruddhā eva sā pūrva apara avirodhāya
translated: It is in accordance with scripture, not opposed to it, for the purpose of avoiding contradiction between earlier and later [passages].

analyzed: śruteḥ pūrva uttara vākya virodha parihāra artham iṣyate a pakṣyate
translated: 'Is accepted' means is asserted.

analyzed: na kevalam atīndriya artha tattva niścayāya iti caśabda arthaḥ
translated: The meaning of the word 'ca' (and) is that it is not only for the ascertainment of the truth of things beyond the senses.

analyzed: kvacid anyathā ced yatra śruti ādi ānukūlyam tad avirodhaḥ
translated: If it is otherwise in some cases, then there is no contradiction with that which is favorable to the scriptures etc.

analyzed: pūrva uttara avirodhāya tattva niścayāya ca kāraṇa tayā iṣyate
translated: It is accepted as the cause for the non-contradiction of the previous and subsequent [passages] and for the ascertainment of the truth.

analyzed: na anyathā na anyā pṛthak anumā kvacid vākye
translated: Not otherwise, not any other inference anywhere else even in a sentence.

original: kutaḥ / yat sā anumā kevalānumā yathākāmā tasmāditi yojyam /
analyzed: kutas yat sā anumā kevala anumā yathākāmā tasmāt iti yojyam
translated: Why? That which is inference is mere inference as desired. Therefore, it should be connected thus.

analyzed: yathākāmā anumā iti ekam padam vā
translated: Or it is one word 'yathākāmānumā'.

analyzed: yathākāmā ca sā anumā iti vigrahaḥ
translated: The analysis is 'yathākāmā ca sā anumā'.

analyzed: tathātve yasmāt eṣā anapagā na tasmāt sā na ukta phala artham apekṣyate
translated: In that case, since this is not removed from that, it is not accepted for the sake of the stated result.

analyzed: anyathā yuktim vinā na iti āvṛttyā anvayaḥ  atas eva sudhāyām yathāyogya akhila jña tā
translated: 'Otherwise', the repetition is connected as 'not without reasoning'.🔽For this very reason, in the Sudhā,

analyzed: iti ekam padam iti uktam
translated: it is said to be one word 'yathāyogyākhilajñatā'.

analyzed: iti śabdasya skānde iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: The word 'iti' is connected with 'skānda'.

analyzed: na eṣā tarkeṇa matiḥ āpaneyā
translated: 'This understanding is not to be removed by reasoning'.

analyzed: kaṭha iti ca
translated: Kaṭha Upaniṣad.

original: spaṣṭoktitvātprathamaṃ smṛtimupanyasyātraiva arthe śrutisammatiṃ cāha naiṣeti /
analyzed: spaṣṭa ukti tvāt prathamam smṛtim upanyasya atra eva arthe śruti sammatim ca āha na eṣā iti
translated: Because of the clear statement, he first mentions smrti and then, in this very matter, states the agreement with scripture, saying na iṣe.

analyzed: āpaneyā iti atra ā apa iti vicchedaḥ
translated: Here, in āpaneya, there is a break after ā ape.

analyzed: viruddha arthayoḥ upasargayoḥ krameṇa sambandhaḥ
translated: The two prefixes with contradictory meanings are connected in order.

analyzed: tathā ca eṣā
translated: And thus, this [means]

analyzed: para brahma viṣayā matiḥ
translated: the understanding [that is] about the supreme Brahman.🔽It should not be brought in [i.e., produced]

analyzed: śuṣka tarkeṇa āneyā  utpādyā apaneyā
translated: by dry reasoning,🔽nor should it be taken away [i.e., removed].

original: nirākāryā ca na bhavatītyarthaḥ /🔽'proktānyena sujñānāya preṣṭha' /
analyzed: nirākāryā ca na bhavati iti arthaḥ  proktā anyena su jñānāya preṣṭha
translated: The meaning is that it should not be done away with.

analyzed: iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder of the sentence is: proktānyena su-jñānāya preṣṭha.

analyzed: preṣṭha iti naciketasam prati yamasya sambuddhiḥ
translated: The address of Yama to Naciketas is preṣṭha.

analyzed: anyena anyatva jñāninā jīva īśvara ādi bheda jñāninā bhagavat bhakti ādimatā iti yāvat
translated: Anyena, by another, by one who knows the difference, who knows the difference between the individual soul and the Lord, etc., who has devotion to the Lord, and so on.

analyzed: ācāryeṇa proktā
translated: Proktā by the teacher.

analyzed: tad upadesāt jātā su jñānāya
translated: Su-jñānāya, for the sake of good knowledge, which arises from his instruction.

analyzed: syāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: may it be.

analyzed: iti ca iti caḥ samuccaye
translated: Iti [means] thus. Ca [means] and.

original: tathā ca iti kaṭhaśrutau coktamiti sambandhaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca iti kaṭhaśrutau ca uktam iti sambandhaḥ
translated: And thus, the connection is: it is said in the Katha Upanishad.

analyzed: asmin asya ca tad yogam śāsti  /
translated: It teaches the connection of this with that here.

analyzed: asya jīvasya
translated: Of this, of the individual soul.

analyzed: yukti samuccaye caśabdaḥ
translated: The word ca [means] and in the sense of conjunction.

original: 'so 'śnute sarvān kāmān saha brahmaṇā vipaścitā' / tai / /
analyzed: saḥ śnute sarvān kāmān saha brahmaṇā vipaścitā taiḥ
translated: 'He enjoys all desires together with the learned Brahman.' Taitt.

analyzed: anilayane bhayam pratiṣṭhām vindate taiḥ
translated: 'In the abode of the wind, he attains fearlessness and support.' Taitt.

analyzed: etam ānanda mayam ātmānam upasaṅkrāmati tai ityādi
translated: 'He approaches this Self which is made up of bliss.' Taitt.

analyzed: nanu astu ānanda mayena brahmaṇā hiraṇyagarbha ādi jīvānām bhedaḥ
translated: Now, let it be that there is difference between the individual souls such as Hiraṇyagarbha and others and the Brahman which is made up of bliss.

analyzed: tathā api saḥ vyāvahārikaḥ saṃsāraḥ eva asti
translated: Even so, that is worldly existence itself.

analyzed: na pāramārthikaḥ muktau api
translated: It is not ultimate, even in liberation.

analyzed: udāhṛta śrutīnām sāṃsārika bheda paratva upapatteḥ iti āśaṅkām pariharat sūtram paṭhati asmin iti
translated: Because it is possible that the quoted passages refer to the worldly difference. To remove this doubt, he quotes the sutra 'asmin'.

analyzed: atra asya iti na ānanda maya parāmarśaḥ  kintu na itaraḥ iti ukta jīvasya iti āha asya iti
translated: Here, 'asya' does not refer to the one made up of bliss.🔽But it refers to the individual soul mentioned as 'not that', says 'asya'.

original: asyānyasya ceti pratītinirāsāya caśabdaṃ vyākhyāti yuktīti /
analyzed: asya anyasya ca iti pratīti nirāsāya caśabdam vyākhyāti yukti iti
translated: To remove the understanding of 'asya' as 'of this other', he explains the word 'ca' as 'yukti'.

analyzed: asti iti śeṣaḥ
translated: 'Exists' is implied.

analyzed: kim tat yoga śāsanam iti atas āha saḥ u śnute iti
translated: What is that teaching of yoga? To this he says 'so ʼśnute'.

analyzed: kriyā viśeṣaṇam etat
translated: This is a qualification of the verb.

analyzed: lupta vibhaktikaḥ vā nirdeśaḥ
translated: Or it is a statement with the case ending omitted.

analyzed: tathā ca ityādi śāsti 🔽ityādinā śāsti iti vā anvayaḥ
translated: And thus it teaches.🔽Or the construction is 'teaches thus'.

original: anena na kevalaṃ bhedavyapadeśādānandamayena jīvānāṃ bhedaḥ siddhaḥ /
analyzed: anena na kevalam bheda vyapadeśāt ānanda mayena jīvānām bhedaḥ siddhaḥ
translated: By this (argument) it is not only established that there is difference between the individual souls and the one consisting of bliss on account of the declaration of difference;

original: kiṃ nāma / yato 'smin prakaraṇe asya jīvasyānenānandamayena saha 'asmiṃśca' /🔽mokṣe 'pi 'yogaṃ' /
analyzed: kim nāma yatas smin prakaraṇe asya jīvasya anena ānanda mayena saha asmin ca  mokṣe pi yogam
translated: but also because in this section the text declares the connection of this individual soul with that consisting of bliss even in the state of liberation.🔽And also because the text declares the connection of this individual soul with that consisting of bliss even in the state of liberation.🔽And also because the text declares the connection of this individual soul with that consisting of bliss even in the state of liberation.

analyzed: sambandham śrutiḥ śāsti
translated: And also because the text declares the connection of this individual soul with that consisting of bliss even in the state of liberation.

original: ato na tadaikyaṃ jīvānāṃ nāpi sāṃsārika eva bhedaḥ /
analyzed: atas na tad aikyam jīvānām nā api sāṃsārikaḥ eva bhedaḥ
translated: Therefore, the identity of the individual souls with Brahman is not true, nor is the difference between them confined to the state of transmigration.

analyzed: na ca etāvatā katham bheda siddhiḥ

analyzed: sambandhasya bheda sāpekṣa tvāt  yat vā yasmāt asmin
translated: Because the connection depends on difference.

analyzed: prakaraṇa dvaye pi asya
translated: Or, because in both these sections,

analyzed: jīvasya tad yogam  taiḥ ānanda maya ādyaiḥ yogam sambandham śāsti
translated: of this individual soul,🔽the text declares the connection with those consisting of bliss etc.

analyzed: pratipādayati phala tvena śrutiḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the text declares the connection with them as the result.

original: tasmādānandamayo na jīvakośādiriti sūtrārtha ukto bhavati /
analyzed: tasmāt ānanda mayaḥ na jīva kośa ādiḥ iti sūtra arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: Therefore, the meaning of the sutra is stated that the one consisting of bliss is not the individual soul, the sheath etc.🔽The knower of Brahman,

analyzed: saḥ brahma jñānī vipaścitā  sarvajñena jñātena eva para brahmaṇā
translated: by the omniscient, the knower of Brahman,

analyzed: caturmukhena ca saha sarvān
translated: together with the four-faced one, enjoys

analyzed: sva yogya kāmān aśnute

analyzed: muktau prāpnoti iti śruti arthaḥ

analyzed: adṛśye na ātmye  iti vākyam tu prāk eva vyākhyātam
translated: The sentence in the unseen, in the inmost soul has already been explained.

analyzed: dehāt utkrāntaḥ jīvaḥ etam
translated: The individual soul, having departed from the body, goes to

analyzed: āndamayam
translated: the one consisting of bliss,

analyzed: pūrṇānandam paramātmānam upasaṅkrāmati  tad samīpam prāpnoti iti anuvāka antara gata tṛtīya vākyasya arthaḥ
translated: the Supreme Self, full of bliss. It approaches🔽means it reaches near Him. This is the meaning of the third sentence in another anuvaka.

analyzed: iti ānanda maya adhikaraṇam

analyzed: adṛśye na ātmye iti uktam

analyzed: tat ca adṛśya tvam antar praviṣṭam kartāram etam

analyzed: antar candramasi manasā carantam

analyzed: saha eva santam na vijānanti devāḥ

analyzed: iti antar sthasya kasyacid ucyate
translated: Tai. Ā.

analyzed: sa ca indraḥ rājā

analyzed: tai ā sapta yuñjanti tai ā

analyzed: ityādibhiḥ anyaḥ pratīyate

analyzed: tasmāt saḥ eva ānanda mayaḥ iti na mantavyam

analyzed: atra adhikaraṇe deha anta stha tva rūpa liṅga samanvayaḥ

analyzed: kriyate iti śāstra adhyāya pāda saṅgatayaḥ siddhāḥ iti āśayena pūrva adhikaraṇa tad viṣaya vākya saṅgatī

analyzed: darśayati adṛśyaḥ iti

analyzed: pūrva adhikaraṇa udāhṛte adṛśye anātmye
translated: In the sentence in the unseen, not the self quoted in the previous section,

analyzed: iti vākye ānanda mayasya kārtsnyena ajñeya tva rūpam adṛśya tvam uktam iti arthaḥ
translated: the state of being unseen, which is the complete unknowability of the Bliss-Body, is stated. This is the meaning.

analyzed: tatas kim iti atas āha tat ca iti

analyzed: caśabdaḥ eva arthe

analyzed: iti vākye na vijānanti iti anena kasyacid antasthasya ucyate

analyzed: deva ajñeya tvāt kaimutyena pratipādyate iti arthaḥ

translated: By this, since the state of being unseen and the state of being the Bliss-Body are raised as belonging to something else through dwelling within, the connection by raising is stated with the previous section.

original: hṛdayaguhāntaḥpraviṣṭaṃ jagatkartāraṃ candramasyantarmanasā svecchayā carantaṃ sahaiva sthitam etaṃ devāstattvābhimāninaḥ kārtsnyena na vijānantīti
analyzed: hṛdaya guhā antar praviṣṭam jagatkartāram candramasi antar manasā sva icchayā carantam saha eva sthitam etam devāḥ tattva abhimāninaḥ kārtsnyena na vijānanti iti
translated: The gods, who are identified with the principles, do not know completely the creator of the world who has entered within the cave of the heart, who moves within the moon with his own mind by his own will, and who dwells together with them.

analyzed: śruti arthaḥ

analyzed: pūrvapakṣe tu iyam anyaparā

analyzed: caśabdaḥ va dhāraṇe

analyzed: anyaḥ eva bhavet kutas

analyzed: antar śrūyamāṇaḥ viṣṇuḥ eva

translated: 'Moving in the mind within the ocean,

analyzed: sa hi kṣīra samudra śīyī

analyzed: kutas na mantavyam iti atas tatra hetu tvena sūtram upanyasya vyācaṣṭe antar iti  sūtre ntar iti uddeśya bhāge apekṣitam padam adhyāhṛtya darśayati śrūyamāṇe iti

analyzed: antar stha tvena śrutyā ucyamānaḥ iti arthaḥ  vidheya samarpakasya anuvṛttasya tat tu

analyzed: iti asya artham āha viṣṇuḥ eva iti

analyzed: taittirīya upaniṣad gata bhinna bhinna vākya udāharaṇa pūrvakam hetvaṃśam vyācaṣṭe antar iti

analyzed: ityādi iti

original: tasya dharmāstaddharmāḥ teṣāmupadeśo vacanaṃ ityādirūpaścāsau taddharmopadeśaśca ityāditaddharmopadeśaḥ tasmādityarthaḥ /
analyzed: tasya dharmāḥ tad dharmāḥ teṣām upadeśaḥ vacanam ityādi rūpaḥ ca asau tad dharma upadeśaḥ ca ityādi tad dharma upadeśaḥ tasmāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The teachings of those attributes are the statements of those attributes. The beginning is in the form of thus, etc. The beginning is the teaching of those attributes. The meaning is from that.

analyzed: yat vā lupta vibhaktikaḥ yam nirdeśaḥ

analyzed: tathā ca ityādeḥ upadeśāt iti arthaḥ  samudāya ekavacanam etat

analyzed: anena antar praviṣṭam  iti vākye antar śrūyamāṇaḥ
translated: By this, within.🔽In the sentence heard within,

analyzed: hṛdaya antar stha tvena śruti uktaḥ viṣṇuḥ eva

analyzed: na tu anyaḥ kutas

translated: Because of the teaching of the attributes of that Vishnu, such as existing in the milk ocean of dissolution, being knowable by Brahman, being obtainable through Brahman's austerity, being the essence of the universe, etc., in that,

analyzed: antar śrute tena antar ityādinā upadeśāt

analyzed: ukta tvāt iti sūtra arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: The meaning of the sutra is stated to be from the teaching.

analyzed: upadeśāt iti antasya sūtrasya tasmāt anyaḥ eva iti na mantavyam iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: The end of the sutra from the teaching is connected with should not be thought to be different from that.

analyzed: brahmā vartamāna caturmukhaḥ samudre

analyzed: pralaya abdhau kṣīrābdhau ca antararṇe

analyzed: jale kṣīre ca manasā

analyzed: sva icchayā sañcarantam daśahotāram

original: jñānakarmākhyadaśendriyeṣu viṣayahotāraṃ tattadviṣayasthāpakaṃ daśendriyāṇi jīvena viṣayeṣu juhvataṃ vā viṣṇum 'anvavindat' / vyajānāt /

analyzed: kavayaḥ jñāninaḥ samudre  kṣīra pralaya abdhyoḥ antar sthitam vicakṣate jānanti

analyzed: vedhasaḥ bhūta bhaviṣyat brahmāṇaḥ marīciḥ mita ruj tvataḥ

analyzed: iti chāndogya bhāṣya ukteḥ

According to the Tattva Pradipika, the wise ones,

translated: Or there is a single relation. The wise ones,

analyzed: kavayaḥ aṇḍakośam

analyzed: brahmāṇḍa ākhya sthānam yasya

analyzed: viṣṇoḥ śuṣmam
translated: The place called the Cosmic Egg belongs to Him, i.e., to Vishnu.

analyzed: vīryam tad upādānakam āhuḥ iti śruti arthaḥ
translated: His strength, i.e., His power, is said to be the material cause of that. This is the meaning of the Vedic text.

original: viriñcivākyasyāsya 'prāṇa ulbaṃ tena kḷpto amṛtenāhamasmi' /🔽iti vākyaśeṣaḥ /
analyzed: viriñci vākyasya asya prāṇaḥ ulbam tena kḷptaḥ amṛtena aham asmi  iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: The remainder of this statement by Brahma is: The vital air is the outer membrane, by that I am formed by the immortal.

analyzed: tasya ulbam  jarāyuḥ prāṇaḥ
translated: The remainder of this statement is: The outer membrane

analyzed: antar prāvaraṇam yena saha eva jāyate  tena amṛtena aham
translated: is the outer covering, by which one is born along with it.🔽By that, by the immortal, I

analyzed: smi iti arthaḥ tattvapradīpe bhihitaḥ
translated: am formed. This is the meaning stated in the Tattvadipika.

original: kṣīrasamudrasthatvasya viṣṇuliṅgatvaṃ kuta ityata āha sa hīti /
analyzed: kṣīrasamudra stha tvasya viṣṇu liṅga tvam kutas iti atas āha sa hi iti
translated: How is it that being situated in the milk ocean is a mark of Vishnu? To this he says: He indeed.

analyzed: saḥ viṣṇuḥ hi śabdena loka prasiddha tvāt iti hetu sūcitaḥ
translated: He, Vishnu, the word indeed indicates the reason that it is well-known in the world.

analyzed: tasya ca vīrya maṇḍa kośaḥ

analyzed: saḥ abhidhyāya śarīrāt svāt sisṛkṣuḥ vividhāḥ prajāḥ
translated: Desiring to create various beings, He, reflecting, from His own body,

analyzed: apaḥ eva sasarja ādau tāsu vīryam avāsṛjat
translated: created water first, and in them He emitted His strength.

analyzed: tat aṇaḍam abhavat haimam sahasrāṃśu sama prabham

analyzed: yasmin jajñe svayam brahmā sarva loka pitāmahaḥ
translated: in which Brahma himself, the grandfather of all worlds, was born.

original: āpo nārā iti proktā āpo vai narasūnavaḥ /
analyzed: āpaḥ nārāḥ iti proktāḥ āpaḥ vai nara sūnavaḥ
translated: Water is called Nara, and water is indeed the offspring of Nara.

original: ayanaṃ tasya tāḥ pūrvaṃ tena nārāyaṇaḥ smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: ayanam tasya tāḥ pūrvam tena nārāyaṇaḥ smṛtaḥ

analyzed: iti vyāsasmṛteḥ

analyzed: astu viṣṇoḥ kṣīrābdhi stha tvam liṅgam prasiddha tvāt
translated: Let the abode in the Milk Ocean be a mark of Viṣṇu because of its well-known nature.

original: tathāpi pralayārṇavasthatvasya brahmāṇḍavīryatvasya ca kuto viṣṇudharmatvamityatastayorviṣṇudharmatve pramāṇaṃ vaktuṃ pratijānīte tasyeti🔽'aṇḍakośo' / brahmāṇḍākhyasthānaṃ 'tasya' /
analyzed: tathā api pralaya arṇava stha tvasya brahmāṇḍa vīrya tvasya ca kutas viṣṇu dharma tvam iti atas tayoḥ viṣṇu dharma tve pramāṇam vaktum pratijānīte  tasya iti  aṇḍakośaḥ brahmāṇḍa ākhya sthānam tasya
translated: Still, how can the abode in the ocean of dissolution and the semen of the Cosmic Egg be the attributes of Viṣṇu? To state the proof for their being the attributes of Viṣṇu, he promises: That, etc.🔽The abode called Cosmic Egg is the semen of Him, Viṣṇu.

analyzed: viṣṇoḥ vīryam iti arthaḥ
translated: This is the meaning.

analyzed: caśabdāt saḥ pralaya samudra śāyī iti pratijñā sūcyate
translated: From the word 'ca' (and), the promise that He is the one who lies in the ocean of dissolution is indicated.

analyzed: tasya eva iti avadhāraṇe vā caśabdaḥ
translated: Or, the word 'ca' (and) is for restriction to Him alone.

analyzed: tathātve pratijñāntaram upalakṣaṇīyam
translated: If so, another promise should be inferred.

analyzed: atas eva pralaya abdhi śāyi tve āpaḥ nārāḥ
translated: For this very reason, in the abode in the ocean of dissolution, the water is Nārā,

original: iti paścātpramāṇopanyāsaḥ śrutāvaṇḍakośaśabdaśravaṇe 'pi pratyayasya svārthikatvāttattyāgenāṇḍakośa ityevānūditam /
analyzed: iti paścāt pramāṇa upanyāsaḥ śrutau aṇḍakośa śabda śravaṇe pi pratyayasya svārthika tvāt tad tyāgena āṇḍakośaḥ iti eva anūditam
translated: thus the proof is stated later. Even though the word 'aṇḍakośa' (Cosmic Egg) is heard in the Śruti, because the suffix has its own meaning, it is repeated as 'aṇḍakośa' by omitting that.

analyzed: śrutau api tathā eva chedaḥ vā
translated: Even in the Śruti, the cutting off is the same.

analyzed: saḥ vāsudevāt jātaḥ viṣṇuḥ svāt
translated: He, Viṣṇu, born from Vāsudeva, is His own.

analyzed: svakīyāt śarīrāt vividhāḥ prajāḥ sisṛkṣuḥ  sraṣṭum icchuḥ abhidhyāya  vicintya ādau
translated: Desiring to create various beings from his own body.🔽Desiring to create, he contemplated.🔽Having thought, in the beginning.

analyzed: aṇḍa sṛṣṭeḥ pūrvam eva apaḥ

analyzed: tad āvaraṇa rūpāḥ sasarja

analyzed: tāsu apsu vīryam avāsṛjat

analyzed: nyadhāt māyā dvāra iti śeṣaḥ  haimam hiraṇya ātmakam sahasra aṃśu sama prabham
translated: He placed it through Maya, the remainder.🔽That golden, having the essence of gold, having the luster of a thousand suns,

analyzed: sūrya sama prakāśam tat  vīryam brahmāṇḍa ākhyam abhavat

analyzed: yasmin aṇḍe

analyzed: brahmā catur mukhaḥ svayam

analyzed: yatas āpaḥ nara sūnavaḥ

analyzed: narasya viṣṇoḥ sūnavaḥ

analyzed: viṣṇuḥ naraḥ nāśāt paraḥ yatas
translated: Because Vishnu is Nara, beyond destruction.

analyzed: iti bhāgavata tātparyokteḥ
translated: As stated in the Bhavata Tattva.

analyzed: atas nārāḥ proktāḥ yena kāraṇena pūrvam
translated: Therefore, the waters are said to be Nara, for the reason that in the beginning,

analyzed: pralaye tāḥ
translated: At the time of dissolution, those waters

analyzed: āpaḥ tasya viṣṇoḥ ayanam tena saḥ nārāyaṇaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: Are the abode of that Vishnu. Therefore he is known as Narayana.

analyzed: tad śabda vācya tvena smṛti uktaḥ iti arthaḥ yadi api
translated: The meaning is that he is stated in the Smriti as being denoted by that word. Although

analyzed: puruṣaḥ ṇḍam vinirbhidya yadā ādau sa vinirgataḥ

analyzed: ātmanaḥ yanam anvicchan apaḥ srākṣīt śuciḥ śucīḥ

analyzed: iti bhāgavate
translated: Thus it is said in the Bhagavata Purana.

translated: The Vishnu who entered the egg broke the egg and manifested.

analyzed: saḥ sṛjat tatas nārā
translated: He created the waters, then the Naras (men),

analyzed: iti bhāgavata tātparye ca aṇḍa sṛṣṭi anantaram ap sṛṣṭiḥ ucyate
translated: Thus it is said in the Bhagavata Tattva. The creation of water is mentioned after the creation of the egg.

analyzed: sa hi pralaya samudra śāyī yatas  iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ  aham tat tejaḥ raśmīn nārāyaṇam puruṣam jātam agratas
translated: For He is the one who lies in the ocean of dissolution.'🔽'I am that effulgence, the rays, the Narayana, the Being born in the beginning.

analyzed: puruṣāt prakṛtiḥ jagat aṇḍam
translated: From the Being, Prakriti (Nature), the universe, the egg.'

analyzed: iti catur veda śikhāyām

original: itaśca brahmāṇḍajanakavīryatvaṃ pralayasthatvaṃ ca tasyaiva jñāyata ityāha ahamiti /🔽'tripuruṣaṃ māyābījamajāyata' /
analyzed: itas ca brahmāṇḍa janaka vīrya tvam pralaya stha tvam ca tasya eva jñāyate iti āha aham iti  tripuruṣam māyā bījam ajāyata
translated: And for this reason also, His being the semen that generates the universe and His being present in dissolution are known. Thus it is said 'I' etc.

analyzed: iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: The remaining part of the sentence is 'The seed of Maya, consisting of three Purushas, was born.'

analyzed: tat iti sarvanāma śabdaḥ

analyzed: athavā sarvanāma śabdaḥ

original: ata eva ṭīkāyāṃ tadaheyamiti vyutkramaḥ kṛtaḥ /

translated: For this very reason, in the commentary, the order is reversed, saying that which is not to be abandoned.

analyzed: tathā ca tat prasiddham vyāptam vā aham
translated: And thus, that which is well-known to it, or pervaded by it, is I.

original: aheyaṃ ratiḥ śaṃ ca mitamasyeti raśmirjīvaḥ tamindayati prerayatīti raśmīt jīvaprerakaṃ /
analyzed: aheyam ratiḥ śam ca mitam asya iti raśmiḥ jīvaḥ tam indayati prerayati iti jīva prerakam
translated: Aham means that which is not to be abandoned, rati is bliss, and mitam means its measure. Rashi is the individual soul. Indayat means it impels. Rashi is the impeller of the individual soul.

original: inda preraṇe iti dhātoḥ ayaṃ dakārāntaḥ śabdaḥ /
analyzed: inda preraṇe iti dhātoḥ ayam dakāra antaḥ śabdaḥ
translated: The verbal root ind means to impel. This word ends with the letter da.

original: anukṛtyadhikaraṇe tu indhī dīptāviti dhātuvyākhyānāt raśmīt bhagavadapekṣayā raśmirūpāṇām alpānāṃ sūryāditejasāṃ prakāśakamiti vyākhyātam /
analyzed: anukṛti adhikaraṇe tu indhī dīptau iti dhātu vyākhyānāt bhagavat apekṣayā raśmi rūpāṇām alpānām sūrya ādi tejasām prakāśakam iti vyākhyātam
translated: But in the section on anu-kriti (similarity), because the verbal root indhi is explained as to burn, rashi is explained as the illuminator of the small forms of solar and other light rays from the point of view of the Lord.

analyzed: tatra dhakāra antaḥ gnīdh śabda vat ayam śabdaḥ jñātavyaḥ  tejaḥ jagat prakāśakam puruṣam
translated: There, this word should be known to end with the letter dha, like the word agni (fire).

original: pūrṇaṣaḍguṇaṃ nārāyaṇaṃ tadākhyaṃ brahma teja iti vā /
analyzed: pūrṇa ṣaḍguṇam nārāyaṇam tad ākhyam brahma tejaḥ iti vā
translated: Tejas (light) is the illuminator of the world. Purusha (person) is the one who possesses the six perfect qualities, Narayana. That which is called Narayana is Brahman, or the light of Brahman.

analyzed: agratas pralaye jātam
translated: Agratas (in front) means before creation. Jatam (born) means existing.

analyzed: sthitam tasmāt nārāyaṇa ākhya puruṣāt agratas
translated: It exists agratas (in front), that is, before the person called Narayana.

analyzed: prathamam prakṛtiḥ
translated: Prakriti (primordial matter) is born first.

analyzed: cetanā jāyate gacchati iti jagat jīva samudāyaḥ

analyzed: jātam iti asya ubhayatra yathāyogyam sambandhaḥ
translated: Jatam (born) is connected with both as appropriate.

analyzed: janiḥ ca yathā yogyā grāhyā
translated: And birth should be taken as appropriate.

analyzed: paścāt aṇḍam ca
translated: Then, 'and the egg'.

analyzed: tri puruṣam
translated: 'Endowed with three Purushas'.

analyzed: brahma vāyu rudra ākhya puruṣatraya yuktam māyābījam
translated: Endowed with the three Purushas called Brahma, Vayu and Rudra, 'the seed of Maya'

analyzed: prakṛti upādānakam ajāyata iti tattva pradīpa diśā śruti arthaḥ
translated: is produced, which has Prakriti as its material cause. This is the meaning of the Shruti according to the Tattva Pradipika.

analyzed: catur veda śikhāyām iti asya vacanāt iti adhyāhāreṇa tasya iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning of 'in the Chatur Veda Shikha' is supplied as 'because of the statement'. It is connected with 'that' by 'asya'.

analyzed: bheda vyapadeśāt ca anyaḥ
translated: And because of the designation of difference, He is different.

analyzed: indrasya ātmā nihitaḥ pañca hotā
translated: 'The soul of Indra is placed as the fivefold priest.'

analyzed: vāyoḥ ātmānam kavayaḥ nicikyuḥ
translated: 'The wise have discerned the soul of Vayu.'

analyzed: antar āditye manasā carantam
translated: 'Moving in the heart by the mind,

analyzed: devānām hṛdayam brahma anvavindat
translated: Brahma has found the heart of the gods.'

analyzed: iti ādi bheda vyapadeśāt
translated: Because of the designation of difference in these and other places.

analyzed: yadi evam samudra stha tva ādi liṅgāt antar sthaḥ viṣṇuḥ
translated: If Vishnu is the inner self because of the indications of being in the ocean etc.,

analyzed: tarhi tena antar sthena viṣṇunā indra ādīnām abhedaḥ tra vivakṣitaḥ stu
translated: then let the non-difference of Indra etc. with that inner Vishnu be intended here.

analyzed: indra ādi prāpaka ka śruti ādeḥ api sadbhāvāt
translated: Because the Shruti etc. which establish Indra etc. also exist.

analyzed: śruti ādeḥ ca svabhāvataḥ liṅgasya niravakāśa tayā balavat tvena anyatara bādhena anyatara pakṣa nirṇaya ayogāt
translated: And because the Shruti etc. are stronger than the inherent indication by being non-interpretable, it is not possible to determine one side by the contradiction of the other.

original: evaṃ ca pūrvottarapakṣadvaye anyonyaṃ bādhyabādhakabhāvaśūnye sati tadanyathānupapattyā
analyzed: evam ca pūrva uttara pakṣa dvaye anyonyam bādhya bādhaka bhāva śūnye sati tad anyathā anupapattyā
translated: And thus, in the two positions of prima facie view and established view, being devoid of the relation of being the object of refutation and the means of refutation between each other,

original: antaḥsthena viṣṇunendrādīnāmabhedaḥ prāpta ityāśaṅkāṃ pariharatsūtraṃ paṭhitvā vyācaṣṭe bhedeti /
analyzed: antar sthena viṣṇunā indra ādīnām abhedaḥ prāptaḥ iti āśaṅkām pariharat sūtram paṭhitvā vyācaṣṭe bheda iti

analyzed: taittirīye indrasya
translated: In the Taittiriya Upanishad, of Indra

analyzed: iti ekaḥ bheda vyapadeśaḥ  vāyoḥ iti anyaḥ
translated: is one statement of difference.🔽Of Vayu🔽is another.🔽Within

analyzed: antar iti aparaḥ
translated: is another.🔽Of the gods

analyzed: devānām iti ca itaraḥ
translated: is another.

analyzed: ādi śabdena amṛtam devānām āyuḥ prajānām indram rājānam savitāram

analyzed: iti ādikam gṛhyate

analyzed: anena sūtre vidheya samuccaya arthaka ca śabdasya bhinna krameṇa anvayena na kevalam antar śrūyamāṇaḥ viṣṇuḥ

analyzed: kintu indra ādibhyaḥ nyaḥ ca
translated: but he is also different from Indra and others.

original: kutaḥ / tasyendrādyantaryāmitvadantassthatvakathanena tebhyo bhedokteriti sūtrārtha ukto bhavati /

analyzed: bādhaka abhāvāt

analyzed: indrasya ātmā antaryāmī ādāna ādi kartā vā
translated: He is the inner controller of Indra, or the agent of taking up and so on.🔽He is

analyzed: sarva hṛdayeṣu nihitaḥ
