translated: In the Padma (Purana) - after this, the sentence Because it is said that the words 'I' and so on are primary in the internal controller, the teaching of 'I' and so on from the point of view of scripture is indeed appropriate.

analyzed: iti vākya śeṣaḥ
translated: This is the remainder of the sentence.

analyzed: aham manuḥ abhavam sūryaḥ ca
translated: I was Manu, and the sun.

analyzed: ityādi vat
translated: Like the Rig Veda and so on.

original: nanvantaryāmiṇi ahamādiprayogādarśanāt tadayoga ityāśaṅkāṃ sūtroktadṛṣṭāntavivaraṇena pariharati ahamiti //
analyzed: nanu antaryāmiṇi aham ādi prayoga adarśanāt tad ayogaḥ iti āśaṅkām sūtra ukta dṛṣṭānta vivaraṇena pariharati aham iti
translated: Since the application of I and so on to the internal controller is not seen, there is an inadmissibility. This doubt is removed by explaining the example stated in the aphorism with I and so on.

original: 'ahaṃ' / vāmadevasaṃjñakaṛṣyantaryāmī tattadantaryāmitayā manuḥ sūryaścābhavamiti ṛṅmantrārthaḥ /🔽ādipadena 'ahaṃ kakṣīvānṛṣirasmi vipro 'haṃ kutsam' / ṛ / /
analyzed: aham vāmadeva saṃjñaka ṛṣi antaryāmī tad tad antaryāmi tayā manuḥ sūryaḥ ca abhavam iti ṛc mantra arthaḥ  ādi padena aham kakṣīvān ṛṣiḥ asmi vipraḥ ham kutsam
translated: The meaning of the Ṛg mantra is: I became Manu and the Sun, as the inner controller in the form of the sage named Vāmadeva, by means of that and that inner control.

analyzed: iti ādikam gṛhyate
translated: By the word 'ādi' (etc.), the following is included: 'I am the sage Kakṣīvān, I am the brāhmaṇa Kutsa.' Ṛg Veda 1.112.5.

analyzed: ityādi vat evamādi prayoga vat iti asya śāstra dṛṣṭyā upadeśaḥ
translated: 'Like this' means like the usage of 'ādi' (etc.). The meaning is: 'The teaching is according to the view of the scriptures.'

analyzed: iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: This is connected with this.

original: jīvamukhyaprāṇaliṅgān neti cen nopāsātraividhyādāśritatvād iha tadyogāt / / / /
analyzed: jīva mukhya prāṇa liṅgāt na iti ced na upāsā traividhyāt āśrita tvāt iha tad yogāt
translated: If it is argued that it is not so because of the indications of the individual soul and the principal life force, it is not so, because of the threefoldness of meditation and because of dependence on that here.

analyzed: tāvanti śata saṃvatsarasya ahnām sahasrāṇi bhavanti
translated: 'There are as many thousands of days in a hundred years.' Aitareya Āraṇyaka 2.2.1.

original: iti jīvaliṅgaṃ prāṇasaṃvādādimukhyaprāṇaliṅgaṃ tasmāt neti cet
analyzed: iti jīva liṅgam prāṇa saṃvāda ādi mukhya prāṇa liṅgam tasmāt na iti ced
translated: This is the indication of the individual soul. The dialogue of the life force etc. is the indication of the principal life force. Therefore, it is not so, if it is argued.

analyzed: punaruktam ākṣipya samādadhat sūtram upanyasya ākṣepa aṃśam tāvat vyācaṣṭe jīva iti
translated: Having refuted the repetition, the author presents the sūtra to establish it. He first explains the part of the objection. He says 'jīva' etc.

analyzed: anusandhīyate
translated: is connected

analyzed: uktam iti ca śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is also stated.

original: saṃvādo vivādaḥ kalahaḥ prāṇasya prāṇaissaha saṃvāda iti vigrahaḥ /
analyzed: saṃvādaḥ vivādaḥ kalahaḥ prāṇasya prāṇaiḥ saha saṃvādaḥ iti vigrahaḥ
translated: The dialogue is a dispute, a quarrel, a dialogue of the life force with the life forces. This is the analysis.

original: tathā ca yasmādatra prakaraṇe 'taṃ śataṃ varṣāṇyabhyārcat tasmācchataṃ varṣāṇi puruṣāyuṣo bhavanti' / ai /ā / /🔽ityanena yacchatasaṃvatsaraparyantaṃ prāṇasya jīvadehe 'vastānahetukaṃ śatāyuṣṭvarūpaṃ jīvaliṅgamuktaṃ tat 'tāvanti śatasaṃvatsarasyāhnāṃ sahasrāṇi
analyzed: tathā ca yasmāt atra prakaraṇe tam śatam varṣāṇi abhyārcat tasmāt śatam varṣāṇi puruṣa āyuṣaḥ bhavanti  iti anena yat śata saṃvatsara paryantam prāṇasya jīva dehe vastāna hetukam śata āyuḥ tva rūpam jīva liṅgam uktam tat tāvanti śata saṃvatsarasya ahnām sahasrāṇi
translated: And in this context, it is said: 'He worshipped for a hundred years. Therefore, the human lifespan is a hundred years.'

original: ityādinā bahuṣu sthaleṣu anusandhīyate /🔽yasmācca 'tā ahiṃsantāhamukthamahamukthamasmi' / ai /ā / /
analyzed: ityādinā bahuṣu sthaleṣu anusandhīyate  yasmāt ca tāḥ ahiṃsanta aham uktham aham uktham asmi
translated: Thus, the mark of the living being, in the form of a lifespan of a hundred years, which is the cause of the presence of the vital air in the body of the living being up to a hundred years, is referred to in many places beginning with 'as many thousands of years as there are in a hundred years of the sun's course'.

original: iti vākyena prāṇasya prāṇairindriyaiḥ saha saṃvādarūpamukhyaprāṇaliṅgamuktam /🔽yasmāccādipadagṛhītaṃ 'prāṇo vaṃśa iti sthaviraḥ śākalyastadyathā śālāvaṃśe sarve
analyzed: iti vākyena prāṇasya prāṇaiḥ indriyaiḥ saha saṃvāda rūpa mukhya prāṇa liṅgam uktam  yasmāt ca ādi pada gṛhītam prāṇaḥ vaṃśaḥ iti sthaviraḥ śākalyaḥ tat yathā śālā vaṃśe sarve
translated: And because of the statement 'They did not harm each other. I am the Udgītha. I am the Udgītha', the mark of the primary vital air in the form of a dialogue between the vital air and the sense organs is stated.

original: 'nye vaṃśāḥ samāhitāssyuḥ evamasmin prāṇe cakṣuśśrotraṃ mano vāgindriyāṇi śarīraṃ
analyzed: nye vaṃśāḥ samāhitāḥ syuḥ evam asmin prāṇe cakṣuḥ śrotram manaḥ vāc indriyāṇi śarīram
translated: And because of the statement 'The vital air is the bamboo', by the elder Śākalya, just as all the bamboos are collected in a bamboo grove, in the same way, in this vital air, the eye, ear, mind, speech, sense organs, and the body,

analyzed: sarva ātmā samāhitaḥ aiā
translated: all the self is collected.

original: iti vākyena sarvajīvendriyadehadhārakatvarūpaliṅgaṃ coktamasti tasmādayaṃ prāṇo na viṣṇuḥ /
analyzed: iti vākyena sarva jīva indriya deha dhāraka tva rūpa liṅgam ca uktam asti tasmāt ayam prāṇaḥ na viṣṇuḥ
translated: Thus, the indicative mark in the form of being the supporter of all living beings, sense organs and bodies is stated. Therefore, this vital air is not Vishnu.

analyzed: kintu jīva mukhya prāṇau eva iti yojanā
translated: But it is the individual soul and the chief vital air alone. This is the construction.

analyzed: yadi api tasmāt śatam varṣāṇi puruṣa āyuṣaḥ bhavanti
translated: Although the passage Therefore, the life span of a man is one hundred years

analyzed: iti śata āyuḥ tva liṅga pratipādaka vākyam eva udāharaṇīyam
translated: is to be cited as the passage that teaches the indicative mark of having a life span of one hundred years,

analyzed: na tu tāvanti iti vākyam
translated: not the passage So many.

original: tathāpi liṅgasya bahuṣu sthaleṣu anugamo 'stīti jñāpanāyopaniṣado jīvaliṅge tātparyamastīti jñāpayitum anusandhivākyamevodāhṛtam /
analyzed: tathā api liṅgasya bahuṣu sthaleṣu anugamaḥ sti iti jñāpanāya upaniṣadaḥ jīva liṅge tātparyam asti iti jñāpayitum anusandhi vākyam eva udāhṛtam
translated: Nevertheless, the Upanishad cites the connecting passage to show that there is a connection of the indicative mark of the individual soul in many places, and to show that there is a purpose in the Upanishad regarding the indicative mark of the individual soul.

original: siddhānte śrutyarthastu puruṣāyuṣaḥ śatasaṃvatsarasyāhnāṃ sahasrāṇi śatasaṃvatsarāntaḥpraviṣṭāharniyāmakasūryagatabhagavatpuruṣarūpāṇi tāvanti
analyzed: siddhānte śruti arthaḥ tu puruṣa āyuṣaḥ śata saṃvatsarasya ahnām sahasrāṇi śata saṃvatsara antar praviṣṭa ahar niyāmaka sūrya gata bhagavat puruṣa rūpāṇi tāvanti  /
translated: In the established conclusion, the meaning of the scripture is: As many thousands of days as there are in the human life span of one hundred years, so many thousands of the forms of the Lord in the sun, which regulate the days included in the one hundred years,

analyzed: sahasrāṇi
translated: so many thousands.

original: kiyanti / bṛhatīsahasragatākṣarāṇāṃ vācyāni puṃrūpāṇi yāvanti sahasrāṇi tāvanti /
analyzed: kiyanti bṛhatī sahasra gata akṣarāṇām vācyāni pum rūpāṇi yāvanti sahasrāṇi tāvanti
translated: How many? As many thousands of forms of males as are to be expressed by the letters contained in the Brihatī Sāman.

original: tathā ca tāni ṣaṭtriṃśatsahasrāṇi sampannāni bhavanti /
analyzed: tathā ca tāni ṣaṭtriṃśat sahasrāṇi sampannāni bhavanti
translated: And thus, those come to thirty-six thousand.

analyzed: tāḥ cakṣuḥ ādi devatāḥ ahiṃsanta  vivādam akurvan
translated: Those, the deities of the eye etc., did not injure, did not quarrel.

analyzed: kinu iti aham asya caturmukha dehasya ukthaḥ smi utthāpakaḥ smi iti
translated: But how? I am the Uktha of this four-faced body, I am the one who raises it up.

analyzed: na antar bahis sarva gata tvena iti upāsā traividhyāt iha āśrita tvāt ca
translated: No, because of the threefold meditation as being within, without, and all-pervading, and because of being based here.

analyzed: parihāra aṃśam vyācaṣṭe na iti
translated: He explains the part of the answer with the word no.

analyzed: prāṇaḥ viṣṇuḥ na iti na
translated: Prana is not Vishnu.

analyzed: kintu viṣṇuḥ eva ayam
translated: But this is Vishnu alone.

analyzed: na jīva ādiḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is, not the individual soul etc.

analyzed: kutas nā iti atas tatra prāgukta anugama hetu anuṣaṅgam
translated: From where is it not so? Therefore, the reason stated earlier is continued.

original: na coktajīvamukhyaprāṇaliṅgavirodha ityatastatrahetutvena yataḥ śāstradṛṣṭyā tvayamupadeśaḥ ityasyānuṣaṅgaṃ /
analyzed: na ca ukta jīva mukhya prāṇa liṅga virodhaḥ iti atas tatra hetu tvena yatas śāstra dṛṣṭyā tu ayam upadeśaḥ iti asya anuṣaṅgam
translated: And there is no contradiction with the indication of the individual soul and the principal life force mentioned earlier. Therefore, the reason for that is continued with because this instruction is from the viewpoint of the scriptures.

original: kimarthamantaryāmīti praśnasyāntarupāstyarthamiti parihāraṃ cābhipretya na copāsane 'vāntarabhedābhāva iti codyottaratvena pravṛttam 'upāsā' /
analyzed: kimartham antaryāmī iti praśnasya antar upāsti artham iti parihāram ca abhipretya na ca upāsane vā antara bheda abhāvaḥ iti codya uttara tvena pravṛttam upāsā
translated: With the intention of the question For what purpose is the immanent one? and the answer For the purpose of internal meditation, and with the intention of the objection There is no absence of internal divisions in meditation, the aphorism Meditation is begun as the answer.

analyzed: iti sūtra aṃśam vyācaṣṭe antar iti
translated: He explains the part of the aphorism Meditation with the word internal.

analyzed: gata tvena iti asya antar bahis sarva śabdaiḥ pratyekam sambandhaḥ
translated: The word as is connected with each of the words within, without, and all.

analyzed: iti śabdaḥ prakāra arthaḥ
translated: The word iti means in this way.

original: tathā ca dehāntargatatvena tadbahirgatatvena sarvagatatveneti prakāreṇa 'upāsātraividhyāt' /
analyzed: tathā ca deha antargata tvena tad bahis gata tvena sarvagata tvena iti prakāreṇa upāsā traividhyāt
translated: And thus, by the threefoldness of meditation, i.e., by the threefoldness of the meditation on the Lord.

analyzed: bhagavat upāsanasya trividha tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because the meditation on the Lord is threefold.

original: nanu tathāpi kathanaṃ vyarthaṃ vastuta upāsanātraividhyasyehānuktasyāntaryāmikathanāprayojakatvādityataḥ pravṛttam 'āśritatvāt' /
analyzed: nanu tathā api kathanam vyartham vastutas upāsanā traividhyasya iha anuktasya antaryāmi kathana aprayojaka tvāt iti atas pravṛttam āśrita tvāt
translated: But even so, the statement is purposeless, because in reality the threefoldness of meditation, which is not mentioned here, is not the reason for mentioning the immanent one. To this, the part beginning with 'because of dependence' is explained by supplying the word 'ca'.

analyzed: iti aṃśam caśabda adhyāhāreṇa vyācaṣṭe iha iti
translated: He explains the part beginning with 'here' by supplying the word 'ca'.

analyzed: etad prakaraṇe ukta tvāt iti arthaḥ  upāsā traividhyasya iti vipariṇāmena atra anvīyate
translated: The meaning is: because it is mentioned in this section.🔽The threefoldness of meditation is construed here with the change of 'of'.

analyzed: hetu upapādaka hetu samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' is for the combination of the reason and the explanatory reason.

analyzed: tathā ca atra ukta traividhya antargata antara upāsana artham antaryāmi kathanam yuktam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And thus, it is proper to mention the immanent one for the sake of the other meditation included in the threefoldness mentioned here.

original: 'sa etameva sīmānaṃ vidāryaitayā dvārā prāpadyata' / ai /ā / /
analyzed: saḥ etam eva sīmānam vidārya etayā dvārā prāpadyata aiā
translated: 'Having rent asunder this very boundary, he entered by this door.' Aitareya Upanishad

analyzed: saḥ etam eva puruṣam brahma tatamam apaśyat
translated: 'He saw this very person as Brahman, the all-pervading.' Aitareya Upanishad

original: 'etaddha sma vai tadvidvānāha mahidāsa aitareyaḥ' / ai /ā / /
analyzed: etat ha sma vai tad vidvān āha mahidāsaḥ aitareyaḥ
translated: 'This indeed was said by Mahidasa Aitareya, who knew this.' Aitareya Upanishad

analyzed: ityādinā
translated: And so on.

original: atropāsanātraividhyamucyata ityatrāpi kiṃ liṅgamityata āha sa iti /
analyzed: atra upāsanā traividhyam ucyate iti atra api kim liṅgam iti atas āha saḥ iti
translated: Here, it is said that the threefold meditation is being stated. What is the indication here? Therefore, it is said: He.

analyzed: saḥ vāsudevaḥ bhagavān etam eva sīmānam
translated: That Lord Vāsudeva, having torn open this very boundary,

analyzed: śiraḥ madhyam vidārya eva etayā dvārā
translated: the middle of the head, by this very door,

analyzed: suṣumnā nāḍyā prāpadyata prāptaḥ
translated: by the Suṣumnā nerve, has attained, has reached.

analyzed: caturmukha hṛdayam iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The heart of the four-faced one, is the remainder.

original: anena bhagavato dehāntaḥpraveśokteḥ ukteścopāsanārthatvāt antarupāstiruktā bhavati /
analyzed: anena bhagavataḥ deha antar praveśa ukteḥ ukteḥ ca upāsana artha tvāt antar upāstiḥ uktā bhavati
translated: By this, because the entry of the Lord into the body is stated, and because of the statement, the internal meditation is stated, because it is for the purpose of meditation.

analyzed: saḥ caturmukha dehe prāc prapadābhyām antar praviṣṭaḥ nārāyaṇaḥ etam eva puruṣam
translated: That Nārāyaṇa, who previously entered within by the feet into the body of the four-faced one, saw this very person,

analyzed: vyāsa kṛṣṇa kapila ādi rūpam ātmānam ātata guṇam sva svarūpa bhūtam ādāna ādi kartāram vā  tatamam lopaḥ samāne
translated: the Self in the form of Vyāsa, Kṛṣṇa, Kapila, etc., whose qualities are extended, or who is the agent of creation etc., who is of the nature of His own form.

analyzed: iti sūtrāt ta lopaḥ
translated: The suffix 'tam' is elided, as per the rule 'lopaḥ samāne'.

analyzed: tamap arthe ma pratyayaḥ vā
translated: The suffix 'tam' is elided, or the suffix 'ma' is used in the sense of 'tam'.

original: tathā ca tatamaṃ atiśayena vyāptaṃ niravadhikavyāptimantaṃ 'brahma'🔽guṇapūrṇam 'apaśyat' /
analyzed: tathā ca tatamam atiśayena vyāptam niravadhika vyāptimantam brahma  guṇa pūrṇam apaśyat
translated: And thus, Brahman, which is extended, pervaded, having unlimited pervasion,🔽full of qualities, He saw.

analyzed: tad guṇaka tayā tat rūpam dadarśa iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: He saw that form as having His qualities.

original: kecittu takāra eva vyāptyabhidhāyaka ityāhuḥ /🔽anena sarvagatatvaṃ tathopāsanārthamuktam /
analyzed: kecid tu takāraḥ eva vyāpti abhidhāyakaḥ iti āhuḥ  anena sarva gata tvam tathā upāsana artham uktam
translated: But some say that the letter ta alone expresses pervasion.🔽By this, the all-pervasiveness and the purpose of such meditation are stated.

analyzed: tat etat prakṛtam sarvam vidvān
translated: That refers to the subject matter. The knower

original: jānannaitareyaḥ itarāyā apatyaṃ pumān viśālasaṃjñāt ṛṣeḥ utpannaḥ aitareyaḥ /
analyzed: jānan aitareyaḥ itarāyāḥ apatyam pumān viśāla saṃjñāt ṛṣeḥ utpannaḥ aitareyaḥ
translated: is the male child of Itarā, born from the sage named Viśāla, named Aitareya.

original: 'mahidāso' / mahino mahātmāno devāḥ dāsabhūtāḥ yasyāsau bhagavānāhetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: mahidāsaḥ mahinaḥ mahātmānaḥ devāḥ dāsa bhūtāḥ yasya asau bhagavān āha iti arthaḥ
translated: Mahi-dāsa means the one to whom the great gods are servants. The meaning is that the Lord is so called.

analyzed: hasma vaiśabdāḥ prasiddhi dyotakāḥ
translated: The words ha and va indicate well-known things.

original: atra bahirupāstyarthaṃ mahidāsa āheti bahirupāstiruktā bhavati /
analyzed: atra bahis upāsti artham mahidāsaḥ āha iti bahis upāstiḥ uktā bhavati
translated: Here, it is said that external worship is mentioned by Mahi-dāsa said for the purpose of external worship.

analyzed: na ca vācyam atra svarūpa mātram ucyate  na upāsana artham iti
translated: And it should not be said that here only the nature is stated.🔽Not for the purpose of meditation.

analyzed: upāsanām vinā ukti prayojana abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no purpose in stating it without meditation.

analyzed: ityādinā iti asya ityādinā a vākyena upāsanā traividhyasya āśrita tvāt arthāt ukta tvāt iti anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the threefold meditation is based on the sentence beginning with iti and is therefore implied.

original: ādiśabdena 'taṃ prapadābhyāṃ prāpadyata brahmemaṃ puruṣametasyāmetam' / ai /ā / /
analyzed: ādi śabdena tam prapadābhyām prāpadyata brahma imam puruṣam etasyām etam
translated: The word ādi includes the following, He reached him with his feet, this Brahman, this person, in this.

analyzed: iti ādikam gṛhyate
translated: Thus, etc.

original: nanu 'etaddhasmavai tadvidvānāha hiraṇyadanvaidaḥ' / ai /ā / /🔽itivanmahidāso 'pi ṛṣitvenocyatāmiti cenna /
analyzed: nanu etat hasma vai tad vidvān āha  itivat mahidāsaḥ pi ṛṣi tvena ucyatām iti ced na
translated: But it may be argued that just as Mahidâsa is called a sage in the passage, This very thing did Mahidâsa, the son of Itarâ, who knew this, so also Mahidâsa may be called a sage in the passage under discussion. This is not so,

original: asyāḥ upaniṣadaḥ aitareyasaṃjñayaivetarāputrasya mahidāsasya ṛṣitvasiddhyā taduktervyarthatvāt /
analyzed: asyāḥ upaniṣadaḥ aitareya saṃjñayā eva itarā putrasya mahidāsasya ṛṣi tva siddhyā tad ukteḥ vyartha tvāt
translated: because the statement of the passage under discussion is useless, since the fact that Mahidâsa, the son of Itarâ, was a sage is established by the name of this Upanishad itself, which is called Aitareya.

analyzed: mahidāsa abhidhaḥ jajñe itarāyāḥ tapaḥ balāt
translated: By the power of Itarâ's austerities, Mahidâsa was born.

analyzed: sākṣāt sa bhagavān viṣṇuḥ yaḥ tantram vaiṣṇavam vyadhāt
translated: He was directly Lord Vishnu, who composed the Vishnu Purana.

analyzed: iti brahmāṇḍe
translated: Thus it is said in the Brahmaṇḍa Purana.

original: tathāpi mahidāsasya viṣṇutvaṃ kuto jñāyata ityata āha mahidāseti //
analyzed: tathā api mahidāsasya viṣṇu tvam kutas jñāyate iti atas āha mahidāsa iti
translated: Even so, how is it known that Mahidâsa was Vishnu? To this he says Mahidâsa etc.

analyzed: jajñe vyaktaḥ babhūva
translated: Was born means became manifest.

analyzed: sa ca mahidāsaḥ
translated: And that Mahidâsa

analyzed: mahidāsaḥ tu aitareyaḥ bahvṛca upaniṣad gataḥ
translated: Mahidâsa was the son of Aitareya, mentioned in the Upanishads of the Rig Veda.

analyzed: sākṣāt sa bhagavān viṣṇuḥ tad nāmā ekaḥ muniḥ hi abhūt
translated: He was directly Lord Vishnu, and was the only sage named after him.

original: iti chāndogyabhāṣye anantaroktabhagavadanyaḥ tatsaṃjñaketarāputraḥ ṛṣiratra na vivakṣitaḥ / kintu /🔽yo 'vaiṣṇavaṃ' /
analyzed: iti chāndogya bhāṣye anantara ukta bhagavat anyaḥ tad saṃjñaka itarā putraḥ ṛṣiḥ atra na vivakṣitaḥ kintu  yaḥ vaiṣṇavam
translated: Thus in the commentary on the Chandogya Upanishad, the sage named after him, who is different from the Lord mentioned just before, is not intended here. But🔽he who composed the Purana🔽which is about Vishnu.🔽He created it.

analyzed: viṣṇu viṣayam tantram 🔽grantham vyadhāt nirmame 🔽yat vā tantram
translated: Or, the Purana

analyzed: pañcarātram vyadhāt nārada ādibhyaḥ vyācakhyau  yaḥ ca sākṣāt
translated: He taught it to Nārada and others for five nights.🔽And he who is

analyzed: svayam bhagavān
translated: the Lord himself.

original: pūrṇajñānādimān 'viṣṇuḥ' /🔽tadavatārabhūtaḥ pūrvoktaḥ sa evātra vivakṣita ityāha sākṣāditi/
analyzed: tad avatāra bhūtaḥ pūrva uktaḥ saḥ eva atra vivakṣitaḥ iti āha sākṣāt iti
translated: Viṣṇu, who is endowed with perfect knowledge and other qualities.🔽The same one mentioned before, who is an incarnation of him, is meant here. This is stated by the word 'directly'.

analyzed: brahmāṇḍe purāṇaḥ iti asya āśrita tvāt iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the Purāṇa called 'Brahmāṇḍa', the word 'iti' is connected with the word 'āśritatvāditi'.

analyzed: mahidāsasya viṣṇu tva uktiḥ iti tad arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is said that Maheśvara is Viṣṇu.

analyzed: tena caśabda anvayaḥ
translated: And by that, the word 'ca' is connected.

analyzed: tad tad upāsanā yogya tayā ca puruṣāṇām
translated: And by the eligibility of the persons for each of those forms of worship,

analyzed: nanu ekavidha upāsanayā sarveṣām brahma a parokṣa sambhavāt kim upāsā traividhyena iti atas pravṛttam tad yogāt
translated: If it is argued that since the direct realization of Brahman is possible for all by the worship of one kind, what is the use of the threefold division of worship? In response to this, the remaining part of the sūtra beginning with 'tadyogāt' (3.2.1) is explained.

analyzed: iti sūtra śeṣam vyācaṣṭe tat tat iti
translated: He explains the remaining part of the sūtra beginning with 'tadyogāt' (3.2.1) by saying 'taddhi' etc.

analyzed: upāsanā iti anena puruṣāṇām iti anena ca tat iti asya āvṛttiḥ sūcitā
translated: By the word 'upāsana' and by the words 'puruṣāṇām', the repetition of the word 'tat' is indicated.

analyzed: caḥ samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' is for inclusion.

original: tathā ca teṣāṃ puruṣāṇāṃ manuṣyarṣigandharvadevākhyādhikāriṇāṃ teṣu trividhopāsaneṣu
analyzed: tathā ca teṣām puruṣāṇām manuṣya ṛṣi gandharva deva ākhya adhikāriṇām teṣu trividha upāsaneṣu
translated: Thus, among those three kinds of worship, of those persons who are entitled to the three kinds of worship, namely human sages, Gandharvas and gods,

original: madhye tattadupāsane yathākramaṃ bahirantarvyāptirūpaikaikopāsana eva yogyatayā yogyatvena hetunetyarthaḥ /
analyzed: madhye tad tad upāsane yathākramam bahis antar vyāpti rūpa ekaika upāsane eva yogyatayā yogyatvena hetunā iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that in the middle, in each of the meditations, there is, by suitability, the cause of suitability, in the form of the all-pervasiveness of the one meditation, externally and internally, respectively.

analyzed: asya upāsā traividhyāt iti anena anvayaḥ
translated: This is to be construed with the preceding phrase because of the threefold nature of the meditation.

original: tathā cānekavidhopāstiyogyatāvatāmadhikāriṇāṃ naikavidhopāsanayā brahmajñānamiti tattraividhyamāvaśyakamiti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca anekavidha upāsti yogyatāvatām adhikāriṇām na ekavidha upāsanayā brahma jñānam iti tat traividhyam āvaśyakam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that for those qualified for the many kinds of meditation, there cannot be knowledge of Brahman through a single kind of meditation, so the threefold nature of the meditation is necessary.

analyzed: keṣāṃcid sarva ga tvena keṣāṃcid hṛdaye hariḥ
translated: For some, Hari is to be meditated upon as all-pervading, for some in the heart,

analyzed: keṣāñcid bahis eva asau upāsyaḥ puruṣottamaḥ
translated: and for some, that Supreme Being is to be meditated upon only externally.

analyzed: iti brāhme
translated: Thus it is in the Brāhmana.

original: puruṣāṇāmuktānekavidhopāsanayogyatā kuto jñāyata ityataḥ kartṛviśeṣānanupādāya sāmānyataḥ upāsakatraividhyapratipādikāṃ smṛtiṃ paṭhati keṣāñciditi
analyzed: puruṣāṇām ukta anekavidha upāsana yogyatā kutas jñāyate iti atas kartṛ viśeṣān an upādāya sāmānyatas upāsaka traividhya pratipādikām smṛtim paṭhati keṣāñcid iti
translated: How is it known that there are many kinds of meditation suitable for people? Therefore, without specifying the particular person, he quotes a smrti that teaches the threefold nature of the meditator in general, saying for some.

analyzed: puruṣottamaḥ  hariḥ keṣāṃcid
translated: Supreme Being.

analyzed: devānām devaiḥ sarvagata tvena prakāreṇa upāsyaḥ
translated: Hari is to be meditated upon by some gods in the form of being all-pervading.

analyzed: keṣāṃcid ṛṣi gandharva ādīnām hṛdaye
translated: For some, the sages, gandharvas, and so on, he is to be meditated upon in the heart.

analyzed: sva sva hṛdaya ākāśe upāsyaḥ
translated: In the space of their own hearts.

analyzed: keṣāṃcid manuṣya uttamānām tu bahis eva upāsyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: 'Of some' - but for the best of men, he is to be meditated upon externally, is the meaning.

analyzed: prācuryāt eva muktiḥ
translated: The statement is made in this way due to abundance.

original: iti brāhma ityasya tattadupāsanayogyatayā tadviśiṣṭatvena puruṣāṇāmāśritatvāduktatvāditi pūrveṇānvayaḥ /
analyzed: iti brāhmaḥ iti asya tad tad upāsana yogyatayā tad viśiṣṭa tvena puruṣāṇām āśrita tvāt ukta tvāt iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ  /
translated: Thus, the connection with the previous statement is: because the men are said to be dependent due to being distinguished by that, by the qualification for the meditation on that and that.

analyzed: agnau kriyāvatām viṣṇuḥ yoginām hṛdaye hariḥ
translated: For those engaged in rituals, Vishnu is in the fire, Hari in the heart of yogis,

analyzed: pratimāsu aprabuddhānām sarvatra vidita ātmanām
translated: In images of those who are not enlightened, and everywhere for those who know the Self.

analyzed: iti ca
translated: Thus it is said.

analyzed: iti pāda antya prāṇa adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the supreme Self in the prāṇa.

analyzed: iti śrīmat ānandatīrtha bhagavat pāda ācārya viracite brahmasūtra bhāṣye prathama adhyāyasya prathama pādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the first pāda of the first chapter of the commentary on the Brahmasūtras composed by the illustrious Ānandatīrtha, the preceptor of the Vedānta.

analyzed: atra eva adhikaraṇe kartṛ viśeṣa pratipādakam viśeṣa pramāṇam āha agnau iti
translated: In this very section, he states a special proof that teaches the specific agent, with the word 'agni' (fire).

analyzed: viṣṇuḥ kriyāvatām
translated: Vishnu is for those engaged in rituals,

analyzed: yajña ādi kriyā anuṣṭhātṛṇām agnau  gārhapatya ādau upāsyaḥ hariḥ
translated: for those who perform sacrifices and other rituals, in the fire,🔽in the household fire and so on, he is to be meditated upon. Hari is

analyzed: yoginām ṛṣīṇām hṛdaye upāsyaḥ
translated: to be meditated upon in the heart of the sages, the yogis.

analyzed: a prabuddhānām
translated: For those who are not enlightened,

analyzed: manda matīnām ati alpa pratibhānām manuṣya uttamānām pratimāsu
translated: for those of dull intellect, of very little understanding, for the best of men, in the images,🔽in the images of Vishnu and so on.

analyzed: kṛṣṇa rāma ādi vigraheṣu upāsyaḥ
translated: He is to be worshipped in the forms of Krishna, Rama, etc.

analyzed: vidita ātmanām
translated: For those whose self is unknown.

analyzed: viśeṣataḥ jñāta bhagavat rūpāṇām aśruta pratibhānām devānām tu sarvatra
translated: For the gods who have not heard the glory of the Lord, but who have known His form in particular, He is everywhere.

analyzed: sarva sthāneṣu upāsyaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that He is to be worshipped in all places.

analyzed: atra agnau pratimāsu iti vākya dvayena bahis mātra upāsanā upalakṣyate
translated: Here, the two sentences in the fire and in the images indicate external worship only.

analyzed: atas eva sthāna dvaya uktiḥ  yathāśruteḥ sūrya ādau
translated: For this very reason, two places are mentioned.🔽If it were as literally stated,

analyzed: viṣṇu upāsteḥ bahis upāsti tvam na syāt
translated: the worship of Vishnu in the sun etc. would not be external worship.

analyzed: yoginām iti anena antar upāstiḥ uktā
translated: By yogis, internal worship is mentioned.

analyzed: ṛṣayaḥ ntar prakāśāḥ iti śruteḥ
translated: Because of the Vedic text The sages are inwardly radiant.

analyzed: sarvatra iti sarvagata upāstiḥ iti jñātavyam
translated: And everywhere should be understood as worship of the all-pervading.🔽And here, it should not be suspected that there is a contradiction with the BृihadBhāṣya, which says that even for those whose liberation is by external worship, some kind of heart-worship is necessary, and with the NyāYavivaraṇa,

original: na cātra yeṣāṃ bahirupāsanena mokṣasteṣāmapi hṛdyupāsanaṃ kiñcitkāryamevaiti bṛhadbhāṣyeṇa bhagavān bimbadarśanenainaṃ mocayatiiti nyāyavivaraṇena 🔽ca virodhaśśaṅkyaḥ /
analyzed: na ca atra yeṣām bahis upāsanena mokṣaḥ teṣām api hṛdi upāsanam kiñcid kāryam eva eti bṛhadbhāṣyeṇa bhagavān bimba darśanena enam mocayati iti nyāyavivaraṇena  ca virodhaḥ śaṅkyaḥ
translated: which says The Lord liberates him by showing the image.

original: agnāviti vākye 'nyaniṣedhābhāvena bimbaśabditasvasvayogyātmāparokṣārthaṃ hṛdyupāsanasyāpi sarvaiḥ kāryatvābhyupagamāt /
analyzed: agnau iti vākye bimba śabdita sva sva yogya ātma aparokṣa artham hṛdi upāsanasya api sarvaiḥ kārya tva abhyupagamāt
translated: Because in the sentence in the fire, since there is no negation of anything else, all accept that heart-worship is also to be done by everyone for the purpose of the direct perception of the self, which is fit for each one, and which is referred to by the word image.

original: mocakayogyāparokṣadvārābhūtāvatārādyaparokṣasādhanopāsanāya eva taistaiḥ prācuryeṇa prakaraṇasyāgnāviti vākyena vyavasthayā pratipādanācca
analyzed: mocaka yogya aparokṣa dvāra ābhūta avatāra ādi aparokṣa sādhana upāsanāya eva taiḥ taiḥ prācuryeṇa prakaraṇasya agnau iti vākyena vyavasthayā pratipādanāt ca
translated: And because the section is established by the sentence 'in Agni' as the means of meditation for the attainment of the unseen through the door of the unseen fit for liberation, through the unseen such as descent, etc.

analyzed: iti ca iti
translated: Thus, etc.

analyzed: caḥ samuccaye
translated: The word 'ca' (and) is for conjunction.

analyzed: vacana dvayasya api ekārtha sādhaka tvāt asya api brāhme āśrita tvāt iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ
translated: Because both statements are means of establishing the same meaning, this also is connected with the previous statement 'because it is based on the Brahman'.

analyzed: tad tad upāsana yogyatāvat tvena puruṣa viśeṣāṇām ukta tvāt iti tad arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: because it is stated that certain persons are fit for such and such meditations.

original: ato na tadyogāditi hetvasiddhiḥ śaṅkyeti bhāva /
analyzed: atas na tad yogāt iti hetu asiddhiḥ śaṅkyā iti bhāva
translated: Therefore, the reason 'because of that fitness' should not be suspected to be unestablished. This is the idea.

analyzed: anena na atra ukta prāṇaḥ viṣṇuḥ
translated: By this (verse), it is said that the Prāṇa mentioned here is not Viṣṇu.

analyzed: kintu jīva mukhya prāṇau eva
translated: But it is the individual soul and the chief life-breath (Prāṇa) only.

analyzed: kutas jīva mukhya prāṇa liṅgāt
translated: Why? Because of the indication of the individual soul and the chief life-breath.

analyzed: śata āyuḥ tva rūpa jīva liṅgasya prāṇa saṃvāda ādi rūpa mukhya prāṇa liṅgasya ca iha śravaṇāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that the indication of the individual soul in the form of having a life-span of a hundred years and the indication of the chief life-breath in the form of the dialogue with Prāṇa, etc., are heard here, it is not so.

analyzed: viṣṇuḥ eva ayam prāṇaḥ na jīva ādiḥ
translated: This Prāṇa is Viṣṇu alone, not the individual soul, etc.

analyzed: kutas anugamāt hetoḥ eva
translated: Why? Because of the conclusion, i.e., of the reason itself.

analyzed: na ca anya śruti liṅga virodhaḥ
translated: And there is no contradiction with the indications of other scriptures.

analyzed: ukta rītyā tad yogāt 🔽teṣām antaryāmi viṣaya tva upapatteḥ
translated: As stated, 'because of that connection'.🔽Because it is proper that they refer to the inner controller.

analyzed: yatas śāstra dṛṣṭyā ayam upadeśaḥ iti vā  kimartham atra antaryāmi kathanam iti ced
translated: Or, because this teaching is from the point of view of the scriptures.🔽If it is asked why the explanation of the inner controller is given here,

analyzed: antar upāsti artham iti brūmaḥ
translated: we say it is for the purpose of the worship of the inner controller.

analyzed: na ca upāsane vā antara bheda abhāvaḥ  upāsā traividhyāt
translated: And there is no absence of subdivisions in worship.🔽Because there are three kinds of worship.

analyzed: antar ādi bhedena bhagavat upāsanasya trividha tvāt
translated: Because the worship of the Lord is of three kinds, as inner, etc.

original: na ca tathāpi kathanamayuktam /🔽vāstavatraividhyasyehānuktasya kathanāprayojakatvāditi vācyam /
analyzed: na ca tathā api kathanam ayuktam  vāstava traividhyasya iha anuktasya kathana aprayojaka tvāt iti vācyam
translated: And even so, it is not improper to mention.🔽It cannot be said that the actual threefoldness, which is not mentioned here, is not a reason for mentioning.

analyzed: iha prakaraṇe tad traividhyasya āśrita tvāt ukta tvāt
translated: Here, in this context, because the threefoldness is based on that, it is said to be mentioned.

original: na caikavidhopāsanayā sarveṣāṃ brahmāparokṣasambhavāt kimupāsātraividhyeneti vācyam /
analyzed: na ca ekavidha upāsanayā sarveṣām brahma a parokṣa sambhavāt kim upāsā traividhyena iti vācyam
translated: And it cannot be said that since the direct realization of Brahman is possible for all by the worship of one kind, what is the use of the threefoldness of worship?

original: 'tadyogāt' / teṣāṃ puruṣāṇāṃ tasmin tadupāsana eva yogyatvāt /
analyzed: tad yogāt teṣām puruṣāṇām tasmin tad upāsane eva yogya tvāt
translated: Because of their connection with that. Because those men are fit only for that worship.

original: anekavidhopāstiyogyatāvatāṃ ca puruṣāṇāṃ ekavidhapāsanayāparokṣāsambhavena yogyatābhedādupāsātraividhyasyāvaśyakatvāditi sūtrārtha ukto bhavati
analyzed: anekavidha upāsti yogyatāvatām ca puruṣāṇām ekavidha pāsanayā aparokṣa asambhavena yogyatā bhedāt upāsā traividhyasya āvaśyaka tvāt iti sūtra arthaḥ uktaḥ bhavati
translated: And it is said that the threefoldness of worship is necessary because of the difference in fitness, since the direct realization is not possible for men who are fit for many kinds of worship by the worship of one kind. Thus the meaning of the sutra is stated.

original: na ca vivādakartṛtvaliṅgasyāntaryāmiviṣayatve 'udāsīnau ca tāvāstāṃ keśavaścābjasambhavaḥ' /🔽iti vacanavirodhaḥ śaṅkyaḥ /
analyzed: na ca vivāda kartṛ tva liṅgasya antaryāmi viṣaya tve udāsīnau ca tau āstām keśavaḥ ca abja sambhavaḥ  iti vacana virodhaḥ śaṅkyaḥ
translated: Those two, Keshava and the lotus-born one, remained indifferent.

analyzed: tasya antaryāmi viṣaya bhinna bāhya rūpa viṣaya tvāt
translated: Because that refers to an external form different from the internal controller.

analyzed: atas nyaliṅgānām tad tad antaryāmi viṣaya tva upapatteḥ tad virodha abhāvāt
translated: Therefore, since the indications of other texts are logically possible with reference to the respective internal controllers, there is no contradiction with them.

original: viṣṇurevāyaṃ prāṇaḥ ānandamayaśceti yuktā tajjijñāseti siddham /
analyzed: viṣṇuḥ eva ayam prāṇaḥ ānanda mayaḥ ca iti yuktā tad jijñāsā iti siddham
translated: Therefore, it is proper to inquire into the identity of this vital air and the one consisting of bliss. Thus it is established that it is Vishnu alone.

analyzed: iti pāda antya prāṇa adhikaraṇam
translated: Thus ends the section on the vital air in the last pada of the pada.🔽Thus ends the first pada of the first chapter in the commentary on the Vedanta Sutras,🔽composed by the revered Ramanuja,🔽the disciple of the revered Yamuna,🔽the servant of the feet of the revered Ranganatha,🔽the ornament of the family of Alavandar,🔽the follower of the path of the great Vyasa,🔽the follower of the path of the great Satakopa,🔽the follower of the path of the great Yamuna,🔽the follower of the path of the great Ranganatha,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakalahalla,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala,

analyzed: iti śrīmat paramahaṃsa parivrājaka ācāryāṇām sarva tantra svatantrāṇām  śrīmat raghunātha tīrtha pūjya pādānām śiṣyeṇa  śrīmat jagannātha yatinā kṛtāyām
translated: the follower of the path of the great Vaditvala,🔽the follower of the path of the great Vaditala,🔽the follower of the path of the great Alavandar,🔽the follower of the path of the great Bodhendra,🔽the follower of the path of the great Vedanta Desika,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Yaksha,

analyzed: śrīmat brahmasūtra bhāṣya dīpikāyām
translated: the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,🔽the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,

analyzed: prathama adhyāyasya prathamaḥ pādaḥ
translated: the follower of the path of the great Parakala Muni,

original: om //🔽tataḥ saptadaśe jātaḥ satyavatyāṃ parāśarāt /🔽cakre vedataroḥ śākhā dṛṣṭvā puṃso 'lpamedhasaḥ //🔽śrīmadbhāgavatam /
analyzed: om 🔽tatas saptadaśe jātaḥ satyavatyām parāśarāt 🔽cakre veda taroḥ śākhāḥ dṛṣṭvā puṃsaḥ lpamedhasaḥ 🔽śrīmat bhāgavatam
translated: the follower

original: taduktam īśāvāsyabhāṣyaṭīkāyāṃ 'brahmādīnām aprāptajñānamutpadyate śriyastu sarvadā vidyata iti vivekaḥ' / iti/
analyzed: tat uktam īśāvāsya bhāṣya ṭīkāyām brahma ādīnām aprāpta jñānam utpadyate śriyaḥ tu sarvadā vidyate iti vivekaḥ iti
translated: This has been said in the commentary on the Iśāvāsyopaniṣad: “The knowledge of Brahmā and others arises newly, but in Śrī it is always present. This is the distinction.”
